DAY SCHOOL RETURN

I HEREBY CERTIFY that the within Return is a true and faithful statement of the attendance and tuition at the No. Hazelton Indian Day School for the Quarter ended March 31, 1947.

Teacher: Jane Massey
P.O. Address: Hazelton, B.C.

Dated: March 31, 1947

I have carefully examined the within Return and hereby certify that it is correctly made out in accordance with the Instructions of the Department.

[Signature]

Dated at: APR 19 1947

Agents should see that all explanations are given by the teacher in the column for "Remarks," if the school was closed during the quarter for other than authorized holidays, and should also themselves make any necessary comments in that column.

INSTRUCTIONS TO TEACHERS

1. Fill up all the columns in this Return.
2. All the columns of the Return must be added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.
3. Number and date of holidays to be inserted in the column for remarks.
4. By the total number of school days in the quarter is meant the number of days in the quarter excluding Saturdays and Sundays. All authorized holidays will be allowed.
5. The standing of each pupil must be signified by inserting opposite his or her name the figure 1 in the column designating the particular grade.
6. No names of other than those of Indian children are to be included in this return.
7. The Quarterly Returns must end on the 31st March, 30th June, 30th September, and 31st December respectively, and be immediately thereafter in each case transmitted to the local Indian Agent.
8. When, owing to the number of pupils, the form of Return is not long enough to contain all the names, use another form, pasting it as No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns. Do not increase the length of the form by pasting another, or portion of one, to it.
9. The average daily attendance during the quarter may be ascertained by dividing the total number of days attendance of all the pupils by the number of days school was open in the quarter.
10. Should the school be closed at any time during the quarter, the reason must be given in the column for remarks for such day or days.
11. The school must be opened and closed punctually at the hours approved of by the Department.
12. This form to be used for Day Schools only.

**REMARKS AS TO PROGRESS, ETC.**

- Six children went to Port Edward in January and five returned in March. The school there was so crowded these children were not admitted.
- Those who were in the village attended very well except for a few days in January when the weather was very severe and again at the end of March when practically every child had flu.
- In January the Health Nurse from Prince Rupert visited the school and examined the children and their teeth.
- Those who attended made good progress especially in reading.

School was closed five days on account of cold. The cold weather and a measles epidemic account for very poor attendance this month.
Hazelton, B.C.
Apr. 27th, 1950.

Supt. of Indian Education,
Ottawa, B.C.

Dear sir:

I regret the delay in correction of the January report. I received it only two days ago.

I had to leave suddenly at the end of February, on account of an accident in the family. At that time I did not think I would be able to return. I contacted Mr. Davey at Easter, and when I learned they were unable to secure anyone for the position I decided to return and complete the term.

This report had gone to Mr. Leighton, and was passed on to me two days ago.

Yours truly,

May 26th, 1922.
Ottawa, May 9, 1922.

Sir:-

The March quarter return of the Hazelton Indian Day School was received by the Department about April 20th, last. Through error, a cheque for the salary of the teacher, amounting to $175 for the March quarter, was drawn in favour of, and sent to Rev. H. Hodson, Hazelton P.O., B. C.

I would request you to get in touch, at once, with Rev. Mr. Hodson and request him to return the above mentioned cheque to the Department, in order that a new cheque may be issued in favour of the teacher, Mrs. H. C. Roberts.

A cheque for the bonus for the March quarter has already been sent to Mrs. Roberts.

The Department trusts that you will give this matter your immediate attention and have the salary cheque returned at an early date.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

H. Hyde, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Sir,

re - quarterly report of the Hazelton Indian Day School.

I beg to hand you herewith the report of the Hazelton Indian Day School, Mrs. Eva Dungate, teacher, for the quarter ending March 31st, 1931.

May I respectfully call your attention to the remarks of Mrs. Dungate regarding the time the Rev. L.F.A. Hannister was teaching at the school during Mrs. Dungate's illness. This was during the full month of February, 1931.

I am firmly of opinion that Mrs. Dungate's illness, which Dr. H.C. Wrinch diagnosed as a "ner vous breakdown", was greatly due to the large number of children she was teaching in the early part of 1931. At that time there were about 40 children attending school.

The Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

I enclose herewith Stationery Department receipts Nos. 547551-2 and 547464-5 for school material for Hazelton Indian Day School, all dated July 13th 1946.

Nos 547551-2 can be regarded as complete as the present teacher, Mrs Massy, does not require the omitted six Patsy and Pat primers. However, 547464-5 is far from complete and she has indicated on these the missing supplies, signing for those marked with an asterisk *. She also advises that none of the articles requisitioned by her in October have been received.

Mrs Massy is considered by us to be an outstanding teacher in this Province and she assumed a heavy burden in taking over the Hazelton school. Without the supplies it is necessary for her to copy out a vast amount of material every evening. This coupled with the fact that she has received no salary cheque since her arrival is extremely discouraging.

It is, of course, possible that the cause for delay lies with this office which is chaotic with months of work piled up gathering dirt. Mr. Boys, the Agent, left here at the end of last month to be followed by the Agency clerk almost immediately; consequently matters of this kind can only be traced through with considerable search, no office help being available so far. We are doing what we can between the hours of 9 p.m. and midnight, consequently if this is the outcome of inefficiency at this end it would be appreciated if you would do what is possible to rectify the matter.

It is for reasons above stated that the receipts are being returned to the Stationery Branch through you rather than direct.

Dear Sir,

re - Hazelton Indian Day School.

With reference to Mr. Hoey's letters of December 27th and January 3rd last regarding the above mentioned subject with an enclosure in the former letter from the Chief Secretary of the Salvation Army and an extract from School Inspector Barry's report of October 16th last, I wish to advise you that the number of children enrolled on this school's last return is made up as follows:

Anglicans 16; Salvation Army 27; Roman Catholic 4.

Dealing with the proposal of the Chief Secretary of the Salvation Army I do not approve of two separate schools on the one reserve - if this is his idea - one conducted by the Anglican Missionary and one conducted by the Salvation Army Missionary. However, I may say the Salvation Army has done very good work amongst the Indians of Hazelton. The above proposal would cause endless trouble, dissatisfaction and disruption amongst the Indians of the one Band. I also do not approve of the location suggested by the Chief Secretary which is on another dangerous corner of the main road where two other roads meet.

However, as per my letter of December 16th last, file S-18-211, I am strongly in favour of a new two-room, non-denominational day school for Hazelton, built and fully controlled by the Department. One of several suitable sites on the reserve for the school, away from main roads, would be available at a small rental.

As there are no building contractors in the vicinity could you send me specifications of the building most suitable for a school? Special consideration should be taken into account for sub-zero weather during winters. Indian labour could be provided under a competent White foreman.

Your obedient servant,

G. C. Mortimer,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 16th ultimo in connection with the Hazelton day school. In connection with this school I would refer you to official letter of the 27th ultimo which was forwarded before your letter of the 16th ultimo was received.

Dear Sir,

Regarding Mr. Hoey's letter of December 8th may I call the attention of the Department to School Inspector Barry's reports of May 26th, 1937, and October 13th, 1938, regarding his inspection of the Hazelton Indian Day School with particular reference to the school building at Hazelton.

There is practically no playground adjoining this building, which faces the main road on two sides, and its position is really a danger to the lives of the children who have to walk on the road to and from school and sometimes play thereon. This school is not on the Indian Reserve.

The children of this school belong to various religious denominations, namely Anglican, Salvation Army and Roman Catholic. Yet the school is conducted as an Anglican Indian School.

Now that a new teacher is to be placed here next September might I suggest that consideration be given to the establishment of an improved Indian Day School - with two rooms if possible - governed entirely by the Department and the teacher, or teachers, nominated by the Department's B.C. Inspectorate, the building to be erected on the Reserve.

Should the Department favourably consider this matter an appropriation could be entered in the 1939-1940 Estimates when full details could be furnished.

Your obedient servant,

G. C. Mortimer,
Indian Agent.

My dear Doctor McGill:

You will recall that on Thursday, December 8th, I called to see you in reference to a proposal for a new school building at Hazelton, B.C. The proposal is to erect a school on the vacant lot at the front of The Salvation Army Hall on the Reserve at Hazelton.

It is reported to us that there is a considerable number of children in Hazelton of a school age who are not provided for, and these are children of parents who belong to The Salvation Army.

You will also recall I had with me a photograph showing the land where it is proposed to erect the school, and there appears to be plenty of room for such a building.

We will appreciate it if the Department can see its way clear to accept our suggestion and have the above mentioned school building provided at as reasonable early date as possible.

Yours faithfully,

This will acknowledge your letter of the 10th instant, this file number, relative to rentals due Mr. Casimel Emil Williams, Old Fort Band.

According to my files there are two schools on Babine Lake for which the Department has been paying rentals, the Fort Babine School and the Old Fort School. The Fort Babine School is the property of Daniel Leon while the latter is owned by Casimel Emil Williams. My records also indicate that as far back as 1943 rentals were being paid to Mr. Williams and continued until my arrival here in August.

I cannot fully understand why these rentals were charged against education as we have had no school at Old Fort since 1939 when the Fort Babine School was opened. After 1939 the Department did not release the building and it was kept as a dispensary and a place in which the Field Matron could stay when visiting the Reserve.

For the quarters ending 30th September 1951 and 31st December 1951 I have vouchered the rentals as a charge against Indian Health Services.

In view of the fact that the unnumbered voucher dated 31st March 1951 on your file has not been paid I would recommend that it be cancelled and a new voucher will be prepared at this office and forwarded to Indian Health Services.

Sgd. M.G. Jutras
Indian Superintendent

I am forwarding herewith Mr. Indian Agent Mallinson's letters of February 15th and March 1st, together with Babine Agency Voucher No. 475 in the amount of $34.70 covering materials and labour required for repairing the fences around the Hazelton Indian Day School.

It has not been definitely established that the Department should be responsible for maintaining the fences in this case as an adequate rental is paid to the Anglican Church for the building but, as the school is located on a corner of the main road of the village of Hazelton where there is considerable traffic and a very limited playground for the children, the fences are very necessary and, if the Department has funds available, I would recommend payment of the account.

for D. M. MacKay.
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
The Hazelton Indian Day School is the property of, and adjacent to, the Anglican Church. In August last, the fences around the Church were renewed and the workman repaired the fences around the School also, which were greatly in need of same. As the Church of England had not allowed for this extra work around the School Building, I am asked by the Treasurer of the local Church, Mr. M. A. Myros, if the Department would assume the cost of same, being as follows:

91 pc 1 x 4 x 8 232 ft.
5 " 1 x 12 x 16 80 ft.
8 " 2 x 4 x 16 128 ft.

440 ft. @ $35.00 M $13.20

10 Fence posts @ 35¢ 3.50
Labour 18.00

$34.70

Your advice in the matter will be appreciated.

S. Mallinson,
Indian Agent.
In reply to your letter of February 19th, answering mine of February 15th, I wish to advise that the Anglican Church receive $48.00 quarterly rental for Hazelton and Kitwanga Schools. Therefore, the Hazelton School rent would be $8.00 per month.

As the fences around the school were broken down, allowing horses and cattle to get into the very small playground, it really was necessary, in my opinion, to have them repaired, and I recommend that the Department assume this cost if possible.

I may say that last year the Anglican Bishop gave the Department permission to alter windows and better lighting purposes, and the Department also undertook to making a new entrance walk, which, had stock been allowed to enter the grounds through broken fences, would have broken down the new walk.

S. Wallinson,

Memorandum

February 25, 1947.

to Indian Commissioner for B.C.
from Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Re: Proposed Hazelton Day School

In accordance with your verbal request for a memorandum on the above subject I would advise as follows:

Site At least two sites are immediately available on Hazelton Indian Reserve No. 1, the first being on Lot 67 owned by the Department, part being in use for the Agency office and residence; a single building that is in need of early replacement, the size of the office being less than half our requirements and the whole structure beyond economical repair. The area of the lot is 2½ acres, about half an acre being in use for the Agency house and outbuildings. There is a fair water supply, a well being located near the house. It is in need of reconstruction.

As it is apparently the intention of the Dominion Dept. of Public Works to replace their telegraph office on the Reserve with a Federal Building that would no doubt provide for our office accommodation it is unlikely that we would rebuild our present office, and in this event the Indian Agent would no doubt be left to find his own residence, renting the present building until he could do so, after which time it could be torn down, leaving the entire lot available for school purposes. An advantage of this lot is that it is on no traffic lanes and is in easy reach of the entire Indian village.

The alternative site immediately available is about five acres practically adjoining the new class room opened in the Church Army Hall on the Village, now owned by Arthur Lowatt, being a sub-bench between that on which the school referred to is located and the flat, part of which is occupied by the Town of Hazelton, the south boundary being only about 150 yards distant. Mr. D. A. Webster of our staff states there is a running spring on this parcel. It is quite level and its twelve or fifteen feet elevation over the main flat precludes any possibility of flooding. It might perhaps be considered somewhat more central than Lot 67 so far as present Indian residences are concerned. As the owner is contemplating enfranchisement he might be prepared to consider an exchange of this parcel for Lot 67 and its improvements, in which case I would consider it as a first choice as it too has no traffic lanes adjoining.
Type of Building. As there is likely to be a housing shortage for some years in this locality I would recommend that any school include suitable teacher accommodation and be well insulated as fuel is expensive.

The present school population of 76 is somewhat beyond the ordinary capacity of two class rooms and if a third is included we should be able to accommodate the nearby Hagwilget children from the Reserve five miles distant, numbering about twenty, (with thirty pre-school age) providing transportation by a school bus service, which could perhaps be economically amalgamated with that for the proposed new Whites consolidated school for Hazelton. The present Hagwilget school is the worst in the Province and this consolidation would make its replacement unnecessary.

Hagwilget being Roman Catholic and Hazelton mostly Anglican and Salvationists with some Roman Catholics and United Church adherents I would recommend that any new school be strictly undenominational with provision for the employment of one Catholic teacher on the staff, who could handle the short morning religious exercises of the Catholic children.

If it is considered that the consolidated school is preferable to small units I would suggest that in addition to the inclusion of Hagwilget's twenty or so children, that the approximately twenty-five at Glen Vowell, (E.A.) six miles distant, be considered in the scheme as we will have to replace their school in the very early future. This brings us within two miles of Kispiox (U.C.) which has a two roomed school of the "home-made" variety, apparently built on United Church Mission property with no quarters except a gloomy manse, one of the teachers being expected by the Church to run a full time mission, as is the case at Glen Vowell.

Such an arrangement would give four rooms including Glen Vowell and almost a fully graded school of five or six rooms if Kispiox were taken in. Construction costs should not be higher as the only one of the group that could carry on for a short while without replacement would be Kispiox. Such consolidation should permit economy of class room staff as it should be possible to group them in larger numbers than is possible by the present system.

Three class rooms would make possible a school similar to St. Catherines at Duncan, with a much better average attendance than experienced there. It would also
help, perhaps, to take the edge off the clamour of these Northern Protestants for a residential school. Three or more class rooms would unquestionably make possible a standard of education much in advance of a two room division as well as opening the way for something worthwhile in manual and domestic arts.

Winter road conditions should present no difficulty as the usual snowfall is probably about the same as at Salmon Arm and ploughed out after every fall.

A factor that might be considered here is making it possible for the new school to be the center for young people's activities after school hours, using the facilities for manual training, domestic science and adult education, present recreational facilities being non-existent, the young people spending their evenings in the Chinese restaurants of Hazelton with the expected sequel, this being a subject in which I have repeatedly endeavoured to interest the local missionaries, without result.

I would strongly recommend that no definite decision be arrived at until the Inspector of Schools has had an opportunity of visiting the area and making his report and recommendations. I attach a sketch showing location of the schools mentioned.

J. Coleman,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
In the instance of non-denominational day schools, religious teaching shall take place only as hereinafter provided.

(a) Such religious teaching shall take place only during the last half hour of the teaching day and shall be conducted by any Christian clergyman whose charge includes any portion of the reserve or by any person duly authorized by such clergyman, or by a teacher when so authorized.

(b) Where so specified in such band resolutions, religious teaching during the prescribed period may take place only on certain specified days of the week instead of on every teaching day.

(c) In any Indian day school where the average attendance of Roman Catholic children is 25 or upwards, the Minister shall, if required by a petition of parents or guardians of such number of Roman Catholic children, employ at least one certified Roman Catholic teacher in such school. In any day school where the average attendance of Protestant children is 25 or upwards, the Minister shall, if required by the petition of parents or guardians of such children, employ at least one duly certified Protestant teacher.

(d) Where religious teaching is required to be carried on in any school in pursuance of the foregoing provisions and there are Roman Catholic and Protestant children attending the school and the school room accommodation does not permit of the pupils being placed in separate rooms for the purpose of religious teaching, provision shall be made by the regulations of the department whereby the time allotted for religious teaching shall be divided in such a way that the religious teaching of Roman Catholic children shall be carried on during the prescribed period of one-half of the teaching days in each month, and the religious teaching of the Protestant children shall be carried on during the prescribed period of one-half of the teaching days of each month.

(e) No separation of pupils by religious denominations shall take place during the secular school work.

(f) Where the school room accommodation permits, instead of allotting different days of the week to different denominations for the purpose of religious teaching the pupils may be separated when the hour for religious teaching arrives and placed in separate rooms.

(g) No pupils shall be permitted to be present at any religious teaching unless the parents or guardians of such pupils desire it. If the parents or guardians do not desire the attendance of pupils during such religious teaching, then such pupils shall be dismissed before the religious teaching is begun, or shall remain in another room.

Re - School Construction Program - 1947-48.
Hazelton Indian Day School.

Further to my letter of February 27th, and in particular to the proposed construction of a new Indian Day School in Hazelton Indian Reserve, School Inspector Davey, during his recent visit to the Babine Agency, conducted a school survey and inspected the alternative sites available. His memorandum dated June 30th is enclosed herewith, from which it will be noted that consolidation of the Rocher Deboule Indian Day School and the Hazelton School is quite feasible, but that it would not be desirable to consolidate either the Glen Vowell or Kispiox Schools with Hazelton. The School Inspector's Survey indicates that a 3-room school will be necessary, and although it is realized that the combined enrolment of the Rocher Deboule and Hazelton Schools last year would not warrant a 3-room school, it is believed that a number of the Hazelton Reserve Indians may have moved elsewhere temporarily because of the lack of adequate school facilities at their home Reserve for some time. It is anticipated that, with the provision of an up-to-date school establishment, a number of these will return to their Reserve.

With reference to the question of a suitable site for the building, Inspector Davey favors the site at present owned by Mr. Arthur Mowatt referred to in Inspector Coleman's
Memorandum dated February 25th, a copy of which was forwarded to you under cover of my letter above referred to.

It is recommended that Mr. Indian Agent Boys be immediately instructed to secure the necessary confirmation of Mr. Arthur Mowatt's ownership of the area, and that he be authorized to negotiate with him for acquisition of the site for school purposes.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Memorandum

To: The Indian Commissioner  
From: The School Inspector  

During my recent visit to Hazelton I investigated the possibility of consolidation of several of the schools in this district.

Consolidation

Due to the very poor road conditions during the greater part of the school year I consider that the only school which may be combined with Hazelton is that of Hagwilget. This school is a distance of about three miles from Hazelton and situated on a main road. This road is well maintained and ploughed throughout the winter.

The schools at Kispiox and Glen Vowell were also considered but the roads to these two are such that I do not consider that the transporting of the pupils from these two points to Hazelton would be successful. The distance from Hazelton to Kispiox by road is approximately 10 miles. Glen Vowell is about half way between the two and about ½ mile off the road joining them. The side road was in very poor condition when I visited the Glen Vowell school at the end of May and the possibility of regular transportation on either the Kispiox or Glen Vowell roads seems unlikely.

School Population

I have attached a tabulated summary of the survey conducted by Mr. Indian Agent Boys which shows that the school population of Hazelton will reach 93 by the school term for 1948-50, but will remain fairly constant for the three succeeding years. In this Province the Provincial Department of Education provides three teachers for a school with an enrolment between 70 and 111 and using this as a standard, a three room school at Hazelton would provide for both Hazelton and the nearby Hagwilget school.

It is to be noted that although the school population for the 1946-47 term for Hazelton is shown as 76 only 55 were enrolled. At Hagwilget the school population is 20, but
the actual school enrolment for the same period was only 10. This is apparently due to a number of families living off the reserves. As the same condition will probably exist in the coming year it should be possible for the two teachers at Hazelton to handle the school enrolment for the 1947-48 term. This would leave the Hagwilget teacher available for employment elsewhere. In addition the school at Hagwilget is in very poor condition and this arrangement would make its replacement unnecessary. Irrespective of whether or not a new school is built at Hazelton this year it seems that the consolidation of these two schools should be carried out for the coming term.

Site

There are two possible sites for the new school, descriptions of which are contained in Mr. Coleman's memo dated February 25, 1947. I favour the site at present owned by Mr. Arthur Mowatt because it is more central, unencumbered by other buildings, and is able to provide more adequate playground space.

The regulation concerning non-denominational Indian Day Schools as contained in Mr. Hoey's letter of March 3, 1947 should apply to this school as the pupils at present attending the Hazelton school are chiefly Anglican or Salvationists with some Roman Catholics, while those at Hagwilget are entirely Roman Catholic.

R.F. Davey,
District Inspector of Indian Schools

Ottawa, July 15th, 1947.

Dear Bishop Jordan:

We recently received a report from Indian Commissioner MacKay with reference to the Rocher Deboule Indian Day School on the Haqwilget Reserve and the Hazelton Indian Day School. The former has been conducted under Roman Catholic auspices and the latter under the auspices of the United Church.

Both buildings are in bad condition and should be replaced.

A two room school is required at Hazelton but a one room school would be sufficient for Rocher Deboule. The Departmental School Inspector recommends that instead of building two separate buildings, a three room school be constructed. This would handle the enrolment at both the schools mentioned above.

If you concur in this arrangement, one of the teachers employed would be a Catholic but the school would be conducted on non-denominational basis. For your information I enclose a list of regulations that have been approved for use in a similar instance at Hay River, N.W.T.

We would appreciate hearing from you in regard to the matter at an early date.

Yours sincerely,

Re: Hazelton Indian Day School

With reference to Mr. Neary's letter of March 6th regarding proposed school construction on the Hazelton Indian Reserve, I am enclosing a memorandum dated March 23rd from District School Inspector Davey having particular reference to the size of the school.

A review of the available pupilage and anticipated pupilage in the next few years indicates without doubt that a two room school will not be large enough but that the possibility of our requiring a fourth classroom is very remote. It is apparent, therefore, that what we require is a three-room school but in view of the fact that the Department has no three room school plans available and that it might take some months to secure such a plan, I concur in the School Inspector's suggestion that it would be better to construct a school somewhat too large rather than to be confronted with overcrowded conditions immediately upon completion of construction. Under the circumstances it would appear that we should plan on the construction of a four room school at the earliest possible date. I am writing to Mr. Indian Agent Boys regarding the question of access to the proposed school site and the valuation placed on the area.

-W. S. Arneil,

MEMORANDUM

To: The Indian Commissioner for B.C.

From: The District School Inspector.

Re: Hazelton Indian Day School

I refer to Mr. Neary's letter of March 6th concerning the above mentioned school in which he makes reference to proposals for bringing the children from Moricetown to Hazelton to the proposed consolidated school. The suggestion of consolidating the Moricetown School with Hazelton did not emanate from this office. Moricetown is situated approximately 30 miles from Hazelton and is on the main road between Prince George and Prince Rupert. Although this is a principal highway and is kept clear throughout the year it is seldom in first class condition. Aside from this the distance between the two schools is too great to make any such consolidation feasible and I strongly recommend that no attempt be made to do this. The Hagwilget school is the only one which I consider practical to combine with that of Hazelton. This school is in very poor condition and its immediate replacement would be required if it were not practical to transport the pupils to Hazelton. This proposal has been thoroughly covered in my previous memo of June 30, 1947. The Moricetown school is in poor condition also and should be replaced with a two room building as soon as possible.

Size of School

The ideal size for the Hazelton school is three rooms and it did not appear from my survey that there would likely be any rapid increase in the school population after 1950. It will be noted from Mr. Neary's letter that he suggests that we undertake the construction of either a two or four room school, and in spite of the above note concerning the possible increase I suggest it would be better to construct a school somewhat too large rather than have overcrowded conditions immediately upon completion of the construction. Although I do not consider it feasible to bring pupils in from Glen Vowell at present due to the road conditions it is possible that the roads may be improved within the next few years to an extent which will permit the consolidation
of this school with Hazelton and the fourth room at the consolidated school could then be put into operation. In his letter referred to above Mr. Neary gives as his reason for leaving out the possibility of a three room construction the fact that no plans are at present available in Ottawa for such a building and that considerable delay would result if plans for a three room school were to be drawn up.

I hesitate to recommend the construction of a school larger than required because of the considerable need for construction throughout B.C. and I do not wish to delay any part of this work by reason of an unnecessary expenditure at one point. However if the increased size of the Hazelton school will not effect other projects I am prepared to recommend the construction of a four room school. The plan of the St. Catherine's school would be most suitable because of the arrangement which permits the use of two rooms as an auditorium.

R.F. Davey,
District School Inspector.

HAZELTON INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

Reference 1-11-3 (151) of February 3.

We have recently received a letter from Bishop Jordan with regard to the proposals advanced for bringing the children from Moricetown into Hazelton to the proposed consolidated school. In his letter he states as follows:

"Frankly, I was hoping that some other solution than that of sending them to a non-denominational school would be found by your Department. It might not be appropriate for me to go into the most serious reason for disliking such a solution, namely, the lack of Catholic environment, but it seems to me that, if an effort in this direction has not already been made, you might instruct your Agent at Hazelton to have the children sent for the rest of this year to Lejac School. If there were some way of taking care of them in Moricetown, they could be sent there as an alternative, to the day school. But I realize that it would be difficult *at present to carry out such a plan*."

Size of School:

Therefore, it would seem that a decision will now have to be reached as to whether a 2 or 4 room school would be required at Hazelton. We have plans on hand for both of these types, of schools but do not have a 3 room school plan available. It will take some months to make such a plan and before proceeding with this step, I would appreciate hearing from you as to the exact size of school which will be required.
Proposed School Site:

It is noted that Mr. Arthur Mowatt of the Hazelton Band has asked $100.00 an acre for a two acre proposed site. In view of the fact that this land will be used for a school site and for Indian Education, it is felt that this price is decidedly high.

Elsewhere Indians have allowed the Branch a reduced rate when they realized that the property was going to become a school site to provide better education for all the Indians on the Reserve. The Department feels that when we are providing everything for the education of these Indians, the least that can be expected of them is to provide property for a school site at a reduced rate. As you are only too well aware white property owners have done this when Provincial Schools are being built. Would you please, therefore, have Mr. Indian Agent Boys approach Mr. Mowatt with regard to the obtaining of a reduced rate for this land.

I would also refer you to Inspector Davey's report of January 30, 1947 and attached map as prepared by Inspector Coleman. It would be appreciated if we could be advised as to whether there is access from the road, west of the Arthur Mowatt site into the proposed school. It is felt that the children from the bottom of the bench should be provided with access to the new school without having to go in a round about way.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR, LANDS AND DEVELOPMENT SERVICES BRANCH

New Construction of Indian Day School - Hazelton, B.C.

Reference our memorandum of April 3

You will recall that we advised you in this memorandum that it was our intention to write you further with regard to the new day school required at Hazelton, B.C. Our actual need there for the immediate present is for a three-room day school and teachers' quarters. Eventually, however, we will require a four-room school at this point as it is one of the larger centres of Indian population in the area.

Therefore a careful study has been made of the four-classroom Indian Day School plans (such as was constructed at Tuscani, Nova Scotia) and we have arrived at the following suggestions:

(a) That a four-classroom school be erected at Hazelton, B.C.

(b) That three of these classrooms be used for normal pupil use.

(c) That the fourth classroom be converted for use as a teachers' apartment. It would be necessary to provide in this apartment for two small bedrooms, a living room and a kitchen. If this were placed in one of the classrooms near the chimney, the kitchen stove could be used as in a normal residence.

We have today sent an airmail letter to Mr. Indian Commissioner Arneil with regard to these suggestions. We will advise you as soon as we hear his reaction to these recommendations. In the meantime it was felt that we should present our views to your architects so that we could be advised as to the feasibility of
these suggestions. It is our intention to have this school constructed under the supervision of your Branch. As it is a large school we do not feel prepared to undertake the supervision of its building.

Director.

I would suggest however that while Mr. Nash is here he should be instructed to make a survey of this parcel of land if it is still intended that we should make use of it.

C.W. Alger, Esq.,
Secretary-Treasurer,

Dear Mr. Alger:

With reference to your letter of June 30th to Mr. J.V. Boys, regarding the proposed combined white and Indian school at Hazelton, we have been awaiting word from our Department in Ottawa with regard to payment of our share of the cost of plans and specifications, should the proposal not materialize and I have today again written asking that they expedite such assurance.

With regard to our contributing towards the capital cost of the building, a memorandum was submitted by the Director of Indian Affairs to the Minister of our Department, on November 16th, 1948, outlining the proposal and suggesting as the basis of a contract the provision of funds by the Indian Affairs Branch in proportion to the number of Indian children in attendance. This proposal was approved by the Minister and you may rest assured that as soon as you are in a position to proceed with the construction, this Department's share of the cost will be made available.

With regard to the actual amount which we will be required to contribute, we have been requested to ascertain if it would be possible at this time to definitely settle on a firm amount. Our reason for endeavouring to establish a firm figure is that we must secure an Order in Council authorizing payment of the amount and you will appreciate that an Order in Council naming a specific amount is much more satisfactory than one which states "nine-sixteenths of..."
an estimated amount of $95,000.00" or some similar wording. In other words, can you now or later definitely fix an amount which will be acceptable to you as our contribution on a nine-sixteenths basis?

For your information I might mention that we are presently in communication with the Provincial Department of Public Works with regard to registration of our sub-division plan of the Hazelton Reserve which is a necessary preliminary to disposition of the school site, and we are hopeful that the Province will waive their requirements with regard to the development of roads within the sub-division prior to registration, as the development of the roads in this case is the principle reason for the delay at this time.

Yours very truly,

Re: Hazelton Indian Day School.

Reference is made to your note drawing to our attention Commissioner Arnell's letter of April 28th with reference to the new school planned for Hazelton, B.C.

Quite frankly, the Hazelton subdivision question has developed into a headache as far as this Service is concerned, for we have encountered one problem after another, the latest being that under Provincial regulations we must construct and gravel every street, lane and road in the subdivision before we can register our plan and proceed with the sale of the subdivision lots. As we had provided generously in our plan for streets and lanes and even exterior streets to allow for further expansion of the subdivision, the cost of building all these streets would be considerable, and we have no funds which could be used for this purpose nor have we any hope that the individual Indians who will benefit from the sale of the subdivision of their holdings would be prepared to pay the cost of opening the streets.

The School Board originally applied for a piece of ground which was surveyed as Block 10 in the proposed subdivision, but have since changed their mind and now wish to double the size of their property by acquiring Block 11 as well. As a street separated these Blocks,
and as the School Board wish to combine the said Blocks, it is necessary to eliminate the street from our plan, and while this may seem a minor point, actually it may involve sending the surveyor back to Hazelton to do re-survey work, for under the Provincial Survey Regulations, it is extremely doubtful that we would be permitted to delete the road from the plan without performing additional survey work. This difficulty is presently being taken up by the Surveyor General with Mr. Nash who performed the survey on our behalf.

As to the general problem of opening streets, we sent a lengthy letter to Superintendent Boys on May 5th, copy of which was forwarded to Mr. Arnell, outlining the general difficulties and suggesting two possible ways out of our trouble. The first was to approach the Town of Hazelton and ascertain whether the Town authorities would be prepared to undertake the opening and graveling of the necessary streets. What their answer will be cannot tell, but our request is not unreasonable in that the entire subdivision scheme came into being through the desire of the Town to secure additional land for expansion. If the Town authorities are not prepared to open the streets at their expense, then we will have no alternative but to cut down our subdivision to a small portion of the area subdivided by Mr. Nash. The cut down area will include the school site and probably one row of lots lying between the proposed school site and the Town boundary, but if this solution is the one decided on, there will again be some delay in that Mr. Nash will have to prepare a complete new plan for registration purposes.

It is regretted that the School Board is being held up in this matter, but for the foregoing reasons we certainly cannot proceed with any sale to the Board at this time nor can we advise when we will be in a position to do so. It can be taken for granted that we are as anxious as the Board to conclude the sale, and will do our utmost to iron out our difficulties at the earliest possible date.

D. J. Allan,
Superintendent,

A.M. The attached draft agreement contains four alterations suggested at a meeting held in this office between Inspector Davey and Mr. H.C. Ferguson, Provincial Inspector of Schools. These alterations are contained in additional clauses numbered 4, 9 and 10 and in the re-wording of the cessation clause now numbered 8 which has been retained on the insistence of the Provincial authorities. The new clause 4 is primarily designed to guard against the segregation of Indian children. The lengthening of the period of termination notice was considered necessary and amended in clause 8. Clause 9 was inserted to protect the financial contribution of each party. Clause 10 has been inserted to guard against either party lightly terminating the agreement. For example, it would be undesirable to have the Board terminate the agreement because it wished to use the accommodation for a sudden influx of white pupils, rather than construct additional accommodation.

Also enclosed is a copy of Mr. Ferguson's letter to the Deputy Minister of Education. This letter was written following the first conference with Mr. Ferguson. Subsequent to this meeting Inspector Ferguson again called at this office at which time clause 10 was added.

The agreement is being presented to School District No. 53 (Terrace) and the Provincial Department of Education so that they may consider the intent of the alterations before having the agreement written in legal form. It would
be helpful if the Department would express its views on the alterations so that the School Board may have assurance that the intent of the agreement is acceptable before passing it to a lawyer for final wording.

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dear Dr. Fahey:

I have today contacted Inspector Davey of the Indian Affairs Branch in Vancouver with respect to the agreement between School District No. 53 (Terrace) and the Department of Mines & Resources. It was hoped that I would have an opportunity of seeing Mr. Arnell. However, he is out of town but I shall probably be able to contact him in Prince Rupert.

The Agreement has been altered in three respects:
A new clause 4 has been added in accordance with the wish expressed to the Department in a letter by Mr. Arnell. The reason for including this clause is to prevent the segregation of white and Native children in the proposed amalgamated school. I believe there is much merit in this particular clause, as a segregation of the children would possibly defeat the purpose of the amalgamation. Clause 7 in the original agreement now becomes clause 8 in the revised copy. It was felt that a longer period of termination of notice should be given and consequently a two year period has been incorporated. Clause 9 is a new clause suggested by Inspector Davey and agreed to by myself. It is not very likely that this clause will ever be used. However, it is felt that both contracting parties should have their investment safeguarded.

I shall take up the contents of this Agreement with the Terrace School Board at the earliest possible date. In the meantime I am sure that they would be pleased to hear of any suggestions which may be offered through the Department. When
the Terrace School Board has given sanction to this Agreement it will be passed into the hands of a lawyer for purposes of drafting it in legal form. A copy of the final draft will be submitted to the Department, as well as the Department of Mines and Resources.

As it is urgent that the Terrace Board get an early start on the construction of this proposed school I shall give this my immediate attention when I return to the Comincoa.

Yours very truly,

H.C. Ferguson,
Inspector of Schools
AGREEMENT made this Fifteenth Day of September, A.D., 1949

BETWEEN

HIS MAJESTY KING GEORGE THE SIXTH
in right of Canada, represented herein
by the Minister of Mines and Resources,
hereinafter called the "Minister"

-and-

THE SCHOOL DISTRICT NO. 53 (TERRACE)
in the Province of British Columbia,
hereinafter called the "School District
No. 53 (Terrace)"

WHEREAS the Minister is obliged under the present circum-
stances to build adequate school accommodation for the Indian children
of the Hazelton Indian Reserve;

AND WHEREAS the School District No. 53 (Terrace) are
preparing to build adequate school accommodation for the White
children of Hazelton;

AND WHEREAS surveys made by the Minister and the School
District No. 53 (Terrace) would indicate the desirability of
amalgamating these two racial groups;

AND WHEREAS the ratepayers in the Hazelton attendance area
of School District No. 53 (Terrace) have approved by an affirmative
vote such an amalgamation;

AND WHEREAS the amalgamation of these two racial groups
would work for the benefit of both in making possible the provision
of better facilities, staff and school accommodation;

AND WHEREAS the financial assistance agreed upon in the
terms herein mentioned is considered fair and reasonable;

AND WHEREAS surveys indicate that the ratio of attendance
would be nine Indian children to seven White children;

AND WHEREAS the School District No. 53 (Terrace) estimates
the cost of this structure will be approximately One Hundred and
Thirty Thousand Dollars ($130,000.00) including full furnishings;

AND WHEREAS the Minister would be asked to provide nine-
sixteenth of this amount, or an amount of Seventy-three Thousand
Dollars ($73,000.00) leaving an amount of Fifty-seven Thousand
Dollars ($57,000.00) to be provided by the School District No. 53
(Terrace).
AND WHEREAS the Department of Education will provide an amount of Twenty-eight Thousand Five Hundred Dollars ($28,500.00);

AND WHEREAS the School District No. 53 (Terrace) will provide an amount of Twenty-eight Thousand Five Hundred Dollars ($28,500.00);

NOW THIS AGREEMENT Witnesseth that the parties hereto mutually covenant and agree as follows:

1. This agreement shall commence on the first day of January, 1950 and shall be subject to the terms, conditions and stipulations hereinafter expressed, that is to say:

2. The Minister shall pay the School District No. 53 (Terrace) an amount of Seventy-three Thousand Dollars ($73,000.00) which sum represents nine-sixteenths of the estimated expenditure for the establishment of an amalgamated Senior High Elementary school building fully furnished;

3. The Minister shall pay the School District No. 53 (Terrace) tuition fees for the Indian children in attendance, in accordance with the provisions of Section 133 "Public Schools Act" of the Province of British Columbia.

4. The School District No. 53 (Terrace) shall accept for enrolment in the Hazelton School children of Indian status who would normally attend the Hazelton Indian School, and shall provide the same educational opportunities to them during the period of their attendance at the School as are provided to white children.

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT the Special Joint Committee of the Senate and the House of Commons, appointed to continue and complete the examination and consideration of the Indian Act, made the following recommendation, as recorded in the Minutes of Proceedings and Evidence, Vol. 5, April 13, to and including June 21, 1950, concerning the operation of Indian Schools:

"Your Committee recommends the revision of those sections of the Act which pertain to education, in order to prepare Indian children to take their place as citizens,

"Your Committee, therefore recommends that wherever and whenever possible Indian children should be educated in association with other children".

THAT the Indian children of the Hazelton Indian Reserve live directly adjacent to the Village of Hazelton, British Columbia;

THAT both the local school and our Indian school were in need of immediate replacement;

THAT, in accordance with the recommendation of the Parliamentary Committee as mentioned above, negotiations have been carried out for the education of Indian children in association with white children in a proposed new joint school to be operated by the Terrace School District;

THAT the cost of this structure will be approximately $130,000.00 including full furnishings;

THAT an educational survey was carried out by the Provincial School Inspector and by our District Inspector of Indian Schools, which revealed that of 160 expected pupils, 70 would be white children and 90 would be Indian children;

THAT, in view of this fact, a grant of nine sixteenths (9/16) of $130,000.00 or an amount of $75,000.00 would be a fair and reasonable contribution and considerably less than would be required to build our own school;
THAT funds are available for this purpose in the Indian Education Vote of the Department of Citizenship and Immigration, 1950-51 Main Estimates;

THAT the Terrace School District No. 53 is prepared to enter into an Agreement for the education of the Indian children at Hazelton, British Columbia;

THAT, as provided in a recent amendment to the "Public Schools Act" of the Province of British Columbia, the Council of Public Instruction of that Province is prepared to authorize the Terrace School District No. 53 to enter into such an Agreement.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that authority be given for a grant to be made to the Terrace School District No. 53 of the Province of British Columbia in the amount of Seventy-three Thousand Dollars ($73,000.00) for the purpose of providing a six-room joint school at Hazelton, British Columbia, for the education of Indian children.

The undersigned further recommends that approval be given to an Agreement to be entered into with the Terrace School District No. 53 for the education of Indian children at Hazelton, British Columbia.

Respectfully submitted,

Minister of Citizenship and Immigration.
Ottawa, June 12, 1950.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Hazelton Joint School

Included in our Main 1950-51 Estimates is a sum for the provision of joint school facilities at Hazelton, British Columbia. Under approval received from our former Minister, we have been negotiating with the Terrace School District No. 53 with regard to this project. All the Indian children concerned are of the Protestant faith and live on a reserve directly adjacent to the white village of Hazelton. The Catholic children live on the Tsitsik Indian Reserve a few miles away and we intend to provide a new one-room school for them this year.

At Hazelton, therefore, we have an ideal situation for joint education and an agreement was drawn up some months ago. Mr. Cory, the Departmental Solicitor, has already checked this proposed agreement and his re-draft was submitted to the Terrace School District. We have now received the signed document from the School District and have prepared the necessary Submission to Council for the Minister's signature. It has been further suggested that we make progress payments on this project, based on the amounts due to the contractor in relation to a percentage of the completed cost of the structure at various stages, as is ordinarily provided for in construction contracts.

I would therefore recommend the following action:

(1) Approval of the prepared Submission to Council,

(2) Approval by the Minister of the attached Agreement after the passing of the Order-in-Council.

(3) Approval by the Minister of progress payments to the Terrace School District as the project advances.

August 30, 1933.

Dear Sir;

I have the honour to forward herewith my report on the Hazelton Indian Day School, Babine Agency, which I inspected on May 25th 1933.

The report will speak for itself, and I certainly very much regret that the children at this school should have been deprived of a year's work through the complete lack of teaching ability on the part of the missionary teacher in Hazelton.

The Rev. Mr Bannister has resigned, and is leaving the country. He did his best at Hazelton; but he was so poorly qualified that his life in the school appears to have been one of considerable disappointment and worry during the year. His wife's illness did not help matters.

May I draw your attention to the correspondence with regard to Mr. Bannister's appointment, and to the fact that the Department approved of his appointment in face of my telegraphed protest. The appointment of untrained teachers in our Indian Schools can lead to nothing but disappointment on the part of the teacher, and complete failure on the part of the Indian children, for whose education we are responsible.

Your obedient servant,

Gerald H. Barry.
District Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

HAZELTON INDIAN DAY SCHOOL

(Babine Agency.)

Date of Inspection May 25, 1933.

Number of Pupils present:
Boys 8
Girls 11

Number of Classrooms and number of desks in each: One; with 42 Single Desks.

THE TEACHER

Name Rev. L. F. Bannister Age 37

Salary $850.00 per annum less 10% with $70.00 per annum less 10% for monitor work.

Qualifications L.Th. Saskatchewan University. Experience of a little substitute teaching work in the Prairie Provinces. Was overseas during the Great War with the Egyptian Expeditionary Force as chaplain. This is stated to be "excellent".

Health I understand that Mrs. Bannister has contracted T.B. and has been forced to leave Hazelton to obtain treatment at Tranquille.

Success The juniors do not appear to have made much progress this year. The teacher has found some difficulty in control of the children. This is due to his lack of any training or qualification for the teaching of Indians. The appointment was sanctioned by the Department of Indian Affairs in opposition to my strong recommendation that only a trained teacher be appointed at Hazelton. The appointment of this local Anglican Minister to a position he so obviously could not fill has resulted in very poor progress during the past year, and the resignation of the teacher, who is giving up the school and the parish and is leaving for England.

No progress can be looked for till a well qualified teacher trained in a Normal School and holding extra certificates in Provincial Summer School is appointed here.

I understand that approval has now been given for the appointment of a man from Kentville, Nova Scotia, who holds qualifications I have no knowledge. It is certainly to be regretted that one of our specially trained Anglican teachers has not been appointed.

Arithmetic Grade 1B are learning to read and write numbers to 10, and to recognize Groups to 10. Grade 1A are very slow in working the Combinations and Separations up to 20. Grades 2 are very poor in the working of the Extensions. The teacher did not of course understand the teaching of these, the children being permitted to go on with other more advanced work too soon. The result of the testing of these Grades with the B.C. Arithmetic Test was as follows:

Grade 2 made a Mid Score of 23 the Norm for Grade 3.0
Grade 3 made a Mid Score of 23 the Norm for Grade 3.0
Grade 4 made a Mid Score of 28 the Norm for Grade 4.2
Grade 5 made a Mid Score of 40 the Norm for Grade 4.2

It will be seen that for this time of the year the Arithmetic (over) is "Very Poor". I spent some time with the teacher in Demonstration Lessons; but this is not an insurmountable effort as he is leaving.

New Equipment Required—
The teacher has not had a Provincial Course of Study. He was instructed to write for once only. I do not know what he based his instruction without some such Programme of Studies.

I consider that if teachers are to be appointed here without training in a R.C.W.M.S. BUILDINGS AND PREMISES

Inspectors will please mention the number of buildings, indicate their ownership and comment on their condition.

The building consists of a schoolroom of about 36ft. by 25ft., lighted by eight windows, set two on each side. This of course gives the worst possible cross-lighting. The building is located at one corner of the Anglican Church lot. The Department pays rent to the Anglican Church for the use of the room. There is little or no playground, and the building is practically on the street. There is a certain amount of automobile traffic past the school. There are two toilets in fair condition. The ceiling and walls of the interior of the schoolroom should be repainted. The floor should either be repainted or better-scraped and oiled. This work should be done during the financial year starting in April 1934.

I do not consider the building of sufficient value to warrant its removal to a better site.

Report of School Work Continued.

Vocational: The Girls' Vocational Work reported on after my inspection of October 21st 1931 appears to have come to an end. This was a very important part of the work at this school, and its loss will not be to the advantage of the local Indians.

Writing: The children have the manuals necessary for the work in the prescribed Writing Course; but as the teacher has no idea whatever of how to teach this writing, the children write largely with finger movement.

Spelling: This is very good in Grades 3 to 5 inclusive.

Art: I taught a Drawing Lesson and a Demonstration Lesson for the teacher's benefit. The Art work is not satisfactory.

Singing: The children learn to sing Hymns, Rounds, Action Songs. The volume was good, the expression fair, and the tone poor.

GENERAL REMARKS

Under this heading the Inspector should report upon the general management of the school and offer any suggestions for improvement he may wish to make.

Reading: Grade 1B are using the Work Book for Beginners. They know about 20 words. This is about the standard of Beginners in their second month at a good Indian Day School.

Grade 1A are BACKWARD. They have read selections from the Primer part of the First Canadian Reader. They can read a little and know about 50 words. They have therefore lost at least six months standing so far.

Grade 2 have finished the Second Canadian Reader. Grade 3 speak fairly well. They have a fair knowledge of the Third Canadian Reader, and are doing some work in the Reading Exercise Book for that Grade.

Grade 4 speak well. Their reading is "Good" They are using the Fourth Canadian Reader and the Reading Exercise Book for their Grade.

Grade 5 speak well. They have finished their course in the Fifth Canadian Reader, and are using the Reading Exercise Book for their Grade.

It is obvious that the failure in the reading of the Primary Grades is due entirely to the lack of any teaching ability in Primary Work.

General: The school is rapidly losing ground. If it were not that the teacher has resigned, I should have asked for his removal.

Mr. Bannister's ideas of control were as weak as his teaching. He had the children march in a ring off the school hall, and appeared to think that control consisted in some form of military drill movements.

It is of course unlikely that he will ever again attempt to teach a country-school—a thing that he was never capable of doing, and which I believe he only undertook to please his Bishop. He looks utterly worn out, and I know very unhappy at the failure of the school this year, would draw the attention of the Department to the correspondence and my telegraphic protest when it was suggested to appoint him.

INSPECTOR'S REPORT ON HAZELTON INDIAN DAY SCHOOL
Babine Agency.

Date of Inspection: September 13, 1935.
Number of pupils present: 7 Boys & 12 Girls. Total 19.
Number of classrooms: One.
Number of desks in each classroom: 42 Single Desks.
Name of teacher: Rev. Bert Shearman Age 59.
Health: Excellent.

Remarks relative to methods employed by teacher:

This teacher has made a very great change for the better in the school. His work is so far quite a success. Mr. Shearman has taken the trouble to apply suggestions made during the last two inspections at his old school, Kitkatla, and is now finding that he can achieve success by such means.

While this teacher is not in possession of any Canadian certificate, he did receive training in England, and has taught for some thirty-nine years. He was appointed to his present position in September 1934, having previously taught at the Kitkatla Indian Day School for six years.

Since my first inspection of Mr. Sherman's work in October 1931 at Kitkatla, he has much modified his old fashioned methods of teaching discipline, etc. He is using quite satisfactory methods at present, his teaching of Reading and Arithmetic being particularly good.

Remarks relative to the examination of pupils:

Reading: Grade 1C know about 12 Sight Words. Their work for the first few days of the school-year is very good. Grade 1A have finished Two Little Indians, and have started Highroads Book 1. Grade 2 has finished the Highroads Reader Book 2. They speak out fairly well and can read well. They are ready for Grade 3. The present Grade 3 are half way through Highroads Book 3. Grade 5 and Grade 6 are working in Highroads Books 5 and 6. From Grade 3 up the reading in this school is "Very Good".

Reading Exercise Work Books are badly needed for Grades 3, 4, 5, and 6. These will be asked for by the teacher.

Arithmetic: Grade 1C are doing good work in the reading and writing of the numbers to 9, and the recognition of groups to 9. Grade 1A are rather slow in the Combinations and Separations. Grade 2 are quite good in Combinations and Separations and are working formal Addition and Subtraction. Grade 3 have finished the Multiplication Tables and are working Short Multiplication and Short Division with success. Grade 5 are on Fractions, and Grade 6 are working Decimals. The whole of the above work is well up to the average, and the work of Grade 3 is above average as was proved by the results obtained from a testing programme. In the All Canada Test, Grade 2 made a Mid Score of 8 which is much above average. Grade 3 made a Mid Score of 22, the Norm being 15. Grade 5 made a Mid Score of 28, which is the Norm for the Grade and Grade 6 made a Mid Score of 34, the Norm being 32.

Singing: The teacher plays the organ. The children sang Hymns, National Songs, etc., with success.

Writing: On the whole this is Very Good. Pencil is used in Grades 1 and 2 as it should be. The rest use ink. Spelling is Satisfactory. Art Work is being started. The work of the children is on the whole "Very Satisfactory".
Attendance problem: remedies suggested, etc.

The Register is now being properly kept. The last teacher here kept the Register so badly that I was unable to arrive at any average attendance. Since the present teacher took charge this state of things has been changed. The Quarterly averages have been:

Quarter ending September 1934 21.5
Quarter ending December 1934 34

Dear Sir:

I have the honour to forward herewith my report on the Hazelton Indian Day School, Babine Agency, which I inspected on September 17th last.

Mr. Indian Agent Mortimer was with me for a large part of the inspection.

It is a pleasure to inspect schools which are as well conducted as this. The Rev. B. Shearman has done very good work here, and his control of the children is very good indeed. Corporal punishment has been very greatly reduced during the past year. The children are bright and answer well. They speak up and are alert, which is not the case when there has been much punishment. These facts are brought out here in view of my past reports on the work of Mr. Shearman.

I understand that Mr. Shearman is seeking the nomination of the Right Rev. Bishop Rix to the position of teacher at Kitwanga, which will become vacant due to the resignation of Rev. H. Flores. I may say that I have no objection to such an appointment as that of the Rev. B. Shearman to Kitwanga. I would however ask the Department in the event of such transfer of the present teacher from Hazelton to Kitwanga to insist that only a trained man with some Canadian teaching certificate be appointed at Hazelton. This Hazelton school has been working during the past couple of years and is now in quite a good condition, and it would be a very great pity to let it return to the dreadful condition existing previous to the appointment of the Rev. Bert Shearman here.

There are many things reported with regard to Mr. Shearman, such as excessive drinking, many debts, etc., of which the Department may or may not be aware. These have not been touched upon by me as I have no evidence of any of them in my possession. I have never seen him the worse for drink myself, and he certainly conducts his school well. While it is quite likely that such reports are quite true, I should not like to see this teacher removed from the staff of the Indian Day Schools at the present time. A move to Kitwanga might be very satisfactory from many points of view.

Your obedient servant,

Gerald H. Barry

Dear Major MacKay:

I am forwarding herewith my report on the Hazelton Indian Day School, Babine Agency, which I inspected on May 26th last.

Since the departure of the Rev. B. Shearman the general standing of this school has declined. The present teacher, Mr. Noel Stewart, was appointed in January.

It was owing to the fact that there was a new teacher here that I decided to visit the Babine Agency a second time during the same school year. Some other important work was completed during the visit, as the Indian Affairs Branch wished me to carry out an Educational Survey at Moricetown. I was also able to visit Kitwanga Indian Day School, to which the Rev. B. Shearman has been moved since my last visit to the Babine Agency in September 1936.

I understand that Mr. Noel Stewart will probably be leaving Hazelton at the end of June. I have not been officially informed of this fact, but I know that this young man is seeking the nomination to the Shulus Indian Day School in the Nicola Agency, and will call upon the Right Reverend the Bishop of the Cariboo when passing through Kamloops on his way to Victoria.

It is very necessary that Mr. Stewart attend the next session of the Provincial Summer School in Victoria in July. He must take some training in Primary Work if he is to be a success in an Indian Day School.

I would ask the Indian Affairs Branch to write to Mr. Stewart with regard to Summer School, the necessity for the preservation of control in the schoolroom without the present excessive use of corporal punishment, and the advisability of following the suggestions of the Inspector in regard to teaching methods and Grade limitations in the various classes. With continued help this young man may train into a good practical teacher.

Yours very truly,

Gerald H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

Remarks relative to methods employed by teacher:

Mr. Noel Stewart was trained in the Edmonton Normal School 1929-30 and holds a Permanent First Class Certificate in Alberta. He attended the Summer School in Edmonton in 1933, 1934, and 1935, and obtained the special Intermediate Grade Certificate. During the years 1926-29 he attended the Ohio State University and obtained his B.Com., Sc. degree. Mr. Stewart is a member of the Anglican Church and taught Grades 6 to 12 in the St. Paul's Indian Residential School at Cardston for the past five years.

This teacher was appointed on the nomination of the Anglican Church Authorities in January 1937. He had no previous experience in B.C. and till the date of my inspection was doing his best to learn our special programme of studies and to adapt himself to the vastly different conditions. He made a number of mistakes which I have pointed out to him. He has been instructed very clearly as to how to proceed in the teaching of the B.C. Course as far as we follow it here. His almost constant use of corporal punishment must cease, as he has been so informed. He has driven children away from school by his daily use of the strap, and then tried to get the R.C.M.P. to bring the children back to school. I have dealt with this whole situation, and would only suggest that the Indian Affairs Branch write to Mr. Stewart and inform him that he will be expected to follow as well as he can the professional instructions of the Indian School Inspector while in B.C.

I have explained to him how he is to keep the School Register, and I have instructed him to requisition certain Work Books of which he has none.

This teacher is a very active young man. He has very little idea of actual teaching technique. He tells me that although he has had five years experience and regular inspection, he has never been told what to do and where he is failing. He seemed to be very glad to have my advice and critical evaluation of his work, and he promised me that he would change his somewhat harsh methods at once. He was advised to attend the Provincial Summer School in Victoria this year and to qualify in Primary Work of which he is rather ignorant at present. He may turn out a good teacher LATER.

Dear Major MacKay:

I am forwarding herewith my report on the Hazelton Indian Day School, Anglican Church, Babine Agency, which I inspected on September 22nd.

You will remember that this school was given an unsatisfactory report last October and that there was considerable correspondence with regard to the teacher, Mr. Burling, as a result.

While I am certain that the Department will be glad to learn that there has been some slight improvement in the teaching at Hazelton, and a considerable improvement in the cleanliness of the schoolroom, the fact remains that the teacher is not well adapted for the work of an Indian school.

There are Salvation Army pupils as well as Roman Catholics at this school, and the numbers are rather too great for one man. I have recommended a new two or three room Indian day school on the local Indian Reserve, in place of this old rented hall located on Anglican property.

Mr. Burling is of course the Anglican Missionary at Hazelton. Some of the local people and of course the Right Rev G.A. Fix, Bishop of the Diocese, are anxious to have him retained as teacher. Though I do not look for any great success while Mr. Burling is in charge of the school, I do consider that it might be well to allow him to continue as teacher till a new school is erected at Hazelton, when a properly qualified British Columbia teacher should be appointed.

Owing to the fact that there are Salvation Army and Roman Catholic children here in addition to the Anglican I consider it my duty to suggest that the appointment of any teachers of a new Indian day school at Hazelton should be selected by the Departmental officials and not by the Anglican Bishop.

My present report on this school read in continuation of my report of October 18th 1938 will I believe give a fairly good general review of the situation. My own letters to you dated February 20th 1939 relative to a report from the Indian Agent of February 21st 1939 relative to Department letter 151-9-1 of February 16th 1939, and of March 1st 1939 relative to Departmental letter 151-9-1 of February 18th, draw attention to various phases of the work in Hazelton. As suggested above the present would not appear to be a particularly good time to make a change of teachers at Hazelton. Well qualified male teachers are very difficult to find owing to war conditions and a previous shortage in B.C.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.
