Dear Major MacKay:

I am forwarding herewith my report on Hazelton Indian Day School, Babine Agency, which I inspected on October 15th.

I have informed Mr. Indian Agent Mortimer that I am not satisfied with the condition of the school.

With regard to the janitor service the Indian Agent informed me that he would see that this was properly done. He appeared to me anxious to retain the services of the present janitor, possibly on compassionate grounds. I know nothing more of Mrs Allen than is stated in my report.

As you will see from my report I do not consider that Mr. Burling is a success here. He does not have the respect of the Indian parents who consider the Indian Agent states that their children are just wasting their time in school. They give this as a reason for not sending the children regularly.

As Mr. Burling only holds a temporary appointment and does not have a B.C. Teacher's Certificate, I see no reason why I should recommend that he be retained here.

We require a well qualified B.C. teacher with experience. The practice of appointing the local Missionary of the Anglican Church is a poor one, though I have little hope that the Department will wish to change this till the Two Room Indian Day School which I have recommended is erected.

I do consider that the Right Reverend Bishop Rix should be asked to nominate a properly qualified B.C. trained teacher to succeed Mr. Burling at the end of the present academic year, if not sooner.

I am very sorry that I have to report in this unsatisfactory way on Mr. Burling's work. In my last report on this school, very soon after his appointment, I expressed the hope that with an experienced teacher the children would make rapid progress. It is however my duty to point out that the present condition of the Hazelton Indian Day School is highly unsatisfactory. The Indian Agent is, I believe, well aware of this, though owing to his illness, he has only been able to visit the school once since my last inspection.

Yours very truly,

Gerald H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.
INSPECTOR'S REPORT ON HAZELTON INDIAN DAY SCHOOL

Anglican Church Babine Agency

Date of inspection: October 13th 1938.

Number of pupils present:
Boys 11
Girls 16
Total 27

Number of classrooms: One. This is a school building rented from the Anglican Church.

Number of desks in each classroom: 42 single desks.

Name of teacher: Mr. Frank Burling Age 50.

Health: Appears good.

Remarks relative to methods employed by teacher:

Mr. Burling was appointed on the nomination of the Anglican Church authorities, The Right Reverend Bishop Rix of Prince Rupert, and took up his duties in September 1927. The appointment was of a temporary nature as we knew nothing of his ability.

It appears that Mr. Burling was for some four years a pupil teacher in England and later taught in England for about six years. In the War of 1914-16 he was in the A.S.C. Trained in the Regina Normal School in 1921-22 he holds a Second Class Certificate in Saskatchewan in which Province he taught for some ten years. He also states that he taught for one year in Alberta and for one year in B.C. on some sort of temporary permits. Mrs Burling is also a teacher.

Mr. Burling is a man with a rather negative teaching manner, and appears to lack the power to organize his work. Much of the children's time would appear to be wasted, at least this is one of the complaints made by parents and I can quite understand the reason.

Mr. Burling is I believe kind to the pupils and has done his best for them, but the results have not been satisfactory. He states that he is not himself satisfied with the progress of the children; but claims that the failure so clearly marked is due to the constant absence of pupils on account of illness. It appears that there have been many cases of bad colds and coughs, possibly whooping cough.

In general the teaching and organization of classes has been below the standard of the Indian Day School of this Province.

Remarks relative to the examination of the pupils:

In general the pupils are very greatly retarded, many having been more than a year in their respective Grades. The Primary children in particular are terribly backward. The Primary Reading is very poor and the Number Work much worse. They do not appear to have any proper seat work assigned. In fact the teacher appears to me to have very little idea how to go about the teaching of the young children in Grade 1, regardless of the fact that when I was here last I explained the whole matter in great detail.
Remarks relative to the examination of the pupils continued:

It was most difficult to discover what had been taught since my last visit. Great care was taken however to be fair with the teacher and I found that:
Grade 1D Beginners were average in Number Work and knew little if anything in Reading.
Grade 1C had been in this Sub Grade since September 1887 for the most part, and were even now very backward in Reading and in Number Work.
Grade 1B read very slowly and in a word for word manner and count all their Combinations.
Grade 1A Read fairly well for such a Grade, but still count all Combinations and Separations.

I regraded most of the older children for the teacher, but could not possibly promote those in Grades 1B and 1C.

Grade 5 children after a year in the Grade were fairly good in Arithmetic and average in Reading.
I suggested that the following be promoted to Grade 6 NOW.
Mary Muldoe Age 14 Howard Wale Age 11 a very bright boy.
Ella Mowatt Age 13 Louise Wale Age 14

In Grade 4 I suggested tha promotion of
W. Wale Age 13 and Bob Simpson Age 13 to Grade 5
I suggested the promotion of Norma Robinson Age 10 from Grade 2 where she has been over a year to Grade 3
and of Richard Lattie Age 9 to Grade 3, but consider that Kenneth Lattie Age 11 must remain in Grade 3.

The promotion of Walter Wilson Age over 10 and Clarence Wale Age 10 to Grade 2 was also suggested.

These children are named here so that the Indian Agent may be able to keep a check on their progress, and in order that they may have a record when I next inspect here.

HOWARD WALE WOULD BE BETTER OFF AT A RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL PARTICULARLY ST. MICHAEL'S ALBERT BAY. He is very bright and might with proper teaching be a success. He will not learn much here I am afraid.

Kathleen Bush Age 9 in Grade 3 and William Bush Age 11 in Grade 5 are the children of a Dutch father and an Indian mother. The father is dead I understand. He had been married to the Indian woman.

The two children mentioned have been attending the Provincial Day School at Hazelton, but are now registered in this school.
I inquired into this case and am told by the undersigned that the two children have been accepted into the local Band. As Indians there would of course be no difficulty in allowing them to transfer from the Provincial School where they are not wanted to the Indian Day School. They are being shown in my classification lists below.

Wilfred Wale Age 8 Grade 1A and Fred Wale Age 7 Grade 1D have been taken out of this school as their father and mother have moved to Kissegas, where the father William Wale has been appointed teacher of an Indian Day School. The remaining Wale children mentioned above are living in Hazelton with relatives.

Arithmetic and Reading in Grades 2 to 5 are about average. I asked that the children now promoted be given the proper Work Books in Language, Reading, Nature etc., so that they could do some worth while school work while the teacher was working with the various subdivisions of Grade 1.

These Intermediate Grade pupils from Grades 3 to 5 inclusive are in general quite bright, and with good teaching would make rapid progress. They responded well to my own teaching. I asked that Health be taught for 15 minutes daily and suggested the use of a new Health Work Book published by J.M.Dent and Sons.

In conclusion I regret to say that the work done since my last visit is below the average of the Indian schools in this Province.
Attendance problem: remedies suggested, etc.

I am not satisfied that all the available children attend regularly. There are notes in the Register that the R.C.M.P. have on a number of occasions been asked to visit homes and see that children attended school. In some of these cases there are notes that the children were found to be ill.

It appears to me that the teacher does not himself visit the homes of the Indians enough.

It should be remembered that Mr. Burling is the Anglican Missionary here and that children attend his school who are members of the Salvation Army and others who are Roman Catholics.

The question of the establishment of an improved Indian Day School at Hazelton requires consideration. I do not believe that an Anglican Indian Day School where the teacher is Missionary, and not well qualified as a teacher from B.C. standards, is a satisfactory solution. Had Bishop Rix nominated a very well qualified B.C. teacher for this school, the fact that he had also to look after the Missionary work for the Anglican Church might have been overlooked, but when unsatisfactory teachers are nominated as in the present case, I would ask the Department to take action.

I spoke about this constant "Leaving the room" which as all teachers know is a sign of very faulty teaching and organization.
General Remarks

I found the schoolroom in a untidy and dusty state. The janitor work has been very poorly attended to for some time. Blackboard ledges were deep in chalk dust, and window ledges dirty also.

I am informed by the teacher that a Mrs Allen is the janitor, but that as this woman is a partial invalid, and that her daughters do the necessary work.

It is very difficult to understand why a "white" woman, and a partial invalid at that, should be employed to do the janitor work in an Indian Day School. I understand that this same woman is the nominal janitor of the Provincial School also. I would recommend that regardless of any compassionate reasons this arrangement be put an end to at once and a proper janitor appointed, an Indian woman for preference, and the teacher held responsible that the work is properly done before such a janitor is paid.

I am not satisfied with the progress being made by the children here. Many are dirty and poorly dressed.

The Indian Agent has been very ill and not able to exercise a constant supervision of this school during the past year or I am certain he would not have permitted the present state of things to continue.

I consider that the fault lies with the Anglican authority, the Right Rev. Bishop Rix, in nominating Missionary teachers without B.C. qualifications, who are in fact quite unable to teach the school, whatever they may or may not be able to do as Missionaries.

As Mr. Frank Burling's appointment was temporary in the first place so that we could see how well he got on here, I would recommend strongly that the Department arrange with Bishop Rix for a properly qualified teacher to be placed here as from September 1939 at latest.

I am aware that the Department may not have the funds available to erect a suitable two room Indian Day School away from the "White" village and on the Indian Reserve as requested by the Indian Chiefs. Such a school will in my opinion be the only satisfactory solution of the situation here. With children from Anglican, Salvation Army, and Catholic homes, the teachers of such a two Division Day School should of course not be of necessity Anglicans. In any case the practice of having the Anglican Missionary the teacher of the Hazelton Indian Day School has proved most unsatisfactory except in the case of the Rev. B. Shearman some years ago.

The present school is conducted in an Anglican Hall for which we are paying rent.

The present standing of this school is "Unsatisfactory"

Hazelton, B.C.

INSPECTOR'S REPORT ON HAZELTON INDIAN DAY SCHOOL

Anglican Church Babine Agency

Date of inspection: October 22, 1937.

Number of pupils present:
Boys 16
Girls 17
Total 33

Number of classrooms: One.

Number of desks in each classroom: There are 36 single desks 6 rear sections and 5 front sections, giving seating for 41 children.

Name of teacher: Mr. Frank Burling Age 49.

Health: Very Good.

Remarks relative to methods employed by teacher:

Mr. Frank Burling was appointed on the nomination of the Anglican Church as teacher here in September 1937. His appointment is temporary as little was known of either his qualifications or his ability.

Mr. Burling was for some four years a pupil teacher in England, after which he served as teacher in England for some six years. During the war of 1914-18 he served with the A.S.C.

This teacher was trained at the Regina Normal School in 1921-22 and obtained a Second Class Certificate in Saskatchewan where he taught for some ten years. In addition he has had about one year in B.C. and one year in Alberta on Temporary Certificates previous to 1931.

Mr. Burling will have been here only a very short time and it is too early to say much about success in the school work. His manner with the children is good. He is an experienced teacher, and appeared to be very glad to have the help I was able to give him in the organization of the work. My visit was of course made to help him to get a good start. No special tests were given to the children. My estimation of their ability was gained through their response to my own teaching during a number of short lessons on key subjects.

The children like this teacher and I feel that he will make a success of the work here.

I hope to have an opportunity next May to again visit the school. It will then be possible to report on the actual results of Mr. Burling's work here.

Mr. Burling is married and I may say that Mrs. Burling is also a teacher.

Remarks relative to the examination of the pupils:

Singing: This was quite good. The little children are taught Action Songs.

Writing: Pencil is used in all Grades as there are no ink exercise books available. I may say that there is a great shortage of necessary exercise books and other school material at the present time. I understand that the teacher will requisition for what is urgently required.

Reading: While this is satisfactory in general, Grade 2 are very backward and are only working in Highroads Reader Book 1.

Arithmetic: The proper texts are now in use. The work is satisfactory for this time of the year.
Report on Hazelton Indian Day School:

**Biography:** Suitable courses were outlined for the teacher.

**Elementary Science:** The necessary work was outlined and a demonstration lesson on Air given to the children. I had brought with me the required chemicals and was able to give a lesson which proved of interest to the pupils. The response was very good.

**Language:** The use of the various Work Books was explained and demonstrated with some care. The teacher is now in a position to make the best use of the books without any actual writing in the Work Books supplied. These will therefore last much longer. The oral work best adapted to the Grade 1 and 2 classes was also demonstrated.

**General:** The teacher's control was good. I spoke to the children on the danger of throwing stones. This was done as I had seen two or three boys throwing stones at one of the Hazelton houses the previous day. I believe that the advice taken in speaking quietly to the children on the danger of using sling shots with stones coupled with the previous police action in gathering in the sling shots from Indian and "white" children will lessen the habit of throwing stones at houses in this village.

I have recommended that the present Grade 3 be divided into a Grade 1A and Grade 2B only one boy and two girls being ready for this latter Sub Grade.

I have also recommended that the Girl at present in Grade 3 be put with the rest of her class in Grade 7 where she belongs.

The whole of the above suggestions will be carried out by the teacher at once without further instructions from officials of the Indian Affairs Branch.

On the whole the children are in Grades for which they are not ready. With good teaching they may be able to make up the lost ground by the time of my next inspection.

From the general wording of your letter, it would appear that you had swallowed a dictionary, and I would suggest that you take a good dose of castor oil. If that doesn't relieve you, try a good stiff dose of carbolic acid which would be better still.

I am afraid you are getting to be like other people who, for some reason best known to themselves, live in out-of-the-way places where every bit of gossip (which you condemn so severely in your letter) is seized upon with the result that a mountain is made out of a mole hill.

I have a pretty good idea as to the identity of the Party who started this controversy, in fact, I heard that someone had been blabbing, so your letter was not unexpected. You quoted quite a lot of legal drivel in your letter but you evidently forgot the old saying that a person is innocent until proved guilty. You heard one side of the story, and without hearing the other have already passed judgment, such as it is. Is it not possible that I was misquoted?

I have always had the greatest respect for Mrs. Garland and Ribby, and admit that I did not encourage the boys as they were constantly "butting in" making private conversations impossible, and have made no secret of this.

Whilst the letter itself was, to say the least, very insulting, parts of it were very humorous, especially lines 22 and 23 of the first paragraph. What on earth are you today that any sane person would "seeth with jealousy" at your success. It is to laugh.

It would be quite interesting to know whether your letter was written (to use a favourite phrase of yours) in your capacity as Stipendiary Magistrate, or in your capacity as third class teacher of an Indian School, and a Day School at that.

Sir—

Were anyone to ask me what were the two greatest hidden menaces to Society at the present day, I would at once answer blackmail and calumny. In a recent denunciation of the crime of blackmail, the Chief Justice of B.C. put it on the same footing as assassination, while another very prominent Judge called it one of the cancers of civilization. Calumny, the cousin-german of blackmail, is a more insidious and treacherous form of mental debauchery. In blackmail there is generally good ground and often evidence for the allegations, but in calumny in nearly all cases there is no ground at all for the insinuations and cruel innuendoes. The blackmailer is generally run to earth and receives his just and deserved punishment, the false calumniator generally runs scot-free while his victims suffer terribly. Just now in Church House we are awaiting with some nervous apprehension the return of the mosquito - that stinging, ubiquitous nuisance which drives people frantic with uneasiness and discontent. But we thank God that the insect is moribund and inert for the greater part of the year. The mosquito plies his mischievous trade while the sun shines and the swamps emit their putrescent miasma. On the other hand the calumniator flourishes in the dark throughout the year. He thrives on the garbage of his own ill-functioned and diseased mind. He is usually an ill-bred fellow and seethes with jealousy at the other fellow's success. He is the personification of the dog in the manger. His usual method is to fasten on to some idle gossip, which he enlarges, magnifies and paints in lurid colors, and then disseminates secretly and maliciously. He is the poison gas expert of society, and the fumes from his devilishly slung bombs are as murderous and the effects as far-reaching as ever were those of the Germans on the battlefields of Flanders.

The burglar, the hold-up man, and the brigand are gentlemen to him. The highwayman of old came out in the open, the victims' loss was merely temporal and remediable; the criminals generosity and fame were sung in ballads and praised in folklore. What can we say of the calumniator? He works in the dark and the wounds he inflicts are deadly. He rarely over-steps the barbed wire entanglements of criminal libel. When trapped or confronted with his victim he utters pallid excuses, cringes like a leprous hound and falters.

We all despise the female gossip who hangs over the neighbors' walls; we should doubly condemn and treat as a pestilence the male gossip who ruins his fellow man with his over-ready tongue. Proverbs of all countries tell us "beware of the man who goes amongst his fellows with a loose tongue". Countless suicides, impoverished and unhappy homes, stunted and distorted lives are some of the results of the calumniators' trade. His stings are as fatal to man as those of the tee-tee fly to animals.
Annias and Saphira were calumniators when God struck them dead. It would be a happier world today if these two had been the last of their vile species.

During the Winter a quaint little trio of figures representing three monkeys sitting in similar poses were on sale in the fifteen cent stores of the City of Vancouver. Every calumniator amongst us should have purchased one of these made idols and bowed down to these figures in repentance and deep reverence. The figures exemplify in the monkey what should be the cardinal virtues in every uprighteous man, "Speak no evil, see no evil, hear no evil."

And, as in society and amongst larger congregations of the human species, so it is in smaller communities and organizations. We know that a worm will sink a ship or destroy a costly edifice if given time enough. In like fashion will the canker of the calumniator spread through and putrefy the foundations of good fellowship, and comradeship, upon which all friendly groups, societies and associations are built. The plagues of suspicion and discontent, the fires of jealousy and greed, fanned by the foul breath of the liar and malignant - have at every stage of history been the chief destroying factors in the lives of the nations, communities, organizations and associations. Let us always remember the immortal words of the great Shakespeare "He who steals my purse steals trash, but he who filches from me my good name, steals that which not enriches him, but leaves me poor indeed."

In conclusion I hope that this letter will be of some benefit to you. At the same time I must request that in your peregrinations up and down the Coast, you will refrain from using my name, or that of my wife, or any member of my family in the manner that you have done, or I regret that I shall be compelled to take some steps to prevent you.

Yours truly,

Sir,

On May 26th, 1928, I received the following information re Arthur Ladsey Garland, the Indian Day School teacher at Church house, B. C., in this Agency, and, as Garland is an employee of this Department, I think this information should be placed in your possession.

My informant told me that he knew Garland intimately, having lived next door to him in Winnipeg for a considerable period, and informed me that "Captain" Garland formerly held a responsible position at the Manitoba Provincial Income Tax Office, but lost this position on account of dabbling in politics.

At one time Garland and Mayor (or Major Webb) were partners in the Garrick Hotel, Garry Street, Winnipeg, where considerable bootlegging took place.

I was also informed that Garland went in for smuggling liquor into the United States, using airplanes for transporting the liquor across the border. Garland usually made the trip on the plane to collect for the shipment of liquor.

My informant told me that Garland "got in bad" with the Winnipeg Police and had to get out of town and that is the reason he came to the coast. He also informed me that Garland was a magistrate in Winnipeg and in this capacity tried other bootleggers who usually were given the limit so as to stop opposition.

Garland at one time lived at Sadler Avenue W. St. Vital, and the parents of my informant lived at 128 Berriydale Avenue, St. Vital, Winnipeg.

I was also informed that Garland was born at Bray, Ireland, and was educated at Trinity College, Dublin. He lived in England for several years. My informant readily identified Garland in the attached photograph and mentioned the names of the children. On the 8th January I wrote to Mr. Bartlett:

"Francis Louie an Indian of the Squirrel Cove Band has come to me in my official capacity as Stipendiary Magistrate and has made the following statement. That sometime during the early part of October he killed a cougar on Cortes Island; that as you were in the vicinity at the time, he gave you this cougar skin and that you told him you would obtain for him the bounty offered by the Provincial Government. He tells me that he has seen you several times since but that he has not yet received either the skin back or the bounty. He now desires to take what legal steps may be necessary to obtain this bounty or the return of the skin. I might add that the matter is known to the Provincial Police Department at Powell River and one of the Provincial Constables was here yesterday and spoke to me concerning the matter. In other words he was making enquiries so as to take more steps, what these steps are I do not know but to clear up the matter I do wish that you would write to me by return mail giving me the full history of this affair as far as it concerns you. With kind regards, Yours truly."

On the 11th January I received Mr. Bartlett's reply:

"Sir,- Your letter of January 8th re Francis Louie's Cougar skin to hand and contents noted. It is ages since I received such a letter and for a while I had visions of the Penitentiary staring me in the face.

You really should get a job writing scareheads for the newspapers.

Now about the cougar skin. On October 14th at Redonda Cannery, Francis Louie through William Mitchell asked me if I would take a cougar skin down to Vancouver with me when I went down and collect the bounty ($40.00) on same for him. I asked him why the skin was not taken to the Provincial Police at Powell River and was informed that the Provincial Police would not accept it. I did not want to bother with the skin as I have had lots of experience in collecting moneys for Indians in this manner and apart from the time it takes running from one office to another, I am usually out of pocket over the business.

I did not return to Vancouver until Oct. 26th, and left right away for another trip. Since then I have been travelling around and had not the time or opportunity to attend to the skin until recently.

I have already taken the skin to the Government Agent here who punched the ear, and I have also presented the application for the bounty. I am now awaiting the arrival of the cheque together with the skin.

Re the last paragraph of your letter re the Prov. Police, I may say that Constable Boyt was with me at the Prov. Game Office yesterday when I went to make enquiries about the bounty. He did not mention anything about those mysterious "traps" which are to be taken against me. I may add that I saw Francis Louie at Squirrel Cove the week before Christmas, and told him the difficulty I had in obtaining the bounty. Francis Louie said it was all right no hurry.

I am sending you some copies of the forms of application for bounties which you will be able to make use of future cases of this nature in your official capacity as Stipendiary Magistrate.

Kindest regards to everyone, Yours truly,

MR. GARLAND: After that, sir, I went back again to Church House and the matter so troubled me that I wrote to Mr. Bartlett on February 19th, 1927:

"Sir:

Were anyone to ask me what were the two greatest hidden menaces to Society at the present day, I would at once answer 'Blackmail and Calumny.' In a recent denunciation of the crime of blackmail, the Chief Justice of B.C. put it on the same footing as assassination, while another very prominent Judge called it one of the cancers of civilization. Calumny, the cousin-german of Blackmail, is a mere insidious and treacherous form of mental debauchery. In blackmail there is generally good ground and often evidence for the allegations, but in calumny in nearly all cases there is no ground at all for the insinuations and cruel imbecilities. The blackmailer generally runs to earth and receives heavy and deserved punishment, the foxy calumniator generally runs into effect while his victims suffer terribly. Just now in Church House we are awaiting with some anxious apprehension the return of the mosquito - that stinging, ubiquitous nuisance - which drives people frantic with uneasiness and discontent. But we thank God that the insect is moribund and inert for the greater part of the year. The mosquito plies his mischievous trade while the sun shines and the swamps exude their putrescent miasma. On the other hand the calumniator flourishes in the dark throughout the year. He thrives on the garbage of his own ill-functioned and diseased mind. He is usually an ill-bred fellow and seethes with jealousy at the other fellow's success. He is the personification of the dog in the manger. His usual method is to rest on to tell idle gossip, with the object of magnifies and plaintively in lurid colours and then disseminates secretly and maliciously. He is the poison gas expert of society, and the fumes from his devilishly sling bombs are as murderous and the effects as far-reaching as ever were those of the Germans on the battlefields of Flanders."
The burglar, the hold-up man, and the brigand are gentlemen to him. The highwayman of old came out in the open, the victims' loss was merely temporal and remediable; the criminals generosity and fame were sung in ballads and praised in folk lore. What can we say of the calumniator? He works in the dark and the wounds he inflicts are deadly. He rarely over-steps the barbed wire entanglements of criminal libel. When trapped or confronted with his victim he utters pallid excuses, cringes like a leprous hound and falters.

We all despise the female gossip who hangs over the neighbors' wall; we should doubly condemn and treat as a pestilence the male gossip who ruins his fellow man with his ever-ready tongue. Proverbs of all countries tell us "beware of the man who goes amongst his fellows with a loose tongue." Countless suicides, impoverished and unhappy homes, stunted and distorted lives are some of the results of the calumniators' trade. His stings are as fatal to man as those of the tse-tse fly to animals.

Ananias and Sapphira were calumniators when God struck them dead. It would be a happier world today if these two had been the last of their vile species.

During the Winter a quaint little trio of figures representing three monkeys sitting in similar poses were on sale in the fifteen cent stores of the City of Vancouver. Every calumniator amongst us should have purchased one of these made idols and bowed down to these figures in repentance and deep reverence. The figures exemplify in the monkey what should be the cardinal virtues in every uprighteous man, "Speak no evil, see no evil, hear no evil."

And, as in society and amongst larger congregations of the human species, so it is in smaller communities and organizations. We know that a worm will sink a ship or destroy a castle sufficed if given time enough. In like fashion will the cancer of the calumniator spread through and putrefy the foundations of good fellowship, and comradeship, upon which all friendly groups, societies and associations are built. The plagues of suspicion and discontent, the fires of jealousy and greed, fanned by the foul breath of the liar and malignant - have at every stage of history been the chief destroying factors in the lives of the nations, communities, organizations and associations. Let us always remember the immortal words of the great Shakespeare "He who steals my purse steals trash; but he who filches from me my good name, steals that which not enriches him, but leaves me poor indeed."

In conclusion I hope that this letter will be of some benefit to you. At the same time I must request that in your peregrinations up and down the Coast, you will refrain from using my name, or that of my wife, or any member of my family, in the manner that you have done, or I regret that I shall be compelled to take some steps to prevent you.

AHG—Yours truly,

A.H.-Garland."

It is quite possible, although I have no clear recollection of the incident, that this letter was written with a lot of others, also that I saw an opportunity to go to Church House and went, and this may account for the fact that I reached Church House before the letter in question reached Mr. Garland and even before it was written by the stenographer. I have every reason to believe that the date on that letter is correct. Whatever may have been the facts of this incident I can give most solemn assurance to Mr. Garland that there was no design against Mr. Garland or disposition to thwart him in any way in that incident.

On reaching
On reaching Church House I held a meeting with the Indians, Mr. Garland and Mr. Bartlett being present at this meeting. The Chief, George Harry, was addressing me in the presence of the Indians and referred to Mr. Garland as a good man, a good teacher, and that the people liked him.

We adjourned, as Mr. Garland stated in his evidence this morning, for a little refreshment in the form of lunch. The meeting was adjourned to the evening and to resume at the call of the Chief, not the call of Mr. Garland, nor of the Indian Agent, but of Chief George Harry himself.

I left the boat at the wharf at the appointed time to attend the meeting, leaving Mr. Bartlett on the boat who said he wanted to clean up before he came up to the meeting. I went along the flat's alone toward the village and saw Chief George Harry coming toward me. He addressed me with whispering voice in these words: "Mr. Perry, that teacher Mr. Garland bad man. Don't you say anything to him. That man is fooling with the Indian women all the time and gives them whiskey." I responded somewhat angrily to the Chief and said to him: "In the meeting this afternoon you told me what a good man Mr. Garland was, now you tell me a different story, it is the same story that you told Mr. Cairns when he was here but you have told the wrong man this time, I am going to find out about this."

"It is true," he said, "It is true. You come up to my house right now." I said: "How about the meeting?" The Chief replied: "The meeting all right. I am the boss for the meeting." He said: "I have bottle of rum that Mr. Garland gave my daughter Mrs. Moses Wilson. She drink it in my house, my wife had some, they both say it is rum."

Before going to the Chief's house I went back to the boat and mentioned to Constable Bartlett what the Chief had said and suggested, in order that there be no misunderstanding, and that the incident would be properly witnessed, that Mr. Bartlett should come with me to the Chief's house. This he did, where a bottle was produced containing rum. It was a medicine bottle. I asked the Chief where he got it. He said that Mr. Garland had given it to his daughter, Mrs. Wilson. I sent Constable Bartlett to Mrs. Wilson's house to bring her to the Chief's house, and presently she came. The statements that were made both by the Chief and his daughter, and wife, were thought by me to be sufficiently important to warrant the taking of an affidavit and taking possession of the bottle with the intoxicant in it.

Now, although Mr. Garland was not more than 100 yards or so away at the Mission House, it did not occur to me for a moment to send for Mr. Garland or make any undue stir or excitement. As a matter of fact, I did not believe the story and told Mr. Bartlett so, knowing the character of the principals of the story. In any event I would not involve Mr. Garland on a simple rumour. If I were to take serious action upon each and every rumour which I hear on every hand from Indians, both I and the Department would be in hot water all the time; the teachers, officials and the Indians would have to put up with a very unpleasant atmosphere without any good results.

After taking the affidavit I told the Chief I would look into the matter and I went up to Mr. Garland's residence with Mr. Bartlett; showed the affidavit and bottle to Mr. Garland asking him to give me his observations on the matter. Mr. Garland emphatically denied with the gesture of an oath to Almighty God that he had not been guilty of supplying this Indian woman with liquor nor any other Indian woman, nor had he been guilty of any other immoral offense toward Indian women. It was a rather delicate situation for me particularly as I regard with great respect Mr. Garland and his family, also taking
taking into respectful consideration Mr. Garland's seniority of years. I did not believe the story.

Mr. Garland stated yesterday he thought I was impulsive, probably we are both impulsive. I felt that if I were to bring this affidavit and bottle back to Vancouver and keep on record here against him it might give Mr. Garland a feeling that I as Indian Agent was holding something in the form of evidence against him so be used conveniently by me on some possible but not probable future occasion. So I thought I would play the game with Mr. Garland, be fair with him, so I handed him the affidavit and bottle, partly to let him see that there was no ill-feeling and that I was anxious to support him if he was innocent, as I believed him to be. Some perhaps may think that I was indiscreet for doing that but I will take the responsibility for it.

We held our meeting with the Indians, finished up our business took a walk with Mr. Garland through the village end next morning left Church House.

Now the Inspector, Mr. Cairns, and I were reviewing that incident and reviewing the letter of the 10th December received from Chief Harry. The pros and cons referred to in my letter to Mr. Garland of December 22nd, 1927 were on the one hand - the pros constituted the written statements of the Indians and the cons would be what we believed to be the good reputation of Mr. Garland - Mr. Garland with his wife and children - a responsible Magistrate. These constituted the pros and cons as we can officially interpret them.

We also decided in our discussion of the matter that we would not give Chief George Harry or any low bred Indian of his type the satisfaction of our rushing up to Church House simply because they choose to take an action against Mr. Garland's accusations and which would put them in a position at any time to say to Mr. Garland: "We write down and tell, Mr. Parry, Indian Agent, and School Inspector about you, very quick we fix you." We have known this happen before, so that if Mr. Garland thinks that the investigation should have been made promptly, I want to say that this explanation, that it was to his advantage and for his sake alone and his family that we did not rush up there. Mr. Garland stated this morning regarding certain complaints against Mr. Nicholson and in that matter I may say that it also was discussed between Mr. Cairns and myself and it was decided that instead of rushing at things that the Inspector of Schools would in due course be making his regular trip of inspection and if at that time the complaints against the teachers had not died down, the fullest investigation would be made into all the circumstances. Since that time I have been to Sliammon and at a meeting of the Sliammon Indians an Indian woman stood up in the person of Mrs. Frank Paul, castigated the man for hesitating to speak and she said the women would do the speaking. They demanded the removal of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholson, saying they were no good, and when I asked this woman who said Mr. and Mrs. Nicholson were no good, the woman said Mr. and Garland of Church House had told a certain Indian of Sliammon that Mr. and Mrs. Nicholson were no good and that if the Indians would ask the Department to remove them they, Mr. and Mrs. Garland would come down to Sliammon and give them some service. I asked the woman the name of the Indian who circulated this report and she gave me the name of Willie Bob. Constable Bartlett and Mr. Nicholson were both present at the meeting. I did not further investigate this matter because Mr. Inspector Cairns had told me he had written to the Chief stating he would be making an official trip of inspection.

In the
MR. PERRY: in the usual way some time in the near future. This Mr. Cairns had done because complaint had reached him of which he himself is able to give particulars if he wishes.

I now come, Mr. Commissioner, to

MR. PERRY: I now come, sir, to my letter addressed to Mr. Garland of December 22nd, 1927, to which exception was taken in strong terms by Mr. Garland in his letter to me of January 14th.

I may say that in the meantime the Agency launch had returned from Northern points and Mr. Bartlett and Mr. Rosenberg were in the City. I had before me the three letters of Mr. Garland already referred to of December 6th, 11th, and 12th, for reply. There is only a weekly service to Church House, which accounts for the fact that these three letters were answered at one and the same time. Mr. Rosenberg gave me the particulars of the mix-up at Church House. I had sent him there to supervise the renovation of the interior of the Indian houses. He reported to me that whilst sitting in his cabin on the Reserve on the Saturday evening in question Moses Wilson and his son Albert, Indians of Church House, came into the Reserve in a state of intoxication on their way to his cabin and had told him that they could easily black his eyes if they wanted to. There appears to be no particular reason for these threats beyond that these men were drinking. Mr. Rosenberg explained that he saw Wilson about to leap on him when he ducked and the Indian Wilson came into contact with a Church House Indian named Tommy Paul. A fight began and the door flew open and there was an inrush of men and women, a general mêlée or free for all fight in which some of the Indians were injured. Mr. Rosenberg is a Danish physicist and could easily have cleaned up the lot of them but refrained from doing so because I had warned him before going to Church House on no account or at any time to have any trouble whatever with the Indians. That in short is what he reported.

MR. GARLAND: Those details related to me are entirely new to me. I insisted upon his staying in our quarters because he was afraid to go down.

MR. PERRY: In regard to this letter, Mr. Commissioner, I will take it out of my clause as far as I can. I notified Mr. Garland that Mr. Rosenberg had given me the details verbally. In addition to Mr. Rosenberg's information however, Dominion Constable Bartlett had returned to Vancouver and had discussed with me the various phases of the cases at Church House. He told me certain Indians had complained that they had incurred expenses in aiding Mr. Garland in the prosecution of the cases against the defendant Indians, also had given certain information, but that although the Indians had done this and had incurred the expense or using gasoline and their time going from Church House to Squirrel Cove, they had not been paid anything for their services and they felt they should receive compensation. As far as I am able to recollect Mr. Bartlett gave me to understand that he had Investigated
MR. PERRY: investigated the circumstances and found that the Provincial Police had laid the information. I could then readily understand how unless provision had been made for it by the Magistrate, the Indians might not receive either the moieties of the fine or any expenses incidental to the costs of prosecution.

Mr. Garland said in his letter that he was calling the attention of the Hon. Attorney General to the matter of certain Indians perjuring themselves and when I read his letter I naturally concluded he had done so. I could not interpret this letter any other way except on a strictly technical analysis, and I wish here to say that if it were necessary for any official handling the amount of correspondence which we handle in this office to split hairs as it were over the technical interpretation of every word we would never be able to get through our work with the present staff. In fact, one would need almost a scholastic professor to satisfy Mr. Garland, if one can judge the evidence he gave yesterday on this point. I say this with great respect to Mr. Garland. Here I feel that I should give you an idea of a portion of the correspondence that has had to do with Mr. Garland and the Indians in the few months he has been there.

Here the Indian Agent showed the Commissioner two extraordinary files of Mr. Garland's correspondence.

MR. PERRY: Now, sir, it is for you to judge on that point. I may not have been strictly technically correct but if you will take the contents of the letter itself, you will not see therein any offence to Mr. Garland.

I maintain there was no indication of a lie and I say there was no lie in except that it may be said to be a technical one.

I felt it was not a matter of my interference. I never interfere with the course of correspondence between the Stipendiary Magistrate and Attorney General, although I am a Justice of the Peace ex officio it is not within my province to interfere with cases where Indians perjure themselves.

You quite properly put it before the Attorney General and I had no jurisdiction to interfere.

My position, Mr. Commissioner, will have to be judged by you on that point. I acted as I thought fit at that time.

"It is understood that you have been in communication with the Indian Commissioner."

This, sir, is that in connection with your enquiry on your visit, in which you informed Mr. Bartlett that you had received certain communications with regard to these cases and I assumed, and take responsibility for assuming, that the cases had been communicated by Mr. Garland. It was my understanding. I did not say that Mr. Garland had communicated with the Indian Commissioner.

"With regard to your statement that Moses Wilson offered you $100.00 ........."

In this matter, Mr. Bartlett reported this incident to me verbally, and before this letter was sent to Mr. Garland I read this communication to Mr. Bartlett to be sure it was correct.

This letter
This letter was not written with any intention to complain but to show you how far I could go in this matter, and get the details with which I was not familiar.

"This, also, however, ..............."

By machinery, Mr. Commissioner, I mean the machinery of the law, where you have a Magistrate with power to deal with the cases and Provincial Police to deal with it. The perjury complained of by Mr. Garland took place, I presume, at the cases in Court.

"Under the circumstances........"

There is no need for further comment on that, sir; I have already said that when anything is in the hands of the Commissioner, it would be quite improper for me to interfere.

"It has been reported to me ......."

That was my information from Mr. Bartlett.

"that you allowed Indians to incur expenditure..."

You sent Willie Francis down from Church House to Squirrel Cove.

In this letter I say "It has been reported to me..."

That report to me, as I have already said, was by Constable Bartlett in the course of his duty and accepted by me, and I wrote to you to get your confirmation and seek further light. The very fact that I wrote this letter to you shows that I wanted to get your view.

No reflection on you in writing this letter.

Now, in regard to the complaints of a very serious nature I again repeat that Mr. Garland himself opened up the first official communication in regard to complaints made against him of a very serious nature.

Regarding complaints of a serious nature I stated in my letter that Inspector Cairns and I had been discussing them pro and con. By pro I meant the review of the incident at Church House when Chief Harry made complaint against Mr. Garland to Inspector Cairns, and the examining of the recent complaints of the Indians which had been received. By con in this letter I referred to the attitude which I took officially at Church House in June when complaints were made to me against Mr. Garland, and also our own personal feeling and goodwill toward Mr. and Mrs. Garland and their family.

We decided instead of rushing up to Church House immediately to satisfy a few disgruntled and ill bred Indians it would be better to make a quiet enquiry in the ordinary pursuit of official business. Had we rushed up to Church House immediately on hearing of these complaints, it would give any Indians ill-disposed towards the teacher an opportunity to confront the teacher with the threat of sending for the officials, if they, the Indians, thought that by so doing they would have a train of officials rushing up to investigate their scandal.

I feel that the course taken by Inspector Cairns and myself was most manifestly fair toward Mr. and Mrs. Garland.

Now we come to complaints of a very serious nature received from Church House Indians:

MR. PERRY: On January 3rd, a letter was addressed to me from Ottawa as follows:

Sir:
The Department has received a communication from an Indian at Church House, B.C., who signs the name "Chief Geo. Harry", in which he makes certain statements regarding the personal conduct of Mr. A. H. Garland, teacher in the Homalco Indian Day School. I shall be pleased if you will state whether any notice should be taken of his letter and also, if you have any information regarding the associations of Mr. Garland with the Indian women on the Reserve, if you will furnish a full report regarding same.

Your obedient servant,
A. F. MacKenzie."

In answer to the Department's letter I sent this letter dated January 17th, 1928:

"Sir:
I beg to acknowledge receipt of Departmental letter No. 167-83-1, dated January 3rd, instant, relative to complaints reaching the Department as to the alleged misconduct of Mr. A. H. Garland, Homalco Indian Day School teacher with Indian women in the Homalco reserve at Church House, B.C.

In reply I beg to say I would suggest for the present acknowledge the letter saying the matter is being investigated by the Indian Agent. I propose going to Church House at the earliest moment when I will fully investigate the complaints and make a complete report to the Department. I say that I have received complaints before about similar alleged conduct on the part of Mr. Garland, but the complaints have come from the members and relatives of Chief George Harry, while mention has reached me from practically the balance of the band members referring to the Chief as a bad man and a "mink" and asking that the teacher be kept in his position. Mr. Garland is a Stipendiary Magistrate and in this capacity has taken very drastic action recently amongst the members of Chief Harry's family for drunkenness in the Homalco village, fining them heavily.

The Department will probably remember that formerly the Homalco Band were in two divisions - the Homalco and Orford Bay, respectively. These two factions have never been well disposed towards each other and I have repeatedly endeavored to keep them united in one big family which is always best for the Indians in every way. Unfortunately these Indians are of a very inferior status and it is not to be wondered at if they, upon the least provocation, revert to antipathies and quarrelling especially where intoxicants are introduced.

The Department will probably remember that some time ago I was complained against by the same Chief to the Department because I threw him out of my office in Vancouver. The Chief is inclined to the use of intoxicants and I have received several complaints against him.

Apart from this I have received rather disquieting report from responsible white sources as to Mr. Garland's conduct with a certain Indian woman, but unfortunately I cannot get the matter of complaint in writing although I have tried to do so. If I could obtain proof of this report

I would..."
I would immediately recommend action by the Department. Until this report is cleared up I am naturally suspicious that there may be something in the rumours going around about Mr. Garland's conduct; although it is hard to believe them as Mr. Garland has his wife and three children residing with him in the house and village.

Another matter is that of an affidavit which I took from Chief Harry's daughter, Mrs. Moses Wilson, on a visit to Church House to the effect that Mr. Garland had given her a medicine bottle full of rum and that she had taken it to the Chief's house and made her mother drunk with it. The bottle, half full of rum, was handed to me by Chief Harry. Upon presenting the affidavit to Mr. Garland and showing him the bottle, he denied it on oath and squared himself as a Roman Catholic saying he believed that the occurrences were machination of certain white residents in the locality, who had been dealt with by Mr. Garland as a Magistrate, in concert with a few disgruntled Indians. Mr. Garland swore he would try to get at the bottom of the matter but so far he has failed to do so and the recent complaints are apparently a recrudescence of the old feud between these particular Indians and Mr. Garland.

While I feel it is a good thing to have a representative of law and order in the person of a Magistrate in the vicinity of Church House, which is the most remote settlement in Vancouver Agency, and Mr. Garland's removal may not be the best thing, yet the charges made against him alike it imperative, in the interests of the Department as well as the Indians, that the fullest possible investigation be held and I intend going carefully and without fear or favor into the matter of these complaints.

Your obedient servant,

MR. PERRY: Now, sir, I wish to call your attention to the fact that this petition contains names which were on the original accusation against Mr. Garland, and that is also why no haste was made in rushing up to Church House to deal with the matter. Neither of these is witnessed properly.

I can say emphatically, Mr. Commissioner, that since the day Mr. Garland applied for the position I have exercised every reasonable thought and action to make Mr. Garland's work successful and to make living conditions as happy as possible for him and his family. I am quite sure that the Inspector of Indian Schools can testify that in comparison with other Indian Day schools the Department's treatment of Mr. Garland's Indian Day School has been magnanimous in every way. To show my estimation and my kindness of heart towards Mr. and Mrs. Garland I met Mrs. Garland at the C. P. R. train with my car and drove her and the children around Stanley Park and showed the children the Zoo, and then drove them around the City. I went down to see them off on their departure for Church House and wished them godspeed. I did it to show goodwill, and respect for a lady. I want there to be no reflection on my general conduct toward the lady.

Since Mr. Garland went to Church House we have recommended to the Department the furnishing of his home. We have supplied for the use of the Field Matron

The expenses for drugs as Mr. Ditchburn will know has been quite considerable and generous in comparison to what other schools have received.

We have put in for the benefit of the Indians at Church House a water supply system. We have repaired the bridges and roads. We put an addition on Mr. Garland's home with bath room equipment.

I am not saying these things because we have done anything wonderful but to show that Mr. Garland will have no suggestion of bias or prejudice or official ill-will. Considerably more has been done for the Hemaleo School and more elasticity given that the usages of the Department have allowed for many other schools.

He has asked for a new building to accommodate the teacher and his family at Church House. This fact has been quoted by Mr. Garland as indicative of bias and prejudice. When that application came in I discussed all phases of it with Mr. Inspector Cairns. We decided that the building up there by expending $500. would be comfortable for a few years to
MR. PERRY: years to come

Mr. Garland asked for tools to be sent up for cutting the thread pipe to take care of a little job there. These tools were purchased from Messrs. McLennan & Macsely Ltd., and sent up but unfortunately Mr. Garland is not expert in the use of tools. I doubt if you could classify him as a handy man as far as doing odd jobs is concerned.

When the request came for certain plumbing work to be done you, Mr. Commissioner, will know that the Department was asked by me through yourself to have the engineers of the Water Power Branch prepare a report, to go fully into the water supply for the convenience of the residents at Church House. Owing to the amount of business on the shoulders of the Water Power engineers in the Interior and elsewhere they were not able to give immediate attention to the Church House requirements. After many months the report was sent me from Mr. Ditchburn, he having received it from the engineers. It was sent to me with instructions to obtain from the Church House Indians in a meeting a resolution authorizing the expenditure based on this report, of Band funds. This all was done and in due course the water system as recommended by the engineers was completed. I trust to the satisfaction of Mr. Garland. While these negotiations were pending Mr. Garland asked me to send a plumber up from Vancouver to repair a pipe which appeared to be in a leaky condition causing dripping which seemed to annoy Mr. Garland and family very much. I sent Mr. Garland's recommendation to Ottawa. Mr. Bartlett helped me prepare an estimate of the cost of sending a man up, and we figured his time and expenses would be not less than $50.00,

and in order to cover this contingency I recommended that the Department send a man up to do this work unless it was the intention of the Department to have the whole thing covered at an early date by the engineers of the Water Power Branch. The Department replied that they would wait for the resolution of the Church House Indians.

This is the reason, sir, that Mr. Garland's request for immediate attention to his water pipe was not concurred in to his satisfaction.

With regard to Mr. Garland's complaint about the leaky roof I forwarded Mr. Garland's report to Mr. Ditchburn. I also placed in my estimates in September last numerous items covering the Church House services including repairs to the School building, etc., and sent a copy of my recommendation to Mr. Garland for his information. Now since those estimates have been sent in no word has been received from the Department as to whether these estimates are allowed or not and I presume that is because the estimates have to be presented during the present session of Parliament.

Also during the course of negotiations of services at Church House with Mr. Garland I received instructions from the Commissioner that no expenses were to be incurred of any nature whatever without Departmental authority as the appropriations made last year were running very low and the strictest economy had to be exercised.

It was a letter bearing on that subject as written by me to which exception was taken yesterday by Mr. Garland in his evidence by which he endeavored to show that the letter contained some evidence of bias and prejudice.
MR. PERRY: In Mr. Garland's evidence yesterday he mentioned the fact that for some time I had provided him with postage stamps in connection with his official correspondence with this office, and that is quite true. I did send to Mr. Garland from my own stamp supply occasionally One Dollar worth of so of stamps because I felt that he was taking an interest in the welfare of the Indians and wrote a good many letters in behalf of the Indians and the local services. One day, however, I received a request from Mr. Garland for the sum of $6.00 to cover the cost of postage incurred by him in writing letters to me. I replied asking Mr. Garland to send me a receipt because I knew that the Department would not pass the Voucher without it. Mr. Garland was not able to furnish me with the receipt, and I have never received it.

MR. GARLAND: I had spent $6.00 during my period of service up to the time I had written the letter. I had bought these stamps from time to time and had not obtained a receipt, and let the matter drop.

MR. PERRY: I wrote Mr. Garland suggesting that he put an item for postage stamps to the Indian Agent in his next requisition for supplies. Mr. Garland did not do so, however, and when his requisition came in I incorporated this item for $6.00 together with other items. The requisition was dealt with by the Department and I was informed by the Department that the Department did not provide postage stamps for teachers. I felt, sir, that I could not draw on my local postage stamp supply any further than I had done without receiving the disapprobation of the Department.

Now, Mr. Commissioner, if there is any point I have failed to cover, I wish, if you have any note of it, that you would let me know.

In regard to the matter of relief I think that matter has been made to your satisfaction - the Gerrard case.

In conclusion, sir, I wish to say that I have nothing but the greatest respect for Mr. and Mrs. Garland. I do not claim that they are in my opinion the best qualified people for handling the Indian situation but I will say I believe they have been conscientious in their work and straight and above board in their correspondence and associations in general. The reason for this observation is this, that it will be apparent from the nature of the correspondence now put in as exhibits that Mr. Garland is inclined to be too severe in his analysis of activities - either Indian or official.

If Mr. Garland would spend the same amount of energy in seeking the things that are attainable and accomplishing the things that can be accomplished that he expends in voluminous correspondence which makes a great deal out of trifling things, I believe he would have better results, and a kinder feeling would exist both between him and the officials and the Indians.

Mr. Garland states that he thinks I am impulsive, and in this I might say that I have found often my impulsive disposition to lead to good results where hesitation might have utterly failed me.

Just one
MR. PERRY: Just one observation in conclusion. I leave it to you, Mr. Commissioner, to judge whether or not it is becoming for any man holding a position for only something short of 16 months to so seriously reflect upon the administration of an Agency handled by a man who has twenty years of active work as a responsible Agent of the Government amongst the Indians. I do not claim that I am perfect, I have my faults like other men, but it hurts very much when the man of Mr. Garland's intelligence and status uses such language as he used in his letter to me in referring to my work in which I am quite as deeply interested, and have always been, as he himself contends that he is. I say that you, sir, and the Department will judge as to my efficiency, and I repeat now most seriously the representations that I made to you, sir, in writing that in view of the nature of this investigation, someone must be relieved of his position in the interests of the service. We cannot allow this contentious spirit to continue in this Agency. The issues are too important and the work of too serious a nature for us to allow conditions like this to go on unchecked in a very decisive manner.

That is all, sir.

MR. DITCHBURN: I think that both of you have had a very fair opportunity to express your views with regard to this investigation. I have all the evidence in connection with it, and my report will be submitted to my superior officers.

But I will tell you candidly I cannot concur in your remark that Mr. Perry as Indian Agent has acted in a manner of bias and prejudice toward you, nor did he say an untruth in his letter of December 22nd, of which you complain.

You have drawn a very fine line with regard to the statement made by Mr. Perry that you had taken up the matter of perjury with the Attorney General. In your letter to Mr. Perry you state you are taking it up and Mr. Perry in his letter of the 22nd December states that you have brought the matter to the attention of the Attorney General.

It was quite a slight misstatement on the part of Mr. Perry and I take it it was done intentionally, but the natural assumption that after a person had written he was taking up the matter on the 11th of December the other party receiving the letter 11 days later would be perfectly within his rights in concluding that the matter had been taken up. Therefore, I do not think you can accuse Mr. Perry of lying in this particular instance.

I feel satisfied after Mr. Perry's explanation to you that he has not been prejudiced or biased in any way.

All these Departmental matters are dealt with by officials in a confidential manner before they can become public property.

Regarding charges made against Mr. Garland Mr. Perry said that he and Mr. Cairns had discussed that matter previously and what to my mind was a perfectly proper thing for two officials to do. Mr. Perry is the senior officer in this Agency, Mr. Cairns is Inspector of Schools for the Province of British Columbia. These were statements made to Agent Perry and Inspector Cairns alleging improper conduct on your part; Mr. Perry and Mr. Cairns discussed this matter between themselves to determine, as explained.
as explained by Mr. Perry as to whether or not the allegations were worth probing in which knowing the situation at Church House as I know it myself, I take it that had these statements come from a more responsible character than Chief George Harry, the matter would have been sifted to the ground right away. However, I do not think, Mr. Garland, that you have any real complaint against Mr. Perry in any of your allegations against him. I think I agree with you in the remarks you made early in the day which were to the effect that had the matter been given more mature consideration, it is possible that your letter would never have been written.

In my report to the Department, I feel that the letter was entirely unjustified, but should the Department say that I have made an error in my judgment I am quite willing to abide by the ruling.

I am sorry this matter has come up because between officials of the Department we expect co-operation. We are not always right in everything we do but there must be a spirit of fairness, even if sometimes a person does willfully wrong all the time we must give them credit for trying to do the best they can under all circumstances. I do not think, Mr. Garland, that this Department could have dealt more kindly with you in any shape or form.

I may say candidly you have been criticized by myself in your items for drug supplies. The orders you placed are not exceeded by any that are put in by any doctor in the Province. Your position as teacher does not warrant you the disposition of medicines, nevertheless I realize that you have some knowledge of medicines.

We have spent a very great amount of money in Medical supplies for the Homalco Indians, supplies that are not often given to Field Matrons but only to doctors. Field Matrons can only be supplied with simple remedies for the alleviation of distress on the part of the Indians for the time being until they can be attended by the Doctor of the District. I must now say we have dealt with you very liberally.

Mr. Perry has never taken it upon himself to criticize your requisitions in any way, shape or form. He has passed them along without any comment whatever and which is proof that he was not biased or prejudiced against you.

MR. DITCHBURN: The complaints made against Mr. Perry are not well founded, and that settles that phase of the question.

We will, therefore, now follow up by dealing with any complaints Mr. Garland may have against Constable Bartlett, as that seems to be the underlying source of the grievance.

The only thing that I have on my file in this regard is a letter from Mr. Garland dated 14th January, 1928:

"SIR:

I am regretfully forced to address this letter to you on account of the Machiavellian activities and deviltries exercised by Dominion Constable T.T. Bartlett, against me, and my family; disseminating lying reports and calumnies in his parading up and down the Coast in these waters, so that my existence has been made a perfect hell through the intrigues of this officer.

The latest infamous and scurrilous report, emanating from the lips of this man, is to the effect that I and my wife are not married - that my WIFE is really my DAUGHTER - that our children are grand-children, and that I and my wife are living in a condition and state of "incest".

May I ask you, Sir, to name a day upon which I can meet you in Vancouver, and there thresh this man's conduct out?

I earnestly beg of you to give the matter your most earnest and serious consideration, as I cannot put up with this man's infamous conduct any longer."

Now in connection with this particular complaint against Mr. Bartlett I have learned that he has written an apology to Mr. Garland, dated 20th January 1928.

(Copy of this letter not left by Mr. Garland)

Now Mr. Garland you have intimated in your remarks the other day that you had other complaints against Mr. Bartlett.

MR. GARLAND: I have already at the commencement of the investigation that has been conducted the past two days mentioned some of the idiosyncrasies of Mr. Bartlett. As you have taken up the case which was commenced this morning, sir, of the scurrilous report made by Mr. Bartlett in connection with my wife and I not being married, I would like to tell you just what happened at the time this statement was made.

The afternoon of the 8th December, Thursday, 1927, Mr. Bartlett came to my quarters and wanted to know something about why the Indians should not be granted moieties. I told him as much as I was able to tell him at the time. He was not present at the time of the trial. I just told him the facts in short. I then told him that I desired to go to Powell River very urgently and I expected to meet Mr. Perry in Powell River and asked him as he was leaving the following day...
MR. GARLAND:

day, if he would take me to Powell River on his boat.

He acquiesced, and went away. On the morning of Friday, the 9th of December, I went to his boat, which was lying against the wharf at the Reserve, at about 9, bidding him good morning when I got to his boat and asking him what time he intended pulling out so that I could have my grip on board. His back was turned to me at the time. He turned round in savagery and a temper. Said that he would not take me. I said: "What is the matter, Bartlett?" and he turned around to me and said "What did you go and tell Mr. Perry that I had given a sweater to Constable Boyt fort?" I said "Because it was my duty to do so." These sweaters had been given the Department I understood from Mr. Perry from some charitable for distribution amongst the Indians. I was already in possession of one of these sweaters. Chief Harry had been given two. He took one of them off me. I did not know at that time the source from which they were obtained other than that they came from Mr. Bartlett. He asked me one dollar for one of them. I gave him a dollar. I turned around to Mr. Bartlett and said "Bartlett, I have had enough of this. Every time you come here you are trying to create a quarrel. I will go in to Vancouver and maybe on to Victoria, but I have had enough of your surliness for many months now, and we will have a showdown." He then started about things in connection with Mr. and Mrs. Nicholson. He admitted, as Mr. and Mrs. Nicholson had told me, that he had been in the habit of going to their quarters and asking for what they termed a square. I suggest that it was a mean act that he had not had a square since he had left Vancouver and that it was time he got his square, and he said "I suppose they did not tell you that I recompense them for it, they did not tell you I had taken armfuls of stuff up for them from the beat", and said "I suppose they, Mr. Nicholson, did not tell that I had nursed him cur of D. T. 's." I said "No, they did not." "Well, I have." He asked me if Nicholson had a drink at that time. I said I believed he had. He said "Nicholson is an irresponsible chap, irresponsible. You cannot believe anything he says when he has had a drink of liquor." I said: "Bartlett that does not affect me. The only thing that affects me is your surliness and the underhand things you say to me when you come on this Reserve." He said "I do not want a showdown, Mr. Garland, I want to be friends. Do not go to Nicholson because I have made friends with him. You must forgive me for being cranky this morning. I had a rough night, been blowing hard, and my boat beating up against the wall, and I have had scarcely any sleep. So let us drop the matter and I will take you down to Powell River. I will let you know what time I am pulling out. I will send somebody up."

As I was coming away something must have seized him for he turned around again in a temper and said that he had been told that I was not married, that my wife ..........

I turned on him then rather savagely. First of all before he made this statement he said "I will tell you something that you do not know. Promise me that you will not tell your wife."

I said "Bartlett, do you know the seriousness of what you are saying. You will tell me who told you this, Bartlett." He then said he had been told it by an Indian from Sechelt.

I said
MR. GARLAND: I said to him "Bartlett, that is no Indian yarn. An Indian does not know the meaning of incest. No Indian could have told you this yarn. This is an emanation from your own mind done to give me pain." And I came away in somewhat of an anger. He turned again and said that he would not take me down on his boat. Told me that if I wanted to go to Powell River I could hire a boat.

I went straight up to my quarters and told my wife just what had occurred and the statement Mr. Bartlett had made concerning her. I said to my wife "I am going on that boat to Powell River more now than ever before. I will insist on Mr. Bartlett taking me to Powell River. I have as much right to go down on that boat as three workmen from another Department. There is ample room to take me, and why Bartlett should act in this manner I do not know."

I went back again to the boat. Mr. Bartlett was still on board and I said to him "Bartlett you are going to take me down on this boat. I am here now on your boat, and I am prepared to stay here until you pull out." He showed me that he was in charge of the boat and he could please himself who he took. I said "I do not care, Bartlett, I am here on this boat and you will take me to Powell River. I will not budge from the boat." After a few minutes he said alright he would take me.

Going down on the boat he was very kind, offered me something to eat on board, was particularly anxious to know whether I was going to stay at the hotel or some friends. If I was going to the hotel I could expect him shortly after and that he would come up to my room. I went up to the hotel with the full expectation of meeting Mr. Perry there in response to a wire which I had sent him an hour ago to Mr. Ewart for transmission to Mr. Perry, but I found Mr. Perry was not there. I went to police quarters then to see if a telegram had been sent by Mr. Perry to me care of the Provincial police as requested in the telegram. It was sent on the night of the 2nd of December. There was no telegram for me. Before leaving the boat that night Mr. Bartlett asked me again what I proposed doing. I said "I do not know, Mr. Bartlett, but it is quite possible that after I have done what business I have to do here in Powell River, I will go on to Vancouver and to Victoria if necessity warrants."

On Monday the 27th September, 1927 Mr. Bartlett was lying at the Government Wharf and I believe around about midnight an Indian boat pulled in with two girls on it, one named Jessie Louise aged 17, married, and the other Catherine Louise aged about 14, single, and on board was Arthur Prendergast when the two girls got off the boat, walked up the float to the reservation and store, that Mr. Bartlett told the girls afterwards that they were not to go away, leave the reservation, in a boat because he wanted them to come up to the school house. In the morning knowing that Mr. Bartlett was in I was going down to the wharf to see him when I met him coming from the wharf with two Indian girls in front. He then told me what had occurred the night before and that he was bringing these two girls up to the school house for the purpose of my taking an affidavit from these girls as to what they had been doing on board the boat with Arthur Prendergast. The girls demurred.
MR. GARLAND: demurred about coming up and one, Jessie Louie, said that she would not come. Bartlett got hold of her by the scruff of the neck and threw her to her knees at the same time giving her a kick from behind. I remonstrated with him for his conduct towards a woman, even though she was an Indian and got the reply: "It is all right for these." Jessie Louie will corroborate that statement today or any time you send a responsible official up there.

The affidavit was taken, the Indian girls came up. And I considered that there was something in the affidavit made by these girls by which a charge could have been laid against Prendergast, observing that one of the girls was 14 or 15 years of age. I understand from Mr. Perry that the affidavit was sent to him or taken to him by Mr. Bartlett and that Mr. Bartlett reported that he and I had discussed that affidavit and had come to the conclusion that there was nothing in it to warrant any further action.
