During the month of June when Mr. McConnell came to repair the church he had nowhere to stay. Mrs. Thompson refused to put him up at the store, he had no accommodation, or equipment to put up a building, and I obtained from Mrs. Pallen, an Indian woman, permission for Mr. McConnell to stay in her house. She agreed to do, and a few days afterwards she sent a child to me asking me if I would go down and see the house as she cleaned it up and if in my opinion it would be agreeable for Mr. McConnell to stay and sleep there. In my doing so I walked into the kitchen and there were two sacks of flour inside of a brown sack, 2 - 49 lb., marked M. Gerrard, Storekeeper, Stuart Island, then in brackets Indian Department. I could not understand how Mrs. Pallen got hold of this flour, as she was not on the indigent list, and I enquired from her where she obtained the flour. She said she had bought it from Arthur Prendergast. I then wondered how could Prendergast get hold of this flour as the outside sack was marked Gerrard. I enquired from Mr. Gerrard if he had sold any flour to Mrs. Thompson or Arthur Prendergast, and he said "No." I then came to the conclusion that there was a leakage somewhere and some flour being supplied to our Indians was finding its way for purposes other than it was intended for.
Mr. Bartlett came in on the night of the 23rd. of June about a leak on our door, and I mentioned the matter to him as important, and told him that there was a good chance for him to exercise his detective abilities. I wanted to clear the matter up to see what Indian drawing relief was giving away supplies. He told me he had too much to do, and what was the good anyhow. I later heard through the intermediary of old Sam Timothy that Sophie Wilson was the culprit and was in the habit of exchanging and bartering her flour to others.

There were very few Indians in Church House at that time only about three families. Mr. Bartlett went away the next morning without taking any steps, and I have never heard of any steps being taken and the matter attended to.

On Sunday the 13th. February, 1927, at about 3 p.m., Mr. Bartlett reached Church House. Isaac Francis had just arrived from Old Church House and reported that a white man named Secord was on the Old Church House Reserve when no one was in the village and that he had lost some boom chains and had every reason to believe that Secord had the chains in his boat. The affair was red hot, Mr. Bartlett was there on the spot, the Indians had just come in town. I reported the same to Mr. Bartlett and asked him to go at once and take some steps to investigate. He refused to go. Said that he had had enough of chains in the past. He left Church House at around about 6 o'clock and went to Shiammen without taking any steps.

What seems to me to be the base of the recent troubles in Church House. Mr. Bartlett left Church House at 4 p.m. on the 1st. December, 1927, and I asked Mr. Rosenberg where Mr. Bartlett had gone. Mr. Rosenberg told me he had gone to Malaspina. Some of the Indians told me that Mr. Bartlett had gone to Malaspina. Chief Harry came up to me that evening and asked me the following question "Is it true that Mr. Bartlett has kicked you out as Magistrate?" I asked him why he should ask me such a question. He said "Jack Bartlett told me" that I was no longer a Magistrate. The tale ran all around the village that I was no longer a Magistrate. The Indians took it for granted that they were free lances. Strange to say that Mr. Rosenberg came to me within a day or two after and told me that the Chief had asked him if it was true that I was no longer a Magistrate. On the third of December we had all this drunken riot.

MR. GARLAND: Saturday night I had all the trouble. I spoke to Mr. Bartlett about this and told Mr. Bartlett what the Chief had said when he returned after the trial, and Mr. Bartlett denied that he had told the Chief this but he told me, Mr. Bartlett told me that the Chief had been down to his boat and told him this, that I had lost my magistracy, thereby turning the little tale upside down; that instead of Mr. Bartlett telling the Chief, the Chief told Mr. Bartlett.

And there is no doubt in my mind that the spreading of this rumour amongst the Indians, whether Mr. Bartlett is responsible for it or the Chief is responsible for it, was the cause of all the trouble and drunken riot which we had on the Reserve, on the 4th December.

Some time in November Chief Harry reported to me that Dave Paul's house was broken into and said that he had got two witnesses, viz., Mrs. Pallen and Mrs. Jasper Joseph; that Mrs. Hackett and Mrs. Bassett were the two culprits. Mr. Bartlett arrived with Mr. Rosenberg at about 4 p.m. Tuesday the 8th of November, the day after Thanksgiving Day, and in the evening he came to our quarters and I told him about this matter in our quarters and asked him to make an investigation. "It served them right" the Constable said. I have never heard that Mr. Bartlett took any steps in the matter, nor did he.

I am a Magistrate and the Indians report these things to me and expect me to do what I can and I do what I can. I can not always be sending for the Provincial Police to do this work, as they frequently grumble at having to do work which they consider should be done by the Dominion Constable.

The trading of clothes and old boots for baskets with Indians seems to me a most pernicious thing. Sir:

I beg to refer to Departmental letter No. 167-33-1, dated January 25th last, in which instructions were sent to me to proceed to Church House Reserve No. 6, of the Homalco Band and investigate certain charges of alleged misconduct on the part of Mr. A. H. Garland, Indian School teacher, towards certain Indian women as complained of by certain Homalco Indians to the Department.

I desire to report that, after issuing forms of summons to all parties concerned, and upon request made by me to the Indian Commissioner that Mr. R. H. Cairns, Inspector of Indian Schools for British Columbia, should be invited to accompany me and assist in the investigation of the complaints, the Inspector and I visited Church House by steamer on March 3rd, and made arrangements for the inquiry to commence at 10 a.m. Monday, March 5th. On the latter date we opened the inquiry with all parties concerned present at the Indian Day School building.

William Mitchell, Indian Constable of Squirrel Cove acted as a special and independent interpreter, and he and all witnesses were placed on oath.

During three days of very careful examination, twenty-one witnesses were heard, pro and con. We made a thorough effort to get at the very bottom of the complaints, and are of the opinion that a plot had been most

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, ONT.
March 13, 1928.

cunningly laid and executed by about ten Indians, mostly relatives and tribal associates of Chief George Harry, headed by him, these Indians, both male and female, being mostly of undoubted questionable character. This was supported by a volume of sworn evidence, of insufficient depth however to justify either the plot itself or even the suggestion of actual immoral conduct on the part of Mr. Garland.

Three women accused Mr. Garland of immoral relations with them, and a fourth, in addition to one of the three mentioned claimed that Mr. Garland had given them intoxicants as an inducement to the misconduct. The husband of one of the three first named supported the testimony of his wife.

Mr. Garland submitted the witnesses to a most gruelling cross-examination in his defence against the charges, as a result of which we were impressed with the belief that the charges were false and the characters making them were perjuring themselves.

In summing up the evidence taken at the inquiry it is believed that the motive of the Indians who made the charges were:

1. Jealousy of Chief Harry against Alex Paul, Chief chosen by the Priest to represent the Roman Catholic Church.

2. The activity of Mr. Garland as Indian Day School teacher in having Chief Harry's son Jimmy compelled to attend school.

3. The search of Chief Harry's house for intoxicants under warrant issued by Mr. Garland acting as Stipendiary Magistrate.

4. The conviction in Court by Mr. Garland of relatives of Chief Harry following a drunken brawl in the reserve on December 3rd last.

The woman
March 13, 1928.

5. The women used by Chief Harry to further the charges against Mr. Garland were of bad character and Chief Harry believed he could get them to swear falsely on grounds of immorality.

6. Those who witnessed the documents setting forth the charges were also relatives and friends of Chief Harry and these were of apparent necessity to the combination.

While we are decidedly of the belief that Mr. Garland is not guilty of the offences alleged against him, we feel however that the following portions of Mr. Garland's evidence should be commented upon: viz-

1. When charged by Indian woman Sophie Wilson with having kissed her at Sliammon Reserve in the presence of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholson, teacher and matron, respectively, Mr. Garland said:

"I deny the Sliammon incident emphatically."

In this matter a letter (Exhibit No.1.) is sent herewith signed by Mr. and Mrs. Nicholson which confirms the evidence of the Indian woman Sophie Wilson.

2. In his evidence of defence Mr. Garland further stated:

"I have never had a liquor permit, nor liquor in these quarters."

In this matter a letter (Exhibit No.2.) is sent herewith signed by Mr. Garland soon after he took over the position of teacher asking Constable Bartlett to send him a bottle of rum and a bottle of brandy. The Constable refused to do as Mr. Garland asked. Later Mr. Garland entered a bottle of brandy in an official requisition for drug supplies, and this item was deleted at the Vancouver office.

It should be stated that on our arrival at Church House we found the Indians of the reserve in a high state of excitement, two rival factions appearing as a mine ready to explode.
March 13, 1928.

to explode on the slightest provocation, one of these factions being in sympathy with Mr. Garland and the other strongly against him.

During the course of the inquiry we observed that both Mr. and Mrs. Garland displayed a conspicuous lack of self control and their hostile attitude and vociferous language coupled with the observable movements of the eldest daughter (age 14) of Mr. and Mrs. Garland who was very active in the matter of her father's defence, gave rise to the belief that these people are not suitable persons to maintain the peace and goodwill desired in this village, and we feel that if they are allowed to remain there there will be further trouble between them and the Indians; as it is clear that Mr. and Mrs. Garland's tendency is to foment trouble through partisanship and favoritism.

We are able to state without hesitation that improvement is seen in the discipline and school work in the classroom at Homalco Indian Day School under Mr. Garland, but the work of the Field Matron is undoubtedly hampered through the admitted dispositions of Mr. and Mrs. Garland not to leave their school quarters after sunset because of their fear of the Indians, although generally her work is otherwise seemingly satisfactory.

Mention should be made also of a statement made by Mrs. Garland to the Commissioner at Vancouver that she was obliged to give her young daughter (age 14) a stick to carry in order that she may ward off, if necessary, bands of Indian lads bent on mischief towards her.

We feel that these three young children should no longer remain amongst the Indians at Church House it being brought to my attention also that they foment considerable trouble amongst the Indian children.

When Mr. Garland was appointed it was pointed out to the Department that it had been our policy up to that time not to have a teacher and matron with a young family at this village, and the acceptance of the Garlands to fill these vacancies and our allowing them to go with their three children

to this village, was a digression from this policy owing to the difficulty of obtaining incumbents without children.

We are satisfied that a decided spirit of hostility and unrest exists at Church House partly between two factions and partly between one of these factions and Mr. Garland. This being the case, and also as we are of opinion that Mr. and Mrs. Garland are not sufficiently well balanced either in their experience with Indians or in their disposition towards things and persons in general, we recommend that the Department request Reverend Father Bellot, district priest at Squamish Mission Reserve, North Vancouver, B.C., to ask the responsible Church Authorities to call for the early resignation of Mr. and Mrs. Garland and to recommend suitable persons to fill the positions of teacher and matron thus to be vacated at the Indian Village of Homalco Band at Church House, B.C.

During three days of very careful examination, twenty-one witnesses were heard, pro and con. We made a thorough effort to get at the very bottom of the complaints, and are of the opinion that a plot had been most cunningly...

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
March 16, 1928.

Gunningly laid and executed by about ten Indians, mostly relatives and tribal associates of Chief George Harry, headed by him, these Indians, both male and female, being mostly of undoubted questionable character. This was supported by a volume of sworn evidence, of insufficient depth however to justify either the plot itself or even the suggestion of actual immoral conduct on the part of Mr. Garland.

Three women accused Mr. Garland of immoral relations with them, and a fourth, in addition to one of the three mentioned claimed that Mr. Garland had given them intoxicants as an inducement to the misconduct. The husband of one of the three first named supported the testimony of his wife.

Mr. Garland submitted the witnesses to a most gruelling cross-examination in his defense against the charges, as a result of which we were impressed with the belief that the charges were false and the characters making them were perjuring themselves.

In summing up the evidence taken at the inquiry it is believed that the motive of the Indians who made the charges were:

1. Jealousy of Chief Harry against Alex Paul, Chief chosen by the Priest to represent the Roman Catholic Church.

2. The activity of Mr. Garland as Indian Day School teacher in having Chief Harry's son Jimmy compelled to attend school.

3. The search of Chief Harry's house for intoxicants under warrant issued by Mr. Garland acting as Stipendiary Magistrate.

4. The conviction in Court by Mr. Garland of relatives of Chief Harry following a drunken brawl in the reserve on December 3rd last.

The women
March 13, 1928.

5. The women used by Chief Harry to further the charges against Mr. Garland were of bad character and Chief Harry believed he could get them to swear falsely on grounds of immorality.

6. Those who witnessed the documents setting forth the charges were also relatives and friends of Chief Harry and these were of apparent necessity to the combination.

While we are decidedly of the belief that Mr. Garland is not guilty of the offences alleged against him, we feel however that the following portions of Mr. Garland's evidence should be commented upon: viz-

1. When charged by Indian woman Sophie Wilson with having kissed her at Sliammon Reserve in the presence of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholson, teacher and matron, respectively, Mr. Garland said:

"I deny the Sliammon incident emphatically."

In this matter a letter (Exhibit No.1.) is sent herewith signed by Mr. and Mrs. Nicholson which confirms the evidence of the Indian woman Sophie Wilson.

2. In his evidence of defence Mr. Garland further stated:

"I have never had a liquor permit, nor liquor in these quarters."

In this matter a letter (Exhibit No.2.) is sent herewith signed by Mr. Garland soon after he took over the position of teacher asking Constable Bartlett to send him a bottle of rum and a bottle of brandy. The Constable refused to do as Mr. Garland asked. Later Mr. Garland entered a bottle of brandy in an official requisition for drug supplies, and this item was deleted at the Vancouver office.

It should be stated that on our arrival at Church House we found the Indians of the reserve in a high state of excitement, two rival factions appearing as a mine ready to explode.
March 18, 1926.

to explode on the slightest provocation, one of these factions being in sympathy with Mr. Garland and the other strongly against him.

During the course of the inquiry we observed that both Mr. and Mrs. Garland displayed a conspicuous lack of self control and their hostile attitude and vociferous language coupled with the observable movements of the eldest daughter (age 14) of Mr. and Mrs. Garland who was very active in the matter of her father's defence, gave rise to the belief that these people are not suitable persons to maintain the peace and goodwill desired in this village, and we feel that if they are allowed to remain there there will be further trouble between them and the Indians; as it is clear that Mr. and Mrs. Garland's tendency is to foment trouble through partisanship and favoritism.

We are able to state without hesitation that improvement is seen in the discipline and school work in the classroom at Homalco Indian Day School under Mr. Garland, but the work of the Field Matron is undoubtedly hampered through the admitted dispositions of Mr. and Mrs. Garland not to leave their school quarters after sunset because of their fear of the Indians, although generally her work is otherwise seemingly satisfactory.

Mention should be made also of a statement made by Mrs. Garland to the Commissioner at Vancouver that she was obliged to give her young daughter (age 14) a stick to carry in order that she may ward off, if necessary, bands of Indian lads bent on mischief towards her.

We feel that these three young children should no longer remain amongst the Indians at Church House it being brought to my attention also that they foment considerable trouble amongst the Indian children.

When Mr. Garland was appointed it was pointed out to the Department that it had been our policy up to that time not to have a teacher and matron with a young family at this village, and the acceptance of the Garlands to fill these vacancies and our allowing them to go with their three children

to this
March 13, 1928.

to this village, was a digression from this policy owing to the difficulty of obtaining incumbents without children.

We are satisfied that a decided spirit of hostility and unrest exists at Church House partly between two factions and partly between one of these factions and Mr. Garland. This being the case, and also as we are of opinion that Mr. and Mrs. Garland are not sufficiently well balanced either in their experience with Indians or in their disposition towards things and persons in general, we recommend that the Department request Reverend Father Bellot, district priest at Squamish Mission Reserve, North Vancouver, B.C., to ask the responsible Church Authorities to call for the early resignation of Mr. and Mrs. Garland and to recommend suitable persons to fill the positions of teacher and matron thus to be vacated at the Indian Village of Homalco Band at Church House, B.C.

There are three children in this family. It has been our policy for some time not to engage officers for these positions who might find it necessary to take children to this village, but our experiences, as well as those of others, have been such as to suggest a departure from this practice, particularly as we now consider that a family man with more responsibilities and considerations might be a more stabilizing influence amongst the Indians and moreover an excellent educational status of the Durands will lead us to believe these people better able to take care of the education of their children than in many other cases. Sir,

The Department will be aware that the offices of Indian Day School Teacher and Field Patron, respectively, at Church House - the Hope No.6 reserve of the Nokolos band of Indians have been vacant for the past couple of months owing to the resignation of Mr. and Mrs. Alex Burke.

The Rev. Father Welch, Vicar of Roman Catholic Missions, has sent three applicants for these positions, two of whom after ascertaining the various phases of information surrounding the appointment and local conditions have not made a formal application.

The third applicant, Mr. A. Hedley Garland, formerly Superintendent of Education of the Provincial Government of Manitoba came upon making application to see Mr. Mitchell and his wife for the vacant positions, advised to visit Church House, look over the premises, and make a personal observation of the life of the Indians, as it was felt that he appeared to be a man of very superior tastes, and that he may not be satisfied to take up residence at Church House under the same conditions as previous incumbents have done. Mr. Garland went to Church House, and upon his return he wrote a letter of application, a copy of which is sent herewith, for the Department's perusal and consideration.

After interviewing Mr. Garland, with Mr. Ann Cairns, Inspector of Indian Schools for British Columbia, we have decided to forward the letter of Mr. Garland with our recommendation that if possible, this application be given favourable consideration. For some time we have felt that more could be done by our officers at Church House, but on account of the lack of experience of applicants and the more or less crude standards of living of the Indians we have not experienced more than a casual improvement notwithstanding the appointees of the Department have done their best to give satisfaction in their work.

On the other hand, in view of the present application I feel it my duty to point out to the Department that notwithstanding the efforts which have been made by previous employees filling the positions mentioned in a formal way, there have been some personal troubles of discipline attached to previous employees which have given this office some embarrassment such as having tended to affect the morale of the officers in question. One of them was the case of Miss Davis Boyle, who became ill through a nervous condition named Albert Wilson, the circumstances which culminated in the resignation of Miss Boyle, as teacher, and her mother, as patron, notwithstanding the services of Mrs. Boyle and her daughter so far as their specific work was concerned.

The other case is that of Mr. and Mrs. Alex. Burke, who have just resigned from these appointments. While Mr. Burke's services as Teacher were regarded by Mr. Inspector Cairns and myself as being most satisfactory, and the services of Mrs. Burke, as Matron, equally so, nevertheless the Nomad Indians at a public meeting informed me recently that there had been evidences of domestic infidelity at the home of teacher and matron; and the premises were left in an unsatisfactory condition from a sanitary point of view. Moreover, guests were instructed by these offenders which have not been discharged. On my recent visit to Church House I found the premises in a worse condition than I had expected to see them, although there is a possibility that the Indians themselves may be to some extent responsible for the condition of the rooms, as it has often been to be an inevitable practice of the Indians upon the vacation of these premises by our employees to break into the premises and to steal drugs and school materials and to generally ransack the premises. On each occasion I have sent the Dominion Constable to Church House to investigate but he has been unable to obtain any clues that would bring the offenders to justice.

In view of the foregoing it is anticipated and expected that in the event of Mr. and Mrs. Garland being appointed to fill these positions, a more satisfactory service and regime will be inaugurated and a better tone and morale will be established in the Reserve.

The Department will probably consider the requisition of Mr. Garland for furniture rather large, but if it is the intention of the Department to furnish the quarters for the use of these incumbents, it is thought that in view of the fact that the furnishings at present in the building herein described constitute, the place will have to be made more attractive by the installation of better furnishings if we are to induce people of the desired calibre to accept the vacant positions. Mr. Garland states that he considers the requisition he has made to be very moderate, and Mr. Cairns and I, after considering the same very carefully, are inclined to agree with him, with the exception perhaps that we are of opinion that one or two couches instead of two may be sufficient. Mr. Garland, however, wishes to leave the final decision in this matter best left with the Department.

The monthly payment of a teacher's salary is a departure from the practice of the Department, but if this could be arranged we would recommend it. We would also recommend the appointment of Mr. and Mrs. Garland, and would be glad if the Department would send a wire advising us of its decision at the earliest possible date.

The probable cost of the furnishings asked for, and of the cleansing and renovation of the school and maternity quarters is approximately $600.00.

I have the honour to be,

Sir:

Having, at your suggestion, visited Church House and seeing the actual conditions prevailing, I am now making formal application on behalf of my wife and myself to fill the vacancies as School Teacher and Field Matron, subject to the condition hereinafter mentioned.

It seems to me that continuity of service in such work is imperative, but I am afraid that you will experience a great difficulty in securing the continuous services of anyone unless the position is made more attractive than at present. The schoolhouse is in very bad condition indeed, requiring fumigating, cleansing, calicoining or painting, scrubbing etc., so generally put into a tolerable habitable condition. I would suggest that this be done immediately as any married couple going to Church House would find it hard to look the conditions over and turn down a fit place. The house to be occupied by the teacher and field matron should be furnished by the Department to the extent of the following articles:

- 2 beds, mattresses, pillows complete,
- 2 Toronto couches,
- 1 good (6 hole) cooking range with pipes etc. complete,
- 1 large table (extension) to 6 ft.,
- 1 small table & 4 ft.,
- 6 stout wooden chairs,
- 2 ladder covered (morris) or lounge chairs,
- 2 good lamps (1 hanging)
- 1 bureau (secretary)
- 1 -area (sitting room)
- Sufficient linoleum to cover sitting room and bedroom.

School Teacher $900.00 per annum from the Government supplemented by £100.00 per annum from J.C.Funds.

Total... $1000.00

Field Matron... $400.00

Total... $1400.00

Janitor's allowance... $50.00

Grand Total... $1450.00 per annum, with an allowance of at least one cord of wood per month and fifteen gallons of coal oil per annum. Salary to be paid monthly.

It must not be lost sight of that the position carries with it that of administration, in which the welfare of the whole community is in the hands of the combined posts, consequently should be appreciated and recognized by the Department. If the caring for and the general educating and uplifting of the Indian community at Church House is a good thing and for the ultimate benefit not only of the State and Church but of the Indians themselves, then it also to be done properly and the position made sufficiently attractive to make it worth while keeping as a life long means.
The general condition of the village is far from being good. Sanitation and hygiene has been entirely lost sight of for some time, and I would suggest immediate attention to the pits at the backs of the houses for the disposal of human excreta, refuse, etc. These have apparently been in use for years. They require filling in and new ones dug and in many instances new privy buildings. I say this with all earnestness as although sunshine and fresh air are very fine deodorizers, yet there is always the fear of an epidemic of scarlet fever, diphtheria and other contagious diseases due to neglect of this, to me, most important matter. The water service should be given some attention, and perhaps the water analysed occasionally for ammonia. The electric service and repair of bridges, etc., should also stand under consideration at the present moment. It would be my utmost endeavour to encourage the community to keep themselves and to teach them how to help themselves; but this can only be done by process of evolution. Time has gone conscientiously and thoroughly. The last months six years of hard work staring the teacher and the field worker in the face and with that, then Church House and the community can be made into a health spot instead of a plague spot and would do credit to the teacher, nation and the Government.

My wife is an educated woman with long banking and legal experience, the mother of three children, and is perfectly capable of handling any condition that may arise or that the exigencies of the post may call for.

The drugs I would suggest for the village are set out on the requisition for drugs, enclosed herewith.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

For myself, I would state that it is understood that Mr. and Mrs. Burke's appointment is on probation for a term of six months and should their services prove unsatisfactory at the end of that period, it is not likely that they would continue working there, in which event the Department would have to decide whether or not Mr. Burke should receive payment for the two holiday months. Both Mr. Cairns and I are assuming, however, that the services of Mr. and Mrs. Burke in office at Homalco will be beyond the period of their probation and with this in anticipation we feel there will be no question as to salary adjustments since it is understood that the salary is based upon ten teaching months in the year, as is the case with teachers throughout the Province.

Sir:

Sir:

Mr. William Marsden, teacher of the Komalco Indian Day School, resigned his position, taking effect December 31st.

He has accepted the position of teacher of the Indian School in the Okanagan Agency, near Vernon, B.C. He will commence work about Feb. 1st in his new position.

Miss Doris Boyle who holds a third class non-professional teacher's certificate, and who has training as a stenographer, has succeeded Mr. Marsden in the Day School at Komalco and I am sure will do her best to produce results. She is only eighteen years of age but is bright and efficient.

Miss Shore who had charge of the Kindergarten and Junior work at St. George's School at Lytton, has taken charge of the Indian Day School at Hazelton. Miss Shore has had training and will do especially good work in this new position. In her letter to me she says that so far she has had only twenty pupils. She finds the pupils very far behind, and except for reading are only in the kindergarten state. She is confident that she can get results.

Your obedient servant,

P.H. Cairns,

Sir,

Owing to the resignation of Mr. William Macdonald, teacher of the Indian Day School at Komalco, B.C., together with that of Mrs. Macdonald, who has been acting as Field-Matron at Komalco, in conjunction with the work of her husband, which resignation took effect at the end of December, ultimo, it became necessary, in order that there should be no break in the work of such officers in the Reserve to make an appointment of their successors accordingly.

In conjunction with Father Wilson, Vicar of Roman Catholic Missions, at New Westminster we have appointed, subject to the Department's approval, to fill these vacancies Mrs. L.H. Boyle as Field-Matron and Doris Boyle, (Miss) her daughter, Indian Day School teacher, the former at a salary of $40.00 per month and the latter at a salary of $700.00 per year and bonus.

Owing to the difficulties of securing competent officers to fill positions in remote settlements, such as Komalco, it was deemed advisable to recommend that the transportation of Mrs. Boyle and her daughter from Vancouver to Komalco (Church House, B.C.), approximately $16.00, receipts for which will be furnished by these officers, be paid by the Department.

Mrs. Boyle has the qualifications of a trained nurse, while Miss Boyle has two years standing in High School, which is equal to a third class British Columbia Certificate. In addition to this course, Miss Boyle stated she had also taken a course in typewriting and stenography.

We would, therefore, recommend that the Department confirm these appointments, which will be operative from the 1st of January, 1923.

I have the honour to remain,

Your obedient servants,

R.H. Cairns,
Inspector of Indian Schools of B.C.

Mr. Scott,

The school referred to in the attached letter is the one at Homalco, which was closed on the first of January, 1913, the former teacher, Mr. George Bruce, having resigned, and it has not been in operation since.

Mr. Agent Byrne was instructed to consult with the Roman Catholic Church authorities with a view to obtaining a suitable teacher and matron for this school, but up to the present no applications have been received.

There are thirty-one children of school age, but, as their parents are engaged in logging and fishing operations at various other reserves belonging to the band, the attendance was irregular.

Mr. Byrne stated that it would be a difficult matter to obtain the services of a teacher for the small salary which was paid, $600.00 per annum, and $300.00 for the teacher's wife as matron. In August, last, the Department informed Mr. Byrne that we would pay at the rate of $700.00 per annum for a qualified teacher.

Mr. Inspector Cairns, in his last report on this school, stated that it is difficult to get a teacher for this isolated place and that the Indians are chronic fault finders. A school is urgently needed there, as no children are sent away to boarding schools.

The Department has done all it can to re-open this school and the only thing to do would be to have the matter brought to the attention of the church authorities again.

Sir,

Referring to Departmental Letter dated the 6th inst., No. 318400-1, enclosing copy of a communication received from Chief George Harry of the Homalco Tribe of Indians.

I beg to state that I enquired into these charges, as made by the Chief against the teacher, some time ago, and as the result of my investigation I came to the conclusion that it was more a matter of jealousy on the part of the Indian than any other cause.

About a year ago a consignment of freight which was unloaded from a Steam Boat on a wharf, which is situated close to the Reserve, was tampered with by the Indians, and a box containing liquor was broken open and the liquor stolen, and as a result of this a number of the Indians became intoxicated, and a free fight followed. The matter was duly reported to me, and I mutually arranged with the teacher, that in future all freight consigned to that wharf should be put into the shed, the door locked and him to hold the key. Since that time no further trouble has been reported in regard to freight left on this dock, for distribution amongst the various logging camps in the vicinity. I may say that the Dominion Department of Public Works, under whose supervision the wharf was erected, were very pleased when they heard that Mr. Bruce was willing to care for freight left there, and see that none was stolen. The school in which the teacher lives is situated about 150 Yards from the wharf and overlooking same. I am satisfied that any work done by Mr. Bruce in this connection, does not in anyway interfere with his duties as teacher.

The Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa.
As to the other charges, would say that I do not think that the interests of the school are in any way neglected by Mr. Bruce going out in his boat with his wife and children in the evenings, and picking up a log if he finds same floating in the Straits.

As to the teacher buying fish, I am not aware that he has ever made a practice of so doing, but he might have stored fish in the wharf referred to, pending the arrival of the regular boat to transport same to Vancouver.

I believe that Mr. Bruce is kind to all the children, and I am sure that his wife is very economical, and would not waste any groceries which might have been left there for the use of the pupils. She told me that about a year ago the Indians left some rice which was damaged from getting damp, and unfit for food, so she told the Indians that she had thrown it out.

Trusting this explanation is satisfactory.

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 30th of Aug. 1912 No. 4776, I beg to state that I never said to any one that the church school would not be reopened till they will erect a new church. On my visit up to the Coast, I found that story spread amongst the Indians and I denied it.

Chief Harry of Church House told me that he first heard it at Vancouver, in Mr. Green's office, by a letter from the Department that he read to him. As I was saying that he misunderstood Mr. Green, the school inspector; he assured me that there were six Indians to listen to the reading and that they knew well the meaning of it.

On my return to Vancouver I had an interview with Mr. Green to inquire about this statement; but at my great surprise this Gentleman denied that he ever read anything the kind to those Indians but only read few lines of an official letter inquiring about the Kamloops School teacher, within the church authority, who did send out.

Soon I will have occasion to meet these Indians, I hope to have more information and discover who are invented the above statement.

Dear Sir,

I am taking the liberty of writing to you with reference to a grievance that we have concerning our schoolhouse. Last week the priest, who only visits us once or twice a year, came over to our place & told us that if we did not build another large church he would keep our school closed & that we should not get a teacher.

Now at the present time our school is plenty large enough for all present requirements & we have not the money nor do we desire at the present time to do as he requests & we consider it a great hardship on us if he has the power to do as he has done.

I would be very grateful if you would give this matter your early attention as our children's education is being altogether neglected owing to the school being closed.

Thanking you in anticipation

Yours respectfully,

Sir,

I have the honor to report for the information of the Department that after receiving a number of letters from the Indians at Church House requesting a meeting to consider school matters, I, after visiting Shuswap, met these Indians.

The Hemalce School has been closed since April 1st, when Mr. W. Thompson resigned as teacher. The Indians are very strongly in favor of the school being opened, and fail to understand the difficulty in finding a suitable teacher. They are quite willing to assist a teacher all they can.

I looked over the school building and dwelling house. It is in fair repair, with the exception of a bad leakage near the chimney. The Chief promised to have this fixed the day after inspection. The stoves and cooking utensils were in good shape, likewise school books, slates, etc. But I noticed that the hand cart belonging to the Department (and nearly new) was missing. Sir:

On the 25th ultimo Mr. William Thompson, teacher of the Komakoo Indian Day School, situated on the Aupe Reserve, visited this office and informed me that Acting Chief George Harry had taken the supplies which were sent by me to the school, into his own house and refused to deliver them to the teacher.

On the 26th ultimo Mr. Thompson again visited this office; Acting Chief George Harry also paid me a visit on the same day. In conversation with George Harry, he informed me that he had placed the goods in his house for safe-keeping, as he understood from Inspector Green, that Mr. Thompson was going to leave, and that he, (the Inspector) would be able to supply them with another teacher about the beginning of new year.

On the 2nd inst. I started for Church House (Aupe Reserve), but owing to the fact that a B.C.R. car had left the track, thereby blocking the traffic for some three hours; I did not arrive in Vancouver in time to catch the boat.

On the 6th inst., I visited the reserve which is situated about 120 miles north from here. I held a meeting of the Indians, and I found that they were very much dissatisfied with Mr. Thompson's actions, in regard to the way in which he had been conducting the school; but the greatest trouble seemed to be in connection with the fact that Mr. Thompson, the teacher, had preempted 160 acres of land adjoining the reserve, on which preemption the school is erected; and the Indians had laid out their cemetery.
As this has been reported on fully by my predecessor, I do not think it is necessary for me to dwell upon it further than to say, that I understand, and so informed them, that the Department of Indian Affairs have arranged with the provincial Department of Lands and Works to secure for the Indians, all that portion of Mr. Thompson's preemption on which the Indians had made improvements, or to which they laid claim. I further informed the Indians, that I understood that a provincial land surveyor, named Mr. Rhodes, B.C.L.S., had been instructed to make the necessary survey; Mr. Rhodes having arranged to accompany me up on the boat for that purpose, but for some reason, then unknown to me, he or his representative did not come. I found out afterwards that he had missed the boat.

My reason for wishing to be present with the surveyor was in order that I might use my influence with the Indians, and also with Mr. Thompson, as to where the boundary line of the new survey should be run, as Mr. Thompson claims, that while he is willing to let the Indians have all the land to which in his opinion they have any claim, he is of the opinion that they are asking for more than they are in justice entitled to. The Indians have a tracing of a suggested boundary to this new survey, furnished to them by the Provincial Department of Lands and Works, which no doubt will be a guide to the surveyor when he goes on to the ground to do the work.

In regard to the school, the Indians informed me that they had closed it some ten days previous to my arrival. I pointed out to them, that they had made a mistake in doing so, and that the best thing they could do was to send their children to school, as Mr. Thompson was going to remain and teach until the
Sist of March next. This they all agreed to do, and I am in hopes that there will be no more trouble between the teacher and the Indians, for some time.

I had the school supplies taken from the Chief's house and delivered at the school, and checked them over to see that everything was in order before I left.

Sir,

In further reference to my report on the Hemalce School Westminster Agency, dated Oct. 28th., I have the honor to report that the teacher Mr. Wm. Thompson is doing more harm than good; he is continually quarreling with the Indians. The store and post office which he runs in the school building take up a great part of his time. He also has a chicken house under the school building where he keeps quite a number of chickens.

Mr. Thompson is trying to sell his "pre-emption record" (which includes the ground on which the school building stands, and on which the two Indian graveyards are situated), to other white men, notwithstanding the fact that the Land and Works Department of the Provincial Government at Victoria, have notified him that the ground on which school house and grave yards are, would be taken out of his pre-emption.

The Chief George Harry holds a sketch map given him by the Deputy Commissioner of Lands and Works, Victoria, showing how the survey could be made, so as to add to the Indian Reserve, the land on which the graveyards and school house stand. The Indians would be perfectly satisfied with this.

I beg to respectfully recommend that the Department cause a survey to be made as soon as possible according to the plan purposed as shown in the sketch map given to the Chief.

I had Mr. Thompson and the Indians together. They charged him with drunkenness, which he denied, but admitted drinking, but as his house (the school building) is not at present reserved, he says he can do what he likes on his own pre-emption. One evening near midnight he fired a rifle off fifteen times. He declared he was not drunk, but mad.

It is urgent for the success of the school and the good of the Indians that a survey be made, and that Mr. Thompson be released from the school.
I informed him the school could not continue as at present and that I should recommend to the Department that his services be dispensed with at Christmas. It would be better to close the school than to let things go on as at present, but it would be well for the survey to be made before he quits the school.

I have the honor to remain

Sir,

I beg leave to address you a personal letter, as to the only one, I think, who is able to settle the matter. I appeal to you as a mother for her children, as a missionary for her flock of Indians. Leaving aside all other considerations, I'll bring two points the school and the land, which is the only one that came question with me.

The land: You know by the Indians through their agents and lawyer, one side of the situation. They take honor to show you my side of the version.

On my arrival here, I took a fancy to these children and not being a worldly woman, I devoted myself, heart and soul to their welfare. Thus, I spoke upon Mr. Thompson, my husband, to preempt 160 acres of land adjoining the Indian Reserve (which land we knew by a letter from the land office had been refused to them) with the intention of setting apart 15 or 20 acres for the use of the school. We figured on finishing the building, fence it, make garden, playground, house, chickens, cows, in fact, everything in the way of...
Improving the surroundings for the instruction & comfort of the children, such as we have in every other school—thus making it a permanent school for a time, many years—which if left to Indians, will never be anything but a dilapidated concern, such as it is today.

Just about the time I was to start the new building, we received a notification from the land office, that the Indian Department had made a protest against us having the land, thus we were stopped in building the school, my future dreams scattered to the wind.

Thus far was my letter when Mr. Green, the School Inspector came to examine the school.

At the meeting after school, the Indians brought such a lot of accusation against Mr. Thompson that Mr. Green thought it best to close the school at the end of the quarter. On the moment of the exultation, the heat being in sight and Mr. Green having to leave in a hurry, it was impossible to argue the matter, thus I suppose he will in his report suggest the closing of the school, with the remark that the system on which it is based is not a success.

But talking the matter over, I decided to ask privately a further investigation, now, they for the sake of the children, who are well worth not to close the school at all. That will be the use of so much money spent if the school is closed, think of the future of these intelligent children, with such parents who instead of helping them to improve, are in every way to hinder their progress.

The system—What other system could we have here...
The Indians, having no way of living around here, are obliged to go in different logging camps, thus being away for three or four weeks at a time, thus making impossible to send their children to school.

I think this experience is good and worth very well under the circumstances. It is true we have applied to the Govt. to help with food, etc., now refuse and everything was settled.

False accusations! Who knows the Indians know that they are made of complaint, falsehood, that only those who live with them, know how to put up with their foolishness. All these accusations brought before Mr. Owen were all settled by Mr. K.S., the Ind. Agent five years ago, which you will see by yourself at the time— all the old yarn over again was brought up.

Mr. Thompson has been wanting a length of time and turn over to me the teaching of the school, owing to being advanced in age, it is a little too much worry for him, but, being unable to secure a good woman helper, has been impossible to do so.

Before finishing, permit me to add a few words in favor of Mr. Thompson, might I not you think it is outrageous to turn out in the midst of winter an old man who has served faithfully the Department for so long and who has seen better days. He was grateful to you for his offer, where he looked upon suspension, a gratuity for which he was very grateful. Trusting you will give this a favorable consideration.

I have the honor to be

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I found a good deal of friction existing between the Indians and Mr Thompson, the teacher. In fact they had previous to my arrival at the reserve requested him to resign. The main cause of the trouble appears to be on account of Mr Thompson pre-empting the land adjoining the reserve, on which their graveyard is. I assured the Indians that the Department has the matter in hand now, and would very likely be able to arrange the matter to their satisfaction. Before I left the reserve I succeeded in getting them all in good humor, and they agreed to allow Mr Thompson to continue teaching until July. If the land question could be settled in the meantime, I think they will be satisfied for Mr Thompson to continue teaching even after the 1st of July.

Sir:-

In further reference to my letter of the 8th instant,
No. 247/14, concerning the report which reached the Depart-
ment that Mr. Thompson, teacher of the Homalco Day School,
has for some time past been neglecting his work, I have the
honor to state that I visited the school in question on the
22nd instant and inquired fully into the case, and the only
fault the Indians found with Mr. Thompson was that he did not
open the school, they said, before 11 a.m. Mr. and Mrs.
Thompson, on the other hand, emphatically stated that the
school is in session from 10 a.m. to 12 noon, and from 1 p.m.
to 3 p.m.; and that the children residing in the school
building also receive instructions from 7 p.m. to 8 p.m.;
that these hours are adhered to except on occasions when the
parents are in the village and the children live at home,
and it happens that some of the children are late in arriving
at the school.

Mr. Thompson, who has had a good many years' experience
in teaching Indian schools, does not think it advisable to
keep Indian children longer in school than the above mention-
ed hours.

I reached the school at 7 a.m. on the 22nd instant, on
the S.S. Cowichan, and the mail was carried on the same boat,

J. D. McLean, Esq.,

Secretary Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
and was sorted in about ten minutes after arrival. It contained mail matter for Mr. and Mrs. Thompson and several of the Indians of the band, and also letters and papers for some white men working in a logging camp near the reserve, who came about 8 p.m. for their mail. This constituted the post Master's duties for the day, and as it only occurs once a week, I could not see that the fact of the post office being kept in the school, interfered in any way with the school duties of the teacher; and the Indians are as anxious to have it there as Mr. Thompson is.

The Indians used to bother Mrs. Thompson a good deal in writing letters to Vancouver for them for small supplies such as candy, fruit, pins, needles, thread, etc., and she decided that it would be more convenient for her to keep a small supply of such articles, more to accommodate and please the Indians, particularly the women and children, than for any profit she might make. She showed me the stock she had on hand, which might easily be packed in a suit-case. I asked the Indians if they had any objections to Mrs. Thompson keeping such articles for sale for their convenience, and they informed me that they wished her to continue doing so, as they all like candy, but they never went to the school during school hours.

When I arrived at the school, Mr. Thompson informed me that he was out of fire wood, and I at once went to the Indians and requested them to get to work to provide wood for the school. They all got to work, and in a couple of hours, they had cut and carried out of the bush, enough wood to last for about four months.

Mr.
Mr. and Mrs. Thompson have worked hard since they took charge of the school, and Mrs. Thompson has acted like a good, kind mother to the children, and they have become very much attached to her.

Mr. and Mrs. Thompson were very much annoyed to think that after all they had done for these children, that the parents, who knew nothing about school work, should accuse them of neglecting their duties; in fact, they were so upset about the matter that they had, before my arrival, decided to leave the school, and this would certainly mean the closing of the school for an indefinite period, as it is almost an impossibility to secure the services of a person of any knowledge of teaching to go to such an out of the way place.

From the progress made by the pupils, which I consider compares very favorably with that of other schools, it is evident that Mr. Thompson has not neglected his duties, and the complaint sent to the Department appears to have been got up by Billy Blainey and Alex Paul, who are not classed as the best members of the band.

Before I left the school, all the Indians shook hands with Mr. Thompson, and promised to assist him as much as possible in providing for the needs of the school if he would consent to stay, and he promised to do so.

In view of the fact that the small articles kept for sale by Mrs. Thompson does not interfere with the working of the school, and is a convenience to the Indians, who have no store within ten or twelve miles of the reserve, I recommend that a license be granted to Mrs. Thompson.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

whatever at that time about Mr. Thompson.

A post office was opened on the reserve last year, and Mr. Thompson was appointed post Master, as there was no one else there capable of filling the position. Owing to the fact that there was no post office within ten miles of the reserve, the new one opened at the school is a great convenience to the teacher, the Department, and also to the Indians themselves, who were most anxious to have it there. There is only one mail a week to this office, and as the mail boat arrives at the reserve early in the morning, usually at about 7 o'clock, I cannot see that the small amount of mail matter received there interferes with the working of the school.

I am not aware that Mr. Thompson keeps a store in the school, as I saw no indications of such when I visited there; but there being no store within ten miles of the reserve, it may be possible that Mr. Thompson at times, to accommodate the Indians, has sold them provisions from his own supplies.

Sir,

The Department is in receipt of a communication from Mr. McNaught, Reeve of the Corporation of the District of North Vancouver, written on behalf of the Indians of the Homalco Band, in which he states that Mr. Thomson, teacher of the school, has for sometime past been neglecting his work.

It would appear that a store and a post office have been opened in the school building by Mr. Thomson and it is said that the school is closed all day on each Friday and frequently on other days and that they seldom have more than three or four hours instruction. He refers to a petition from the Indians, but this has not as yet reached the Department.

If you will refer to Section 42, Chapter 81 of the Indian Act you will see that no school teacher on an Indian Reserve shall without the special license in writing of the Superintendent General trade with any Indian or sell to him directly or indirectly any goods or supplies. This license has never been granted in Mr. Thomson's case.

As you are aware a liberal salary is paid him as teacher of this school and $300.00 per annum is paid towards help for Mrs. Thomson in her work as matron. The Department must, therefore, insist upon Mr. Thomson giving his full time to the school work during school hours, if

Dear Sir,

On my return home one of the first happenings I heard of was the death of Chief Joe Capilano, with whom we have always been on the best of terms, and I was much interested to learn that one of the last things he did was to assist in getting in shape a Petition to your Department from the Churchhouse Band of Indians in Bute Inlet. I understand that their appeal has reference to their school there. Over two years ago the Chief assisted this Band to petition your Department for a Teacher for a School they had built, and you sent a Mr. Thomson to teach. This Mr. Thomson for a year did excellent work, and they were greatly pleased to see their children being well taught, but about a year ago, through the influence of the Indian Agent and a priest, he opened a store and at a post office in the school building and now his school work is neglected. It is closed all day every Friday and frequently on other days, and they seldom have more than three or four hours instruction. This is a great disappointment to these people, hence they are petitioning you about the matter.

Chief Joe was keenly interested in this Band, hence out of respect for him I venture to write you personally with these particulars, and I hope you will see that an independent enquiry is made, and the earnest wishes of the Indians conceded.

I am,

Yours faithfully,

Reeve.

Sir:—

Referring to your letter of the 2nd ultimo, No. 690, M.S., requesting a full report on the management of Homalco Day School, and the results of the experiment so far as shown up to the present, I have the honor to state that I visited the said school on the 19th instant.

There were 25 pupils on the roll and 19 in attendance on the date of my visit. I examined them in reading, writing, and arithmetic, and in view of the fact that the school has only been in operation since the beginning of August last, and that none of the pupils could then speak English, and none had previously attended any school, I consider that they have made excellent progress. They read very well in the First Primer, their writing is good, and they can count and add fairly well. Twelve of them are now sufficiently advanced for promotion to the 2nd standard.

Sixteen pupils boarded in the school from the beginning of August to the latter part of December, when the parents returned to the village and took their children to their own houses, except four pupils, who remained inmates of the school all winter, and were still there at the time of my visit.

At the beginning of April, the parents will nearly all be going away to work, and will again leave their children as boarders.

The big girls, whom she expected to assist her with the housework, only attend as day scholars, and, consequently do not help her as was expected they would. MEMORANDUM:

Deputy Superintendent General.

This proposition for a Day School at Homalco reserve, Fute Inlet, B.C., is in the line of our idea for an improved Day School and I think is worthy of consideration. At the same time our policy has been not to increase the schools in British Columbia, or to make any new arrangement there, without carefully considering the whole field. It seems hard to refuse assistance in this case when the Indians themselves have spent nearly $4000.00 on the building. Would it be possible to allow the School to go on as an experiment for a year. I would rather favor that plan. We might offer $600.00; and I would propose to charge it to the first vote for Boarding and Industrial Schools rather than the Day School vote. There is no money provided in the latter vote, and the former vote can bear it.

Sir,

I have the honor to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 27th ultimo, No. 318400, requesting a report from me in regard to a petition received by the Department from Chief William and other Indians of the Homalco band, Bute Inlet, asking for a grant to pay the salary of a teacher on the reserve where they have erected a schoolhouse.

In reply I beg to say that these Indians have, for several years, been anxious to have a school established on their reserve. They have about 30 children of school age, none of whom have as yet attended any school. I have, on several occasions, requested them to send some of their children to the Sechelt school, and others to the Squamish Mission school, as each of these Institutions has accommodation for several additional pupils, but they did not wish to send their children so far from home; and, as they would not consent to send their children to any of the schools already established in the Agency, I advised them that they should join with the Klahoose and Nlakpmx Indians, who are also anxious for schools, and erect a building on some reserve conveniently situated for the three bands, but they would not consent to this proposal either, as they wanted a school on their own reserve. I may add that the Rev.

Father

J. D. Mclean, Esq.,
Secretary Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Father Chirouse, Missionary to these Indians, advised them in this matter along the same lines as myself.

About a year ago, without consulting anyone, they commenced the erection of a school building on their Alpe reserve, where their village is situated. When I visited them in the month of September last, the building was then not quite completed, and there were no furnishings in it.

At that time, they did not wish me to apply to the Department for a grant for them, until they would have their building completed and furnished, and some necessary clearing and grading done around it. As soon as they had everything ready, they were to notify me, so that I could lay their request before the Department.

They have put up a fairly good frame building, the main part of which is 50 x 40 feet, two stories high. The first story has two class-rooms, each 15 x 30 feet, one small room 10 x 12 feet, and stairway. The second story has two dormitories, 15 x 30 feet each, and one small bedroom, 10 x 12 feet. Adjoining the rear of the main building is a kitchen 20 x 30 feet, one story. The building cost in the neighborhood of $4000 and has been all paid for by the Indians themselves. It is fairly well constructed, but has not sufficient accommodation for a regular boarding school, as such institutions are conducted in this agency.

I have just been informed by these Indians that the school building is now completed, and that they will provide the necessary furnishings as soon as provision is made by the Department for a teacher's salary. They say that they would like to have a teacher holding a public School certificate, a man with wife and family preferred, but, as their
their school is in a very isolated locality, there being no white settlers within twenty miles of the village, and passenger steamers calling there only once a week, I fear it will hardly be possible to secure the services of a public School teacher to go to such an out out of the way place, as there is a scarcity of such teachers even further the public Schools of the province.

These Indians, by reason of their occupations, are obliged to be away from their village most of the year, usually taking their families with them, and, in order that the children could attend school regularly, it would be necessary for them to board in the school, at least during the absence of their parents.

In discussing the matter with the Rev. Father Chirouse, he informed me that he can secure the services of a gentleman (I have forgotten his name) who has had several years' experience teaching in the Indian schools of Vancouver Island, and who, with his wife, would be willing to take charge of this school, provided the remuneration were sufficient, he teaching the boys, and his wife teaching the girls, and, with the assistance of the older girls would look after the cooking and other housework, for which he would require a salary of at least $600 per annum, or $300 for each of them.

This, in my opinion, is the best arrangement that can be made, and I would recommend same to the favorable consideration of the Department.

It is thought that the Indians will, for a time at least, be able to provide provisions, &c., for the maintenance of the school, as they have made no request for such assistance.

Towards the end of my inspection the teacher told me that some Indians wished to speak to me. I explained to the teacher and later to the Indians that I WOULD NOT HOLD ANY SORT OF MEETING WITHOUT THE INDIAN AGENT. I was prepared to listen to anyone who wished to speak to me however. Four or five Indians explained the reason why they sent me the petition complaining of the teacher and the school. T. Paul spoke for the others. He was most impertinent and asked me all sorts of foolish questions. I told him to ask the Indian Agent who was the official who had charge of the matter. He explained that there were far more children in the village than were in school that day. I told him that the Indians could not expect their children to get on in school if the parents did not send them to school. He said that the teacher did not ring a bell for school. I asked one of the Indians who looked as if he could understand English if he did not know the time. He said he did. I remarked that if he knew the time he could see that the children were sent to school regardless of any bell.

I asked the teacher to requisition for a new bell and in the meantime to try to mend the old one. All that is required is a large hand bell which the teacher can ring for school.

The whole attitude of the Indians was truculent.

I have read a long letter from Mr. Indian Agent Ball in which he gives the teacher's explanation of points raised in the petition sent by the Indians of Church House to me, and later forwarded to the Department through the Assistant Commissioner for British Columbia. I wish to say that I am in complete agreement with the observations of Mr. Indian Agent Ball as far as the Homalco Indian Day School and the Indians and others at Church House are concerned. I told the Indians that they were in my opinion being made fools of by others, and that the best thing they could do was to send their children to school. They, however, let me know that they do not intend to do this.

In some ways it might be best to transfer Mr. and Mrs. Sowrey to another school in the Vancouver Agency should there be a vacant position, at Sliammon for instance. I doubt that under the circumstances Mr. Sowrey could be expected to do better than he has at Church House. The Indians appear out to upset the Department's work there if they can do so. I am certainly of the opinion that they are being urged on by someone other than an Indian.

These points are all mentioned here as I wish the Indian Agent, Mr. Ball, to know that I entirely agree with him in his estimate of the conditions at Church House.

COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE

26th October, 1937.

Dear Sir:

I have received your 167-33-1 of the 14th instant, with which you enclosed a letter from Mr. Indian Agent Ball addressed to the Department, regarding the situation at the Homalco Indian Day School, Church House.

This situation continues to be given close attention. At present the children have not returned to School but I was given assurances yesterday by one of the local advisors to the Indians of Church House that the children would return to School in deference to my wishes.

Mr. Sowrey has not been a success as a teacher at Church House and, whatever causes there may be for the dissatisfaction that exists with respect to the conduct of the Indian Day School there, this is one of the contributing factors to the present situation, if not the main one.

Inspector Barry, in report on the situation on October 7th, stated:— "I am quite unable to recommend the retention of the services of Mr. Sowrey, the teacher at Church House. He is not in possession of a Normal School certificate, and though he did attend the Provincial Summer School in Victoria last year he appears to have made a complete fool of himself there."

From the information I now have before me, I cannot do otherwise than recommend that Mr. Sowrey be replaced at Church House. He is heartily disliked by both parents and pupils and the continuation of his services there would only tend to aggravate the dissatisfaction that already exists. Mrs. Sowrey's work as Field Matron at Church House has been outstanding, and her services should be secured for one of our other Reserves, if it is possible to make satisfactory arrangements.

After considering all the circumstances involved, I do not think it advisable this time to prosecute the parents under the compulsory provision of Section 10 of the Indian Act.

I would recommend that His Excellency Archbishop Duke be asked to nominate a new teacher and field matron for our work at Church House.

Mr. Ball's letter is returned herewith, as requested.

Yours faithfully,

R. A. Hoey, Esq.,
Supt. of Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,

Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith quarterly report from Mr. W. H. Sowrey, teacher at Homalo Indian Day School, showing that no children have returned to school this term.

I believe you should have the following particulars regarding the situation at Homalo Reserve (Church House). There is a well-kept combined school and residence building on this Reserve, about 100 miles north of Vancouver. The Reserve, of 14 acres in extent, is the headquarters of the Band chief, and is on a rocky bay at the mouth of Burrard Inlet. An old store building holds the Reserve, being occupied by an old French woman of 80, named Thompson, and a nondescript man of about 35 named Prendergast, trading under the name of the Rute Mercantile Company. These are the only white people within some miles of the Reserve. Besides the school building on the Reserve, there is a large Roman Catholic church, a new and substantial council house, and about 35 dwellings, all frame buildings. The Homalo Band numbers 156, of whom about 25 should be attending the day school provided.

The present teacher is Mr. W. H. Sowrey, and his wife is fieldmatron. Mr. Sowrey is well-educated and was formerly science master at Kingsley School, North Vancouver, but does not hold B.C. teaching certificates. His wife is a qualified nurse, and both served during the war. Mr. Sowrey has been teaching at Church House for five years, succeeding Mr. Becher who resigned. Mr. Becher gave as the reason for his resignation the continual interference and unpleasantness experienced by himself and his wife by the two white persons living at the store. Mr. Becher's predecessor, Mr. Garland, was also a stipendiary magistrate, and he sentenced Prendergast to six months imprisonment on one occasion, so although I have no personal knowledge of Garland, he also apparently had trouble with these people.

Mr. Sowrey believes, and I think he is correct, that all the trouble about the school emanates from these people at the store, who apparently resent the presence of any other white people, as it interferes with their solicitation of the Indians. In this connection I should mention that a few years ago, these store people were agitating the Indians to ask for relief, stating they were starving, and the Department advised me to have some relief work done on the Reserve. Orders were given on the store to each Indian for the amount of work done, and when the bills were received, 75% of the purchases were for face-cream, hair oil, face-powder, shaving soap, chocolates and tobacco, showing that there was no destitution. This shows the class of people who are advising the Indians at Church House against schools and Department officials generally.

The man referred to, A. J. Prendergast, has been convicted for trespass on the Reserves; there is no question of
why he goes there. We have records of Church House Indian girls coming to Vancouver and staying at low-class hotels, Prendergast occupying the adjoining room.

Unfortunately, for all of us, the missionary for Church House, Reverend Father P. Flannagan, always makes his headquarters at the store, and is quite unaware of the real character of Prendergast in particular.

Immediately after the summer holidays, Father Flannagan took all the Church House children to Sechelt Residential School without the formality of applying for permission to place them there, and I instructed the Reverend Principal to return them, which he did. The teacher is under the impression that Father Flannagan is opposing the day school, being influenced by the store people. Whether this is so or not, I cannot say. He is very old, and has been missionary for many years, and probably views day schools with disfavour.

I cannot blame the Indians entirely for their present action, as they are no doubt confused in the matter, if they are given the impression that their priest does not approve the day school. This would not be direct, but through the store people. Mr. Sowrey complains that the children are sent to the store for religious instruction, which is given at the school when they attend.

I have mentioned this matter to School Inspector Barry, who is unable to attend to it at present as he is going north. He says he went to Church House last year on this question, and was not received very well by the Indians. Mr. Barry advises me that Mr. Sowrey has not been entirely successful as teacher at Church House, the children have not made the progress they should. Mr. Sowrey admits this, and says the reason is that he has been interfered with continually by the store people and the children have been very irregular in attendance.

The new Chief, Tommy Paul, is also opposed to the school, and Mr. Sowrey says he is instructed by Prendergast and is advising the parents not to send their children to school.

I believe this covers the situation, except that it should be stated that Mrs. Sowrey, as field matron, has rendered invaluable service to the Indians, especially in recent epidemics, and Dr. Lyons, the medical officer, says he believes she saved several lives by her devotion to duty.

I hoped to transfer Mr. and Mrs. Sowrey to Shuswap, when Mrs. Nicholson, field matron there, resigned, but she withdrew her resignation, and it was not possible to do so.

If other teachers had not had trouble at Kamloops School, I should be inclined to think Sowrey was at fault, but Teacher's left there because conditions were impossible. The store woman referred to was at one time paid as teacher at Church House, although the teaching was imaginary, and undoubtedly this is why any teacher will be thwarted. Prendergast was recently before me on a charge of trespass when he interfered with the field matron's
work in one of the Indian houses, but through slackness and incompetence of the Provincial Police prosecuting, I had to dismiss the case.

I respectfully offer these suggestions in the matter:

1. To close the school temporarily, leaving the Sowreys there so that Mrs. Sowrey's work will not be lost to us.

2. Send a teacher there temporarily who could reside with the Sowreys, but could not stay alone on the Reserve. (I do not know whether the Sowreys would remain very long under these conditions).

3. Prosecute all parents under Section 10(4) of the Indian Act.

If it was only a question of replacing the Sowreys, it would be simplified, but in that case, their successors would be under the domination of the store people, and the position of all officials of the Department made impossible. The Nomalco Indians already think the store people control the Department's policy at Church House, and I would not like this opinion strengthened.

Your instructions and advice are respectfully requested.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

[Fred J. Ball]

Indian Agent.

Dear Mr. Ball:

I enclose herewith in duplicate my school return for September. As you suggested at Powell River, it is a nil return.

Actually the number of attendances should have been in the region of 100. There have been more children on the Reserve this month than in any previous September since I came here.

I have already brought to your notice that there was a refusal on the part of parents to send their children to school. No one was ignorant of the fact that school was open. In point of fact I have heard children down the village shouting they heard the bell, which has been rung regularly. Fr. Plamondon was in the village during part of the month, and was aware of facts, but I do not know of anything he did to get children to attend.

Two weeks ago the chief, Tommy Paul, visited you in Vancouver, as you had written him informing him that children should attend school. You informed me that he assured you that he had not told Mrs. Bowrey that he had told them not to attend. This statement made by the chief is absolutely incorrect. I heard him say, in the dispensary, in reply to a remark by Mrs. Bowrey, "Mear that you have told the children not to attend school." That's right". Since his return, children have not attended. Also I have been told that on his return to Powell Bay, he again told a parent, Joe J. Wilson, that no children were to attend school and Joe Wilson from At Cal is said here. Some parents tell me that they have been threatened about sending their children to school. These parents tell me they are willing but afraid.

I notice that again there is an exodus of children to the store in school hours on school days. Not all the children who should be attending school are going, nor do many of the boys appear to be going. The time they may would seem to preclude the idea that they have gone to purchase candy; nor do they appear to be carrying anything on the return journey. This seems to be the same business started by Fr. Plamondon last January which I brought to your attention at that time.

Yours faithfully,

"Mrs. M. Bowrey"
Teacher.
