Sir:

I beg to report that on April 16th I received a letter dated April 1st from Mr. W.J. Phillips. It was headed "Churchouse April 1st" but was mailed in Vancouver April 15th. In his letter he resigned as teacher of the Homalco Indian Day School, effective April 21st. I forwarded this letter to the Indian Commissioner in the usual way.

On the 21st I received a radiogram from Chief Tommy Paul, of the Homalco Band, saying the teacher had left the school and it had been broken into on the night of the 12th instant. I left for Churchhouse on the 22nd, arriving there on the 23rd. Meanwhile I had radioed the B.C. Police boat to meet me and investigate the breaking and entering charge. En route to Churchhouse by gasboat and about two hours run from there, I passed another gasboat which I did not recognize and took the number of it as I usually do in such cases.

Upon arrival at the Reserve, the Chief told us that Mr. and Mrs. Phillips and two others had been to the School, taken some tools to the School, and had taken away some packages when they left about two hours before - this was the boat I had passed earlier.

Upon entering the School - which is a combined school and residence building - we found the tools above mentioned lying on a chair, there was a saw, hammer, chisel and screwdriver all completely covered with red, salt-water rust, and practically worthless. Upstairs we found a few broken rusty tools. Mr. Phillips had advised the Chief that the tools were there when he left and had evidently been stolen when the school was broken into. I could not find out when Phillips left, as apparently he was in and out of the Reserve several times. The date of the breaking and entering was the Saturday following Good Friday, when all the Indians except two were celebrating Easter at another Reserve 25 miles away. The Police searched these two houses as Chief Paul said Phillips mentioned that they had probably done the stealing but nothing was found at their places.

Later in conversation with the Chief, he told me that a departmental cheque for $45.00 which I had sent to him through Phillips (copy of my covering letter enclosed) duly arrived, but Phillips told him to endorse it and let him have it and he would pay it back later, and the chief stated that Phillips told him I had authorized him to use the money. While on the Reserve, the local storekeeper sent a letter to me asking if I could help him collect a $55.00 grocery bill from Phillips but I advised him this was not in my jurisdiction. Dr. Lyons, medical officer, also mentioned that Phillips had borrowed money from him.

We sealed up the School building, and I left on the police boat to locate Phillips. We found their boat late at night tied up at a small dock. I questioned Phillips and...
his wife on the Police boat, and he denied saying I had authorized him to use the $45.00, but admitted that, being short of funds, he had asked the Chief if he could borrow it. As this money represented wages for about 11 men for cutting wood for the School, and did not belong to the Chief, it was an unfortunate thing to do. This money was to be put in a fund to buy shingles to repair the Church roof.

Phillips had bought a gas-boat from an Indian, paying a small sum down and had built a cabin on it and left for Vancouver. This boat had not been registered, and was stopped by the Naval Patrol when it tried to enter the harbour, and taken into False Creek, where it is now held. This Indian says he did not know Phillips was leaving the School, or he would not have sold him the boat. Phillips tried to register the boat in his own name, but the Registrar refused without a bill of sale.

The B.C. Police discovered an unregistered rifle in the boat, and I do not know what action will be taken in either of the above misdemeanors.

Without going further into a long list of his reprehensible actions, I would point out that Mr. and Mrs. Phillips left the Reserve about the end of March or beginning of April and that any salaries due them should be paid until March 31st only. Further, that the $45.00 being held by him, should be deducted from such salary cheque, as this money belongs to several Indians. For that reason I wired you on the 24th requesting his cheque be held pending this report.

I understand that Phillips intends travelling around in the boat he bought, selling insurance. His school work I believe was satisfactory and Mrs. Phillips was field matron, and there was no reason for them to leave. They are both very young and have two small children. Unfortunately, Phillips does not appear to have much balance and his integrity is not beyond question.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Sir:

It has sometimes been my unpleasant duty to report adversely in the matter of teaching at our Indian schools, but I now wish to report to the Department upon the excellent work which has been done during the past year by Mr. J. Gallagher, teacher at Homalo Indian Day School.

Mr. Gallagher has had wide teaching experience, as he has taught at public high schools, but not always does this experience count so much when teaching Indians in the lower grades. The attendance of Homalo School has jumped from about five or six to twenty-five or twenty-eight, which is 100% attendance on the Reserve. The pupils are bright, alert, extremely clean, and well-behaved, and the progress they have made under Mr. Gallagher is amazing. Immediately upon entering the school room, one notices the obedience the pupils have in the teacher and the kindness of his attitude towards the pupils, but discipline is perfect. Mr. Gallagher informs me he has never yet had to punish a pupil. His theory, as told to me, is that each pupil has a head and a heart, and although he may sometimes miss the head and have no scholastic success, he has never failed in his aim at the heart to win the regard of his pupils.

Mrs. Gallagher is field matron, and also has had teaching experience. Homalo is a rather isolated Reserve; their only contact outside being a weekly boat and on account of his experience in high schools, we may not be able to hold him long, which will be an irreparable loss to Homalo.

Dear Sir,

I regret that it is necessary to protest against the manner in which this office is ignored completely in the matter of appointments to day-schools in this agency. A previous appointment was made to Silsillon Day School; and within a short time the teacher was forced to resign because of his actions in connection with some young Indian girls on the Reserve. In the last appointment to Homalco, the teacher proved to be a thief and a rogue. Recently, I hear from the Indians that Mr. and Mrs. Daly have arrived at Homalco to take over the school. In these isolated places, the teacher and field matron are people who can either cause embarrassing situations to the Department, or be of great assistance, according to the type of person employed.

At Homalco, the teacher was incurring all kinds of expenses, chargeable to the Department, in addition to straight theft from Indians and others. I believe that the Indian Agent, as senior official in the agency, is held accountable for what occurs in the agency. Therefore, he should be consulted, or at least advised, as to the kind of people with whom he is expected to work.

In the case of Homalco, referred to above, in addition to the dishonest activities of the teacher, the field matron ran wild in the granting of relief, etc., to Indians, which was absolutely unnecessary. The present incumbents at Silsillon, Mr. and Mrs. Gallagher, are an exceptional fine couple, and I do not see why the same type of people cannot be employed elsewhere. Of course the school inspector is responsible for the academic training; but the agent, who is not consulted about the appointments, is responsible for them otherwise.

Unless much more care is taken in these appointments in future, the Department may receive adverse publicity by the actions of such employees. I would like to say that it was not an easy matter to prevent publicity in both the cases mentioned above.

Dear Major MacKay:

As requested I have read with care Mr. Indian Agent Ball's letter of August 26th last a copy of which was forwarded to you with Departmental letter 167-35-1 of the 8th instant.

With special reference to the first paragraph of Mr. Ball's letter the teacher to whom he refers must be Mr. P.J.A. McGuinness. This teacher was appointed to the Indian day school at Sliammon on the nomination of His Excellency Archbishop Luke. The appointment was of a temporary nature as explained in Departmental letter 167-24-1 of September 1st 1938.

Though Mr. McGuinness had no professional qualifications I did not object to his nomination as Mr. Indian Agent Ball asked me to consider the fact that his wife was a good nurse and he wanted her at Sliammon, see his letter of September 2nd 1938 to the Department.

Mr. McGuinness resigned his teaching position at Sliammon on September 1st 1940 to join the Canadian Active Service Forces, his letter to this effect being forwarded to you by Mr. Indian Agent Ball under date of September 6th 1940.

The teacher referred to in the second paragraph of Mr. Ball's letter was Mr. Phillips who was nominated by His Excellency Archbishop Luke on October 13th 1940, and recommended to the Department in your letter 15/14/8377 of October 19th 1940, and later appointed by Departmental letter 167-35-1 of October 26th 1940. You will note that I was absent at that time and did not see Mr. Phillips at the time you recommended their appointment to the Department.

There is considerable difficulty in obtaining the qualified teachers sought to fill vacancies in Indian day schools, and from time to time those with satisfactory academic qualifications but without Normal School training have been appointed.
The present Departmental policy of having the various Church authorities nominate candidates to fill vacant teaching positions in general works quite well provided the nomination is sent to the Department through your office. For in this case certain records only open to Inspectors of schools may be consulted. It is possible for instance for me to obtain from the Registrar of the Department of Education, Victoria an accurate record of the particular candidates work while at Normal School, and also to see the teacher's reports as filed by Provincial Inspectors at the Parliament Buildings, Victoria. In other cases I can and do consult Provincial Inspectors directly.

None of this could be done by an Indian Agent, and no other Indian Agent as far as I know has suggested that he be consulted before the Department makes appointments since I was appointed Inspector of Indian Schools.

When delay occurs even in forwarding the nominations candidates accept other appointments and when the appointment is made by the Department and the teacher is advised the position is declined, which means that we have again to ask for nominations. Were it decided that Indian Agents should also be consulted it would simply be impossible to fill vacancies, at least with Normal trained teachers.

I do not think it necessary to go into detail into the reasons for the transfer of Mr. C.O. Daly from the Skawah Indian Day School, New Westminster Agency to the Homalco Indian Day School, Vancouver Agency.

The actual transfer of Mr. Daly was approved in Departmental letter 156-2-1 of June 2nd 1941. Your own letter to Mr. Daly 13/9/41 informing him of the Department's decision is dated June 4th last and copies of this letter were sent to Mr. Indian Agent Daunt and to Mr. Indian Agent Ball.

I have been requested by Mr. C.O. Daly, teacher at Homalco Indian Day School, Churchouse, B.C., to send the enclosed letter to you. I have already advised Mr. Daly that we are not responsible for the individual acts of Indians, but he appears to think we are liable in this matter.

The School was closed as usual for the summer holidays last year and the Dalys left for Vancouver, the robbery being discovered on their return to Churchouse for the re-opening of school in September. This is a most isolated place, and few Indians are around the Reserve in the summer. One Indian admitted stealing some groceries, but denied stealing anything else. After he broke in, it was easy for anyone to walk into the house and the police made every effort to trace the property which Mr. Daly says was stolen, but without success in recovering any of it. As the school had been broken into in other years, although nothing was taken, I was surprised when Mr. Daly said they had left jewellery, etc. lying in the school for two months. It seems incredible that such articles as watches, bracelets, medals, etc. were not taken with them when they left Churchouse on their holidays. It is quite possible that white men could have entered the school and the police had one under observation because of his reputation and proximity to the School.

Mr. Daly was not insured against theft. He has had a lot of trouble with the Chief and some of the other Indians and consequently they will not co-operate in trying to locate any of the stuff allegedly stolen. Will you please advise what can be done in this matter, as I feel sure that the Department will not accept responsibility?

B/DH.

We do not understand the last paragraph of your letter in which you refer to an adjustment in her salary. Her salary rate at Seabird Island was $90.00 plus bonus and with the basic salary and bonuses consolidated, it means that she was paid to the end of December at the rate of $112.00 a month. However, the salary paid at Homalco to the former teacher was at the rate of $125.00 per month (consolidation of basic salary of $100.00 and bonus).

We have found from experience that when a teacher is transferred to a school at which a higher salary has been paid than at the school from which the teacher came, there is always a great objection, if we do not allow the increase. I enclose herewith the resignations of Mr. and Mrs. C.O. Daly, teacher and field matron respectively of the above Day School, Church House, B.C.

These elderly people have not been happy at this isolated and rugged place, and I am surprised that they have stayed so long. Under the circumstances, there has not been much improvement at the School and I recommend that their resignations be accepted. Mr. Daly informs me that he will teach Latin and Mathematics at a private school - he had no scope for these subjects at Homalco.

The Homalco Indians are a truculent, quarrelsome and drunken Band. They are rather remote from supervision either by myself or the police, and this adds to the unpleasantness of existence there.

About 20 years ago we employed a man as teacher under similar conditions and he greatly improved the Indians by precept and example. His name is Frank Grist, who is at present in the Veteran's Guard of Canada. If he could be employed at Homalco, it would be a splendid thing for the Indians and the administration of the Reserve. Grist is a fine man of undoubted integrity and does not mind isolation. Evidently he is appreciated in his Unit as he has been promoted to Warrant Officer. He is unmarried, but we could get along without a field matron, as he is a good first aid man and taught at Osyoos and other Indian Day Schools. I have not contacted him of course until I hear from you. He is a Roman Catholic as are the Homalco Indians.

Ottawa, Jan. 14, 1934.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 2nd instant, with reference to the payments of salary in the case of Miss Doris E. Boyle, Teacher of the Komakoo Indian Day School.

I wish to state, for your information, that salaries of Indian day school teachers have, for years, been paid once every quarter. Until recently, the Department of Indian Affairs made four equal payments during the year to this class of employees. This method of payment was found most unsatisfactory and payments are now made quarterly, but on the basis of the number of teaching months in each quarter. It is realized that this method may cause financial inconvenience in the fall of each year, as there is but one teaching month in the September quarter. To obviate this difficulty for teachers as much as possible, it is the Department's practice to make advances in November or December on the employees' earnings for the December quarter.

Relative to the payments to Miss Boyle, I have to inform you that she receives a salary of $700 for the ten teaching months, plus a bonus of $15 a teaching month. Payments are made during the academic year as follows: End of September, $70 and $15 bonus; end of December, March and June, $210 and $45 bonus.

Payment of Miss Boyle's September quarter salary, of $70 and $15 bonus, was delayed because of an error in the Indian office in Vancouver and her cheque was not directed to her until the 3rd of December. The Department of Indian Affairs, realizing that this teacher would be financially embarrassed, sent her on the same date an advance of $100 against her December quarter's earnings. Miss Boyle had therefore, before the Christmas season, a payment of $185.

I trust this explanation will convince you that the Department is considerate in its dealings with Indian day school teachers and I have to add, for your information, that Miss Boyle's relations with the Department have been most pleasant.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.

Dear Sir:

His wife does the correspondence and has promised us time and time again that the amount would be paid to us from his salary earnings.

Sir,

I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of July 9th instant, No. 167-33-3, with reference to the matter of school attendance at Homalco Indian Day School during the June quarter last.

In reply I beg to say that if you will be good enough to peruse the matter contained in the remarks column of the report referred to, it will be seen that the cause given by the teacher for the poor attendance was the absence of the Indian parents at their work.

I would point out that the Inspector of Indian Agencies and I visited the distant stations of the Homalco Indians during the month of June, at which time it was obvious that the teacher could not accompany the Indians as they are separated at many camps. The closing of the school appears at present as the only alternative to the continuance of the arrangements at present obtaining. The Indians must leave the village to work, as there is nothing for them to do at their village. They are at home, however, a great deal in the winter.

I would recommend that Mr. Becher's salary be paid for the full quarter, he having been on duty during the period and available to the Indians.

Your obedient servant,

C.C. Perry
Indian Agent.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 27th ultimo, nominating the services of Mr. W. H. Bowrey as teacher and his wife as field matron to replace Mr. and Mrs. A. H. Becher, who have applied for six months' leave of absence. With regard to a teacher for this school, I have to say that the Department will approve of the temporary appointment of Mr. Bowrey with salary at the rate of $95 per teaching month, less 10% for the current fiscal year.

While the appointment of Mr. Bowrey is temporary, the Department could give no guarantee that the position will be kept open for Mr. Becher. The Department will await a report regarding the success that Mr. Bowrey meets with in the work and in the encouraging of a regular attendance of the Indian children. There has been a very small attendance at this school and, under the charge of Mr. Bowrey, there may be a great improvement both in the attendance and in the classroom work. You should furnish a full report early in the new year regarding the work being accomplished and the attendance, when the retention of Mr. Bowrey for a further period than six months would receive consideration. Please inform Mr. Bowrey of his temporary appointment and the salary he is to receive.

You will be written in a separate communication regarding the appointment of Mrs. Bowrey as field matron.

Sir,

I beg to transmit herewith extract from a letter of the 24th December, which was addressed by Chief George Harry, to Mr. Bury, of this Department. You will observe that the writer of the letter is asking for payment for work done in connection with the construction of a school-house, which it would seem was built more than two years ago. A.F. MacKenzie

Sir,

Referring to Departmental Letter dated the 31st ult., No. 318,400-5, with copy of a communication enclosed, addressed to Mr. H. J. Bury, Supervisor of Indian Timber Lands, written by Chief George Harry, re work performed by him in the erection of the school at Churchouse.

I beg to state that at the time the Department consented to purchase the material for the erection of this School building, it was on the distinct understanding that the Indians would do all necessary work, free of charge, if a competent Foreman was engaged to show them what to do.

The Department obtained the services of Mr. R. Cucksey, as working Foreman, on this job, and the Indians erected the building in accordance with the arrangements entered into previously.

In view of the foregoing I cannot recommend that Chief George Harry or any of the Indians get paid for work performed by them on the School, as they fully understood at the time the building was under construction that they were not to receive any remuneration for their services.

This School was completed in April, 1914.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent,
The Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Extract from June Quarter Return of the Homalco School, B.C.

I should like to call the Department's attention to the following matters:

a.- The water system, which for several years has been in a precarious condition, has completely broken down and I should be glad if the Department will give the necessary instructions to have same thoroughly overhauled and new pipes laid where found necessary.

b.- Due to the school windows looking directly on to the village playground, they are constantly being broken by the football, baseball, etc., I should recommend strong wire screens being placed over at least six of these windows immediately and so help to eliminate the recurring expense of reglazing as well as safeguarding against accidents from flying glass.

c.- The chimney of the school building is in a very bad condition. It should be thoroughly scraped and cleaned and the brickwork repointed. As it now stands there is an ever present danger of fire breaking out and demolishing the building.

William Marsden,
Teacher.
OTTAWA, July 24th, 1922.

Madam:

The teacher of the Homalco Indian Day School, in his report for the June quarter, draws the attention of the Department to the need of wire screens for at least 6 windows of the school building, in order to prevent them from being constantly broken during the games played on the village playground. He also states that the chimney of the school building is in a very bad condition, and recommends that it be thoroughly cleaned and the brickwork repointed, in order to prevent fire.

I shall be pleased if you will arrange to have wire screens placed on the windows of the school building facing the playground. You may also arrange to have the chimney cleaned and the brickwork repointed.

The above work should be carried out at the lowest possible expenditure. Properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, should be forwarded covering the expenses incurred.

These matters should receive your early attention.

Your obedient servant,

for Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Sir,

Referring to Departmental Letter dated the 24th ult., No. 318400-5, in reply would say that I have discussed the question of repairs to the Homalco Indian Day School with Mr. Marden, the teacher, who visited the office recently, he is spending a short holiday in Vancouver.

In order that the School and Teacher's suite may be comfortable, it is necessary that further repairs be made to the building, as considerable hardship was experienced by both Teacher and Matron during the winter months last year.

After a full consideration of all conditions, I would respectfully recommend:

1. Building covered with tar paper and shingled-shingles to have creosote stain.
2. New floor in school-room.
3. New steps to front porch.
4. The present living room being too small, partition moved back three feet into school-room.
5. Small cupboard off kitchen, as at present no provision made for storing food stuffs etc.
6. New brick chimney, as present one is inadequate to carry smoke from existing flues.

I would also respectfully recommend that the above work be completed at once, as it will be more economical, otherwise, in my opinion, teacher's cottage should be erected, it being almost impossible to keep the present building warm, the weather at this particular place being very cold for, at least five months in the year. Also that the material be purchased by the Department and a competent carpenter engaged to perform the work on the building.

The Indians are willing that the total cost be charged to the trust account held by the Department at Ottawa, it was impossible to obtain a petition signed by the majority of the members, as they are nearly all away working in the logging camps.

Your obedient servant,

L. M. Dynes,
Acting Indian Agent,
The Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, Ont.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6394, File 815-5, part 1)
Ottawa, August 25, 1922.

Madam:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 15th instant, reporting on the repairs required to the Homalco Indian Day School and Teacher's Residence.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will approve of the repairs as mentioned by you being carried out. It will be necessary to purchase the material needed, after competitive prices have been first obtained. The material should be purchased from the firm quoting the lowest price.

Arrangements should be made with a competent carpenter to do the work, and you will be good enough to see that all these repairs are carried out at the lowest possible cost. You may arrange to have the building covered with tar paper and shingles so that shingles to have creosote stain. A new floor should be placed in the schoolroom and new steps made to the front porch. The partition in the living room may be moved back 3 ft. in order to provide more accommodation in the teacher's living room. A small cupboard may be built in the kitchen to provide storage room for foodstuffs, etc., and a new brick chimney may be built.

The Department will expect that all the above work will be satisfactorily performed and that no undue expenditure will be incurred. When completed, properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, should be forwarded, covering the expenditure, to which should be attached a memo showing the names of the firms asked to quote on the materials used and the prices quoted. It may be that the teacher can give you assistance in having these repairs carried out.

It is noted that the Indians are willing to have the total cost of the work charged to the funds at their credit in the Department.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

September 9, 1930.

Sir,-

I beg to enclose herewith requisition from the Homalco Day School, teacher's residence.

With regard to the sink, this has been repaired a number of times, but on my last visit it was seen to be beyond further repair and I respectfully recommend that a new one be installed.

The Coleman lamp is necessary as the two oil lamps have to be carried around, and better lighting is needed at the school.

Church House is a cheerless place at the best, especially in Winter, and judging from the general personality of the teachers in the past, it appears to have a bad effect upon the nervous system.

The present incumbents have been there only two years, but already such small matters as broken sinks, insufficient light, etc., assume a tremendous importance in their lives. Mr. and Mrs. Becher are teacher and field matron respectively and are quite earnest in their work.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

[F.J.C.Ball]
Indian Agent.

Mr. Sowrey said he would be pleased to do the work without cost to the Department for labour, as it would be part of the manual training he is giving the pupils. The paint and a brush or two would cost approximately $20.00 and the lumber, nails, etc., a further $15.00, $35.00 in all.

Mr. Sowrey has done a lot of work already, having built a good cabinet for the dispensary, cupboards for the school material, repaired the roof and also the drain-pipes and wood-shed. He says this occupation helps pass the time in their isolation at this cheerless spot.

Mr. and Mrs. Sowrey live on the reserve and there is no other white population and no roads out of the place and it is pleasing to see the way they are both working there. Mrs. Sowrey is a graduate nurse, having served overseas during the War, and is invaluable as field matron, taking her work very seriously, and already well-known among both whites and Indians alike for many miles around the Coast, where there is no doctor and her services are in constant demand.

I held a meeting of this Band when ninety-three Indians of all ages were in a room 30'x20' for over three hours and I remarked afterwards on the entire and unusual absence of odour in such confined space. I learned afterwards that the field matron had persuaded this Band to bathe daily. I think this is most commendable.

I am well aware of all the demands being made upon the Department by the schools and hope this will not prevent this school from being given these necessary repairs.

I have the honour to be,
Sir,
Your obedient servant,

[F.J.C.Ball]

Re: Homalo Indian Day School and residence.

Sir:

With reference to the above building, the drain pipe has been broken for some time and needs repairing as soon as possible—preferably immediately school closes. The material will cost very little and is as follows:

One section of pipe,
Bitumen paint for uncovered portion of pipe,
New trap at intake (wire netting 10" x 3'6" and staples),
Also a galvanized chimney pipe and cowl 10" diameter 2'6" high.

The teacher, Mr. W.H. Sowrey, advises me that if no other labour is available, he will do the work himself, gratis.

The cost plus freight on the material should not exceed £25.00.

Mr. Sowrey has done a great deal of repair work on this building and takes a genuine interest in improving it.

Homalo Reserve is an isolated and rather desolate spot and in the past we have been very unfortunate in the type of teacher employed there. The Department's selection of Mr. Sowrey for the position has proved a particularly successful one from all angles.

In the past we have paid substantial accounts for a plumber to go there to do the simplest jobs on this building, the boat hire being usually higher than the wages and material. As Mr. Sowrey is also unmeasurably superior to any teacher we have had in the past as regards his teaching qualifications and his wife is a trained war-time nurse doing excellent work as field matron, the Homalo Indians are unusually fortunate.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I have your letter of the 31st ultimo, requesting that authority be granted to supply a small quantity of sewing and knitting material for use at the Hemalco Indian Day School.

In reply I have to say that, as our funds are extremely limited, the Department will only be able to authorize an expenditure which must not exceed the sum of $15 in the purchase of the supplies. It might be advisable for you to consult the wife of the teacher concerning the articles required. You may then arrange for the purchase, from a firm on the approved list. Please obtain an itemised account, in triplicate, which you should attach to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and forward for payment. Your File 167-33-5.

Dear Sir:

Under date of October 12, 1932, the Department authorized the supplying of a small quantity of sewing and knitting material for Homalco Day School.

Mrs. K.M. Sowrey, Field Matron and wife of the teacher there, is keenly interested in the girls at the school and voluntarily instructs them in domestic science, during the hours when the boys are at manual training.

Good use was made of the material supplied fourteen months ago and a further supply is needed of some articles, as follows:- sewing cotton, needles, wool, crochet needles, crocheting thread and sewing material, quantities depending upon the amount authorized by the Department. Mrs. Sowrey uses her own sewing machine for instruction purposes although personally I think it would be only fair to supply one. However, no request has been made for it so I leave that point to the discretion of the Department. Twenty Dollars would be sufficient material to carry on with for another year and I hear that uniform dresses for the pupils are to be made if the material is supplied. This is done in the residential school at Sechelt and the pupils appreciate having these uniform dresses.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

In a report regarding his visit to the Homalco Indian Day School on the 12th of June, Inspector Barry states that there are two small leaks in the roof and that there is an odour from the septic tank in the spring. He also advises that the children's toilet is in very bad condition and recommends that two separate single toilets be erected.

You may have the minor repairs done and report to the Department, giving the approximate cost of erecting two toilets.

Your obedient servant,

F.J.C. Ball, Esq.,

203-6 Rogers Bldg.,
Vancouver, B.C.
The house was built on the Indian Reserve during the winter of 1917-18. The foundations appear to be in good condition, as does the roof. There are however two small leaks in the roof, the water coming in near the chimneys, where cement flashings have crumbled. The drainage is to a septic tank. This tank is reported to smell in the spring. I believe that it should be cleaned out this Autumn. The Indian Agent has provided pipes which will take the drainage from the bath, and kitchen, direct to a small creek. It will not run into the above mentioned septic tank.

The children's toilet is in a very bad state of repair. It is falling down, and the teacher pointed out to me that it was dangerous to step into it as the floor was completely rotted away. The pit is full up and in fact the toilet can not be used in its present condition.

I have to strongly recommend the construction of two separate single toilets at this school. There can be no doubt that they are urgently required, and that they should be ready for use for school opening in September, next. The teacher pointed out to me that he was quite unable to clean the present toilet. I should like to suggest that when new toilets are constructed here, padlocks be supplied, and that the toilets be kept locked except when school is in session. The field matron suggested and I agree with her that the old toilet should be burned. The pit should of course be filled in. The new toilets should be located in a fresh position a little farther from the playing field and screened by the small bushes growing there.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 7th July authorizing minor repairs to the school building as per Mr. Barry's report to you.

The necessary material is being sent up to Homalco School and to save freight I shipped at the same time enough lumber to build two toilets. The cost of roof repairs and building two toilets will be approximately $50.00 with freight, and I trust this action will be approved by you although I have not received definite authority for the latter.

All the work will be done by the manual training class under the instructions of the teacher, Mr. Sowrey, without cost for labour. I consider these small jobs much more valuable as instruction than work done in the class room as it is more in line with what they will do after they leave school. Although Mr. Barry did not report it, the school woodshed is leaking badly and needs repairing and there should be enough material left over to do that job also.

Regarding the septic tank, this work can not be done at present, but will be taken up at a later date. We are not sure of the cause of the odour and on the return of the majority of the Homalco Band to Church House it will receive further attention. Sir:

I beg to advise that the teacher of Homalco Indian Day School, Mr. W.W.H. Sowrey, has applied for the following articles for the school building:

1 Kitchen range.

Material for School Fence:

- 2 rolls netting wire 2" mesh,
- 500 ft. lumber 5" x 3",
- 1 lb. Spikes 4",
- 1 lb. Staples for netting,
- 4 lbs. nails 2" headed,
- 2 lbs. paint, green.

Mr. Sowrey applied some time ago for these articles but it was held over as we thought Mr. Phelan might visit the school and see what was required.

The netting is required because the Indians have a village football team which plays quite close to the residence and windows are being broken regularly. It is the only flat piece of land on the Reserve.

The cost of the range, lumber, netting, etc., would be approximately $75.00 and the freight about $5.00 to $7.50, according to space required on the boat.

The range has been burned through and is almost useless.

The residence is occupied by the teacher and his wife who is field-matron and they keep the building in excellent condition. There would be no expense for labour in building the fence as Mr. Sowrey would be pleased to do it in spare time.

Dear Mr. Bell,

Many thanks for information and valuable suggestions contained in your letter of the 11th and 16th inst.

Campbell has been here for the first three or four days. He has shown me your letter to Louise Nelles case. Campbell says that the woman has not been living with the man, but for some considerable time, and that the case can not be considered as settled satisfactorily.

Re wood for fuel.

I have received two cords. It is the largest the Indians could get, but it is really very green and therefore hard to burn. We have tried it on the stove, but it does not work well. I am foreseeing difficulties with wood range and want to make it fit to cook with. I am foreseeing difficulties with wood range and want to make it fit to cook with. I am foreseeing difficulties with wood range and want to make it fit to cook with. I am foreseeing difficulties with wood range and want to make it fit to cook with.

I hope it is all right. In fact the questioner for question is with the wood consumption. The eight gals applied for should last a long time as I have used only 2½ gals during the five weeks. I have been able to save more. I will need more after next week. A gal. will last considerably longer than the same quantity of gas. I am wondering what the two gas lamps I have are useless unless they can be repaired. Unfortunately I brought two gas lamps here with me.

Re tools.

I am not requisitioning any tools for manual training, those I am calling for are those which in my opinion are indispensable to the proper upkeep of a house and grounds. Yet will probably work; why I am ordering wash basins and wash pans. The fact of the matter is that the kitchen sink and also the washing room will have to be in working order once we arrive. The whole plumbing of the house is out of order and the water at times unattractive, so much so that we have to close all the doors and let down the windows. We thought at first that some animal had died under the house but some diagnosis—inspired by the plugging of the water—showed the true state of affairs though not until several pounds of food and other food stuffs in the cooler were over one of the cool pots had been spoiled.
It is beyond me to fix this, even if I had the lumber and fittings which I have not. As it is, it is a serious menace to health. I am not going to wait for this until you visited the house, but it struck me that unless I did you would not see the need for washbasins and pans. Some of the former tenants must have experienced the bad smells because in the course of the digging I found several obsolete oil lamps which evidently had been pierced and then buried to serve as deodorants. It seems to me that a large area of soil underneath the house and outside the house on the east and south sides has been saturated with the overflow.

Mr. Oah and myself are very thankful for your good wishes. It will probably require an effort to settle down, but we must do so and to leave nothing undone to make our stay here as pleasant and profitable for you and for our Indian charges as it is humanly possible to make it.

Your very truly,

C.O. Agh.
Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith requisitions received from Mr. W.O. Daly, teacher at Homalco Indian Day School, who has just been transferred there from another agency. Every assistance will be given to Mr. Daly in making a success of his work there.

The first requisition is for material required at the school residence and around the building, which is badly overgrown with brush. There has been no teacher there since March.

The second requisition refers to school supplies and the third to fuel for the building. As there was very little fuel left by Mr. Daly's predecessor, I have authorized two cords, pending your approval, which I trust will be satisfactory.

Mr. Daly reports that the drainage system is out of order, and I enclose his letter regarding it. Apparently, this needs the services of a qualified plumber, but nobody can say what the cost will be until it has been opened up. There is no plumber anywhere near Homalco and it will be necessary to send a man there from Vancouver. It would take 4 days for a man to go there, inspect the work to be done and return to Vancouver, and I would suggest, if the work is to be done, that the man be employed to do it while he is there, rather than make two trips. However, you may wish to make some other arrangement, and I respectfully request your advice in the matter. I have had no previous complaint regarding the plumbing.

I have the honour to be,

sir,
your obedient servant,

B/DH.

Sir:

re: File No.167-33-5.

With reference to the enclosed voucher, covering work done at Homalo Indian Day School and residence, as authorized by you, I beg to advise that it was necessary to send a man who was experienced in the work rather than a plumber. I, therefore, asked Mr.R.R.Stiller, of Grantham's Landing, B.C., to go to Homalo and put the sewage disposal system in good order.

He found the whole system over-flowing and the pipes clogged, and it was necessary to construct an entirely new septic tank, and empty the old one. Stiller is a practical man and made cedar planks and pipes and completed the job without the necessity of purchasing any material whatever. A second tank for the kitchen was also necessary, and he made that also. Apparently a good job was done, as the teacher reports everything quite satisfactory.

As there is only one boat a week to Homalo, he worked all the daylight hours, and sometimes after dark and was able to take the first boat out. He has charged only for his labour, and nothing for travelling and other expenses which must have amounted to at least £15.00.

The job, in consequence, has cost considerably less than I anticipated, and the account is respectfully submitted for payment.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith a requisition for material at the combined Homalo Indian Day School and residence. I also enclose a letter the teacher has written to me in explanation of his requests.

It is quite true that these replacements should be made as some of the furniture which has been used by many teachers is in a deplorable state, and if funds can be found, I recommend that the request be favourably considered.

With regard to fuel, this has long been a troublesome matter. All good wood logs have been used up long ago and it has become a problem to obtain wood. The Indians will not cut and haul it when they can do any other work. Coal appears to be the only solution, and would probably be cheaper than wood. The teacher asks for 1 ton only as a trial, and I respectfully recommend that this be supplied, and a further report made later as to the success of it.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Dear Mr. Ball,

Please find enclosed requisition in quadruplicate for school materials regarding which it may be necessary to state the following facts:

Lamps. When I woke up only two last fall I found the two genuine lamps in stock out of order and therefore useless. Fortunately I had brought two old lamps of my own along not knowing what I might be up against. After a year service here without standing some rough beat spring—these lamps are now useless and need to be replaced with new ones.

Mattresses there were three in stock. They were ragged, stained and smelly. One was so bad that I turned up the two others I have never used much preferring to use two belonging to myself that I brought along with me. Of course when I have those will go along with me and new ones must be supplied for the next teacher as no self-respecting person would sleep on the old one.

Coal, the fuel situation here is a constant worry. Several times I have run down almost to the last sticks. The wood supplied is generally of the poorest quality, being what the Indians term "country" and saturated with "hide-wax." At present I have but more than half a cord on hand and there is no prospect of getting any for months to come. Some of the Indians I have spoken to
about getting fuel at #6.00 a cord just laughed at me. They say they can get from #8.00 to #10.00 a day in the lumber camps and that it would be wasting their time to handle fuel wood at less than #10.00 or #12.00 per cord. For these reasons I am asking you to help me along for the present by giving me a ton of coal for cooking purposes.

Window shades. It is but the bare truth to say that we have none worthy of the name. They have been torn and have had pieces cut off and then re-tailored until only remnants of the originals remain and these can neither be pulled down nor rolled up.

The requisitions that I am making for lamps, mattresses, linoleum, window shades and a chair, are all for standard equipment & replace articles rendered useless through age and long service. Not one of them can be classed as a luxury. They are all essential to the most modest standard of housekeeping and will not need to be replaced again for many years and I am therefore hoping that you will kindly sanction them.

Your sincerely,

[Signature]

With reference to your letter of April 24th last, regarding need for new toilets for Homalco Indian Day School, I have only now been able to locate someone in the vicinity of Church House, who will do this work.

No lumber is available in the district.

I enclose a requisition for material for two toilets and for new steps in front of the school entrance.

The present steps are in very bad repair and are a hazard. They should be replaced before someone is injured. The school teacher has located a carpenter but he cannot give an estimate of total labour costs, merely stating he will do the erecting at a rate of $1.00 per hour.

Mrs. Oulton undertakes to keep a record of his time, and to ensure that his time is fully occupied, and from what I know of her she will protect our interests in that respect.

The local rate for carpenters is now $1.40 per hour.

(H. E. Taylor),
Indian Agent.

Reference enclosed requisition for a radio-telephone for the Homalco Indian Day School teacherage. I would advise as follows:

This school serves the Indian village of Churchouse, which is an isolated community of Indians only.

The school teacher has no contact with white people nearer than on Stuart Island some five miles distant. There is no telegraph or telephone communication between Churchouse and outside points, it being necessary to go to Stuart Island for such.

In view of the isolation, the lack of police supervision, and the turbulent conditions which prevail owing to the excessive drinking habits of the Indians, it is considered essential that the school teacher be enabled to send out messages by radio-telephone.

The model requisitioned will enable messages to be radio-telegraphed from Churchouse to Cape Lazo on Vancouver Island and they are transmitted from there as ordinary telegrams.

It is not considered necessary to establish connection by telephone also, as such radio equipment costs several hundred dollars, requires installation by a technician, and a small power plant to charge batteries.

The model recommended can be set up by any user and one battery can service the set whilst the other battery is being re-charged at Stuart Island.

At present telegrams to the teacher are only accepted for Stuart Island and remain there until an Indian boat calls for them. As some of the Indians will read or neglect to deliver the telegrams, the operator is reluctant to hand them out for delivery in this manner.

It is very necessary from every viewpoint that some direct communication be established to this isolated point and I would strongly recommend approval of purchase.

[Signature]

(H. R. Taylor)
Indian Superintendent.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

October 19th, 1949

The attached application dated September 9th from Supt. Taylor, and enclosures with regard to the proposed installation of a radio telephone at the Homalco Indian day school teacherage, has been the subject of careful consideration and discussion with District School Inspector Davey and it is agreed that in view of the circumstances it would be most desirable to have this equipment installed.

You will note that the initial cost is $270.00 and maintenance will consist only of recharging the batteries periodically. Mr. Taylor's proposal is recommended for favourable consideration by the Department.

Encl.
Reference enclosed requisition for heaters etc. for the Homalco Indian Day School at Church House, I would advise as follows:

There is a wood burning heater in the school classroom and a wood burning heater in the sitting-room in the teacherage, which is attached to the school building. These two heaters are connected to the same chimney.

As oil is used in the kitchen range in the teacherage it would be more economical and labor-saving to provide oil heaters to replace the above mentioned wood burning ones.

It is difficult to get wood delivered at Church House, and the present set-up is a fire hazard, the wall having been badly scorched on two occasions by overheated stove pipes.

Asbestos boards are included in the requisition for installation on the walls behind the heaters. An additional Coleman gas-lamp is necessary, as the one at present in use has to be carried from room to room. Broken window panes also need replacing.

In view of the isolation of this school, it is necessary that it be made as attractive and comfortable as possible if teachers are expected to remain.

Purchase of the above is recommended.

(H. E. Taylor)

OPERATION - Schedules with the Cape Lazo (VAC) radio station shall be arranged by the District Superintendent of the B.C. Radio Service. Signals are to be exchanged between the stations at the standby times when any messages on hand are to be disposed of.

OPERATOR - Should the operator not work the station to the entire satisfaction of the Department, the Minister reserves the right to call for his discharge, when the licensee must replace him by another qualified operator without delay (it is understood that this action will only be taken by the Minister in an extreme case, such as wilful interference or disobedience of orders issued by the controlling station.)

CONTROLLING STATION - The Cape Lazo (VAC) radio station will act as controlling station for the licensed station, and the operator at the latter station must implicitly obey any and all instructions issued by the former.

COMMUNICATION WITH OTHER STATIONS - The operation of the licensed station is to be limited to communication with the Department of Transport station at Cape Lazo (VAC). No other stations of any character whatsoever are to be worked except in case of distress or urgent necessity.

MESSAGES FROM THE PUBLIC - The licensee must accept messages to and from the public in accordance with Regulations issued under The Radio Act, 1938.

TOLLS - (a) The "Government Wireless" charge on all messages handled between the licensed station and the controlling radio station will be 25¢ for the first ten words and 2¢ for each additional word, address and signature free.

(b) On messages destined to or received from the outside public at the licensed station, an additional wireless charge of 25¢ and 2¢ will be allowed, this charge to be credited to the licensee.

DELIVERY - Messages destined to offices beyond the Government terminal radio stations will be handed over to the landline for delivery and the regular landline rates in force between these stations and the office of destination will apply on such messages.

The Department reserves the right to transfer the messages to the landline at any of its stations.

ACCOUNTING - Statements and Accounts shall be made up and rendered monthly and adjustment, if any, made with the least possible delay.

Authority to use the frequency or frequencies specified in this licence has been granted on a temporary basis and may be withdrawn, if necessary, in order to comply with any future Regional or International Agreements.

Sitt Meadows, B.C.,
Feb 18, 1914

Peter Byrne,
Indian Agent,
Whitehorse.

Dear Sir—

The Indian children attending Sitt Meadows Public School, owing to the school filling up with white children, and the added burden in the way of school taxes, we do not feel that we should except Indian children from Whitey's Reservation. We are of the opinion that your department should establish a school for them, on that Reservation, as an undertaking is being done at other places. The Indians are showing a desire for learning now, more so than at any time in the past, and this desire should be encouraged, and while Public School trustees, will do what they can, a good many will not want to face the friction that might result from the mingling of the races. Also we think the Indian children would do better with a teacher of their own, one who understood them, and could give his whole time to them.

Yours very truly,

J.W. Harris,
Sec Sitt Meadows School Board

Katsey Indian Reserve,
Feb. 16 1914

We the members of the Katsey Band of Indians in meeting assembled respectfully ask the Government to open a School for us on our Reserve. Some of our children have been going to the White Schools here. But lately they have not been allowed to go, as the White people said when they sent our children home that their School was full. We have twenty-five children of School age, as shown by the accompanying list.

We will supply a building 13x28 ft. the Government furnish it and supply a teacher.
Indian Office, New Westminster, B.C.
February 23rd, 1914.

Sir:—

For many years the children of the Katsie Band of Indians attended the white school in the vicinity of their reserve, and no objections were raised to their presence until recently when it appears the New Comers objected very strongly to the Indians attending the same school as their children.

The parents of the Katsie children visited this office recently and brought with them the Secretary of the Pitt Meadows School Board, who stated that while he, personally, had no objection to the Indian children going to the school, as he was an Old Timer, yet it was absolutely necessary that these children should be prevented from attending this school in future.

I held a meeting of this Band and the Indians are willing to provide a building large enough for a school, if the Department will furnish them with a teacher and school material. At present there are twenty-five children of school age on this reserve and I would respectfully recommend that the Department establish a school for them.

I am enclosing herewith a petition from the Indians of the Katsie Band, together with a census of the people who reside there, and also a letter from the Secretary of the School Board.

Your obedient servant,

I beg to report that I visited the new school on Katzie Indian Reserve on the 26th ultimo, and carefully examined the building in which school is now being held. It is 27 X 35 ft. with a loft ceiling. The building, although an old one, has been repaired and altered, and I believe will answer very well the purpose for which it is used. The Indians have put in a new floor and ceiling and lined up the walls on the inside so that it now looks clean and neat. There are four large windows which will supply ample light, they can be opened from the top, and this with a loft ceiling will ensure plenty fresh air for the pupils while in session.

The Indians generally are very enthusiastic in their expectations of the results of this school and wish me to convey to the Department their sincere thanks for supplying a teacher and school material for them. I expect to visit this school again during the present month and will report fully to the Department the progress made and the conditions existing.

I beg to report that Mr. John F. Wilson, Teacher of the Katzic Indian Day School resigned the position last week, to join the 211 American Battalion for Over Seas Service. Immediately on Mr. Wilson advising me of his decision to resign, I communicated with the Missionary in charge of these Indians, who recommends the appointment of Mr. P. B. McGarrigle, whose application I am enclosing herewith, together with testimonial from Rev. Doctor Wm. P. O'Boyle, as to the character and qualifications of the applicant.

I visited this school on Monday last, the 27th inst., and placed Mr. McGarrigle in charge of it as teacher. This was necessary as there is one pupil, at least, in the Entrance Class, and the parents were very anxious that the school should continue. Mr. McGarrigle is a man with a wife and four children and I believe he will make a very efficient teacher, as he seems to be very sympathetic towards the Indians.

In view of the foregoing, I would respectfully recommend that the resignation of Mr. J. F. Wilson be accepted, and that the application of Mr. McGarrigle for the position be approved by the Department.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Confirming what I said to you verbally the other day, I am very pleased to speak regarding the very excellent qualifications of Miss Mary W. Traiman for your Indian appointment at Port Hammond.

Firstly, as to character, personality, and influence for uplift; it would be extremely difficult to find a more ideal worker. Another sister is entering her third year in our public school service and is giving entire satisfaction.

Secondly, as to qualification or training, though
The Junior has no B.C. Certificate for her academic standing is of a high order.

Not alone qualified to teach the academic branches, she can teach Domestic Science and Domestic Art, clay modeling, painting, drawing, sketching, woodwork, dress making and sewing, weaving, music, vocal and instrumental music, first aid, and a course in education.

These are all more or less valuable qualifications on the part of any teacher particularly for an Indian school where fitting for life's duties and happiness counts for far more than mere "book cramming."

I am pleased to say that this young lady will be able to give a sound practical education in any or all of these.

In a word, I most strongly commend this Junior to our Chief Selection Board and rely she will give entire satisfaction.

Dear Major MacKay:

Mr. Roy Edwards, who lives with his wife and at least five children of school age on the Pitt Meadows Stock Farms Limited within a few hundred yards of the Katzie Indian Day School, has requested that permission be given for his children to attend the above mentioned school in the New Westminster Agency.

You will remember from reading my report on the Katzie Indian Day School that the attendance there is very small and not at present above eight on an average.

The teacher Miss Winter has no objection to receiving the Edwards' children. I have consulted the Indian Agent, Mr. Daunt, and the Provincial Inspector of schools, Mr. D. Daniels, and neither has any objection to the strictly temporary accommodation of the Edwards' children at the Katzie Indian Day School. It has been pointed out by the Provincial Inspector of schools that the Official Trustee has made reasonable arrangements to pick these children up by means of the School Bus, but that the children would still have to walk a certain distance.

I would recommend that the children of Mr. and Mrs. Roy Edwards of the Pitt Meadows Stock Farms Limited in Grades one to six inclusive but in no higher Grade, be given permission to attend the Katzie Indian Day School, New Westminster Agency, during the pleasure of the Indian Affairs Branch. I would further recommend that if this permission be given, the parents of the children be informed that such permission is only of a strictly temporary nature, and that it will be withdrawn at once and without notice should the children in question become in any way troublesome to the teacher, or the attendance vacant seats in the schoolroom be required for Indian children. It would be possible to terminate the proposed arrangement at any time upon the recommendation of the Indian Agent at New Westminster and without reasons for such action being of necessity given to the parents.

The whole file in this case has now been forwarded to you, but I may say that Mr. Indian Agent Daunt has been supplied with a copy of each letter. As I am leaving for an extended inspection itinerary in the northern part of the Province, I would request that the Department's decision be transmitted directly to Mr. Daunt, as soon as it is received from Ottawa. I have informed Mr. Edwards that consideration is being given to his request and that he will be informed in due course through the Indian Agent at New Westminster of the decision of the Indian Affairs Branch in this matter.

Yours very truly,

Gerald H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

Sir:

I have to refer again to yours of the 19th ultimo, enclosing an application for salary increase from Miss Helen Coughlan, Teacher of the Katzle Indian Day School.

I have to inform you that the Department cannot view favourably Miss Coughlan's application for an increase in salary. Indian day school teachers in Canada receive, on the average, less than $650 per annum. It is true that salaries are higher in British Columbia than in any other province, but the Department cannot see its way clear to offer Miss Coughlan another increase. She has taught at the Katzle Indian Day School since September, 1917, beginning at a salary of $600. She received increases of $100 on each of the following dates: July first, 1918, January first, 1920 and January first, 1921. She is being paid at present at the rate of $900 per annum, plus whatever bonus is allowed by law.

You may inform Miss Coughlan of our decision and assure her that the Department, in refusing this application, is not casting any reflection upon her ability as a teacher. We are hesitant about paying her a larger salary, in view of what other teachers at Indian day schools are receiving. The Department wishes to thank Miss Coughlan for her faithful and excellent work, and I trust that she will see the situation from our standpoint.

Dear Sir:-

The Department is in receipt of your letter of November 1 with reference to the request that has been received to allow the children of Mr. Roy Edwards to attend the Katzie Indian Day School.

As you are aware, the Provincial Government requires that this Department pay for any Indian child attending a "white" school within the Province of British Columbia at the rate of $20.00 a year, based on the average attendance.

The Department has no objection to Mr. Edwards' children attending the Katzie school on the same terms as in the case of Indian children attending "white" schools. It should, of course, be further understood that this permission is only of a temporary nature and that it will be withdrawn at once and without notice should the children in question become in any way troublesome to the teacher, or if the accommodation at present vacant in the school is required for Indian children.

I feel it should also be possible to terminate the proposed arrangement at any time, upon the recommendation of the Indian Agent at New Westminster and without reason for such action being of necessity given to the parents.

SIR:

We have had, in the past, some considerable trouble in getting many of the children of the Katzie Band to attend the Day School on their No. 1, Reserve.

This was really not their fault, as there are more than half the school-age population on the No. 2, and No. 3, Reserves across the Fraser River from the village on the No. 1, Reserve, where the school is situated. Hitherto, the cost of a definite transportation system has been too high, but I am now enclosing an offer from Andrew James, an Indian on the No. 3, Reserve, to make the necessary trips for One Dollar per day. There are at present thirteen children of school age on the south shore, who would thus be added to the present school list. At the moment, there are only nine pupils on the register.

I would recommend that if at all possible, this offer be accepted, and an account submitted by the teacher, at the end of each month, for the number of days on which Andrew James brought pupils to the school. The above nomination has been discussed with Inspector Barry who informs me that Miss Daly is the daughter of Mr. O. Daly, teacher of the Skawah Indian Day School, that she has just completed her professional training at the Vancouver Normal School and, though quite inexperienced, might well prove a success at a small Indian Day School such as that on the Matzie reserve where boarding accommodation with white people is available at a reasonable distance. Inspector Barry will give Miss Daly detailed instruction with regard to the work to be covered, etc., should her appointment be approved.

Will you please let me know, by air mail if possible, the Department's decision, at the same time mentioning the salary that will be allowed to Miss Daly if approval is given this appointment.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

D.H. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

AIR MAIL

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 13th instant the Department approves the appointment of Miss Maureen Daly as teacher of the Katzie Indian Day School for the academic year 1940-41. She will be allowed salary at the rate of $105.00 a teaching month for the nine-month period October 1, 1940, to June 30, 1941.

I enclose staff questionnaire which you should have Miss Daly complete and return to the Department as soon as she begins duties.

Yours truly,
